content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Playing this game is rather like watching the proverbial train wreck: you'll be horrified, but you can't look away. This is in no way a bad thing. Spec Ops wants to tell a story about soldiers in war. But unlike games such as Call of Duty, it doesn't want you to feel like an awesome, unstoppable killing machine that's fighting terrorism FOR 'MERICA!!! or whatever; it wants you to see that war is not glamorous, awesome, fun, or desirable. It wants you to see the terrible toll that combat can exact on those who experience it. And above all, it wants you to see that in real conflict, there are no "good guys" and "bad guys," and the world is full of gray areas. War is hell, and anyone who goes in will either join the fortunate dead...or have to live with what they've done to survive.Spec Ops is a third-person cover-based shooter that alternates between desert environments and crumbling urban ruin. You have two squadmates who can be directed to attack specific targets or heal a fallen comrade; they're pretty good at following orders in a timely fashion and, unlike some other AI partners, they're not highly prone to getting themselves shot constantly or hung up on the level geometry. Enemies are decently clever, more than willing to flank you, toss grenades to get you out of cover, or trick you into walking right into a Heavy Trooper's line of fire.The game also offers the clever idea of having drifts of sand piled up on fragile surfaces like windows, which you can shoot out to bury your enemies. It doesn't show up that often, but it's kind of neat when it's there.There's the usual shooter stable of weapons: pistols, heavy pistols, shotguns, sniper rifles, etc. They sound good and feel decently punchy, and aiming is never a problem. Most weapons also have an alternate fire mode, which does add a little depth to the combat.I didn't play the multiplayer, so I can't honestly review it. I will say the developers originally didn't even want multiplayer, and the campaign is designed well enough to stand on its own, so make of that what you will.I highly recommend this game. It is a breath of fresh air in an over-crowded genre that's becoming increasingly generic. This game is also visually stunning, with exceptional voice acting, and sound. It is definitely worth the money and the effort to play the game from the beginning to the end.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												About halfway through Yager's third-person-shooter Spec Ops: The Line, in one of the game's most controversial moments, I found myself disgusted and infuriated. Not at the scene I'd just witnessed, or at the game's statement as a whole, but rather that it even needs to be said at all. Two of the ten bestselling video games of all time are Grand Theft Auto V and Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2. The "military shooter" is one of the most successful genres of the last ten years, and the objective of these games is to kill people. Lots of people. We eat it up non-stop, and always, always ask for sequels seconds. In order to keep the profit margins wide, we are encouraged to never think about it, to never stop and look at ourselves with a critical, compassionate, clear eye. Of course, it's not only Hollywood that benefits from the blinders we've all put on, since only the desperate and crazy would fight our wars for us if it weren't for the glorification of war peddled by the governments of this strange, sad world upon which we find ourselves spinning through the abyss.In an ideal world, these things wouldn't need to be said and all of this would be a moot point. Games like The Line would be seen as a gratuitous miserywank, and people would rightly ask, "Why do we need something like this?" But we don't live in an ideal world, and as gamers, we inhabit a very flashy and seductive yet still a very small and confined space where, ever since John Carmack created Wolfenstein 3D and Doom and ushered in the era of the ultraviolent shooter genre, there is an elephant in the room covered in blood and gore. As such, The Line is a game that needed to be made, its message one that we need to listen to.The plot, involving a small group of elite U.S. soldiers sent to Dubai on a rescue mission in the midst of a freak sandstorm that all but destroys the city, is adapted from the novella Heart of Darkness[en.wikipedia.org] by Joseph Conrad, which also inspired the movie Apocalypse Now[en.wikipedia.org]. The themes of both are intact here -- the horrors of war, the darkness that lives in the soul, and the lengths to which the human mind will go to rationalize its own nature -- but I would argue that they are made much more effective by the vicarious immediacy of the video game medium, and because so much of gaming involves visiting death on whole populations of pixellated AI effigies. Here, the formula is largely unchanged; indeed, you mow down an impressive number of folks with a variety of well-represented handguns, rifles and heavy weapons, but unlike your regular military shooter, The Line invites and occasionally straight-up forces you to think about the enemy soldiers: who they are, what their motivations are, and of course, how they die. The writers at Yager accomplish this in several ways, some with all the subtlety of a sledgehammer to the face, but others which surprised the sheer hell out of me with their deft use of the medium's voyeuristic and user-participation elements. Spoiler: There's one such moment available in the demo after you use a zipline to reach a building where you sneak up on a pair of soldiers overlooking the ruined city. Their quiet, wistful conversation together is human, poignant, and, because you have no choice but to kill them to proceed with the mission, painfully affecting.A lot has been written about this game[en.wikipedia.org] and I doubt I'm saying anything new. It is well-deserving of its praise. It's mature and uncompromising. The characters are believable, sometimes heartbreakingly so. At one point I questioned Yager's decision to use the third-person perspective instead of first-person; it seemed to me that the latter would have been much more powerful. But when you stop to wheel the camera around and look at your character, you don't see your typical hardcore BAMF with the obligatory, almost muscular, furrowed brow, the thin, tight, all-business lips, the hard eyes, etc. You see a soldier scared for his life, scared for his soul. His eyes dart everywhere like a cornered animal, he breathes unsteadily, he looks like he feels: horrified, nauseated and on the edge of tears.The devs say that the story is open to interpretation, but for me, the game is at its heart an honest illustration of post-traumatic stress disorder, or as George Carlin would say, "shellshock":


YouTube™ Video: George Carlin   Shell Shock 

			Views: 125,429		

			this is my tribute to George Carlin. the teacher teaches. i do not own this video.		

If George were still around and had been a gamer, he probably would've approved of Spec Ops: The Line. He was first and foremost an observer of life, a philosopher who just happened to be funny as hell. This is not a funny game. One of the characters starts off as the typical comic relief character that all shooters seem to require, but like Pvt. Joker in Full Metal Jacket[en.wikipedia.org], he sobers up fast and his wisecracks dry up completely during the events of the game. It's almost a shame the cover-based shooting mechanics are so well done, because I find myself torn between wanting to do another playthrough and not wanting to feel the way this game makes me feel. Because this is where The Line lives: the duality of our chosen brand of entertainment, where we "play" at the deadly game of simulated mortal conflict, and never stop to ask ourselves: what does my kill/death ratio mean for my soul? Does blood still stain if it only exists in my head? Should I even care?A man broke into my neighborhoodHe threatened the family with a loaded gunHe tied them all up and beat 'em real goodHe took everything and he got away cleanAnd I can't believe that anyone wouldWanna do such a terrible thingBut why should I care?Every time I look around this placeI see them scream but I hear no soundAnd the terrible things happen down the roadTo somebody else that I don't even knowNothing bad ever happens to meNothing bad ever happens to meNothing bad ever happens to meNothing bad ever happens to meWhy should I care?Why should I care?Why should I care?Oingo Boingo - Nothing Bad Ever Happens To MeSpec Ops: The Line is a game that needed to be made. It is a game that, in my opinion, needs to be (I hesitate to use the word "played") experienced. It is a powerful milestone in the ongoing evolution and maturation of gaming, and it asks hard questions that deserve to be heard. It's up to you whether or not to listen. To paraphrase Kenneth Jarecke, a Gulf War photojournalist whose photograph of a dead Iraqi soldier was pulled from the U.S. media outlets because it was deemed too shocking for the public[www.theatlantic.com]: if you're big enough to fight a war, you should be big enough to look at it.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line might be dismissed at first glance for being just another modern military shooter. That assumption couldn’t be more wrong though.Based loosely on Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness, Spec Ops provides one of the strongest and mature narratives in recent memory.The story revolves around Captain Walker and his two wingmen, Lugo and Adams. Their latest mission sends them to a post-catastrophic Dubai to find Colonel Konrad who was in charge of evacuating the civilian population. Captain Walker is often forced to make difficult decisions and any pretense of him being some badass hero is quickly removed as it's clear that sometimes there's no correct decision to make. The character progression is strong and the voice acting is phenomenal.The art direction is spectacular as Dubai provides almost a surreal experience. When you’re not avoiding sandstorms, you'll travel through luxury hotels and buildings that have all been submerged in sand. The game also gives you a taste of PTSD as you’re sometimes left wondering whether or not certain things are real.The combat plays out similarly to other third person shooters. It will have you taking cover, blind firing and issuing commands to your squad mates. The AI is well done, making Lugo and Adams feel very capable while the enemy AI on the other hand could use a bit of work. The combat is solid but it makes no attempt to do anything new or innovative.The soundtrack is fantastic, including a lot of real songs along with ambient guitar pieces that match the mood perfectly. The inclusion of Jimi Hendrix and other classics really give the game an ‘Apocalypse Now’ type of feel which was another Heart of Darkness adaptation.Unfortunately, Spec Ops is fairly short (around 5 hours) but the different endings offer some incentive to replay the game. There’s a multiplayer mode that offers a few different game types, weapons, and stages but it feels a bit tacked on. It’s fairly clear that Spec Ops was designed to be experienced as a single player game primarily and it’s one I strongly recommend.For a more detailed review, here’s a video by my friend and fellow reviewer, Trent:


YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: Spec Ops: The Line 

			Views: 3,479		

			Join Senior Reviewer Trent as he covers Spec Ops: The Line. Spec Ops: The Line is a game that is often overlooked but features one of the strongest and most mature narratives out of any game released...		

Pros+	Amazing Narrative+	Fantastic Soundtrack+	Beautiful Art Direction & Environments+	Great Characters & Voice ActingCons-	Short length & Linear-	Generic Combat-	Multiplayer isn’t very excitingIf you enjoyed this review, feel free to follow me as a Steam Curator: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/4886473/

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												This game, is most likely one of the most depressing games I have ever played in my entire life. What does that mean, does this game suck? No. In fact, this game is incredibly beautiful in many ways, and when you are done playing this game, the whole game story is stuck in your head and makes you think about it. Definitely not some game that is recommended for those who only play Call of Duty multiplayer and such, but for those who are able to appreciate such an amazing story that this game offers. But the problem is that I do not know why this game is called "Spec Ops". I have been avoiding this game for a while, not knowing why and now I know the reason. Because this game is associated with the franchise "Spec Ops" that existed in the past, and Spec Ops games generally were not really good games when I was a kid. So, when I googled the name Spec Ops, I thought "Oh man, now I remember this name Spec Ops...now I know why I have been avoiding this game....all simply because it is associated with the franchise that I was avoiding as a kid." I honestly wish this game was rather called something else. Probably 33rd. The name "Spec Ops" might be the reason why the sales of the game was not that good as well...when the game is absolutely "nothing" like the Spec Ops games that I have played in the past, which is a good thing, a great thing even. The only complain I have would be that....probably as a TPS game, it is not that amazing to be honest. It doesn't mean it is bad, but it is just...not that amazing. But I really liked the fact that at some point, you can choose to do what to do. Such as disobeying the command, or you could simply just choose to obey. I guess the story alone covers everything in this game and this game is essentially worth taking a look at, all just for the story alone.This game, is about the horrors of war. This game, is about the value of life. But this game is not about good and evil, or mayhap, it indeed is. But that depends on how you look at it. As a philosopher myself, this game is what I would call, a game for the thinkers. Who is Captain Walker in the end? What happened to him? The only person who can find out, is you. 9.3 out of 10

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												Finishing Spec Ops The Line was a dreadfully exausting experience. I walked along a man who's mental brakedown was more stable than my own, I felt remorse and sickness of everything I've done, I reflected upon war, death and life and in the end, I was sitting in front of a PC , trying to figure out why Yager hates me so much and why they would make such a horrible, HORRIBLY harsh journey to drive me into depression.After a walk on the park, a cup of tea, donating to a charity and helping an old lady cross the street, I still feel like a ♥♥♥♥ing monster, a cruel, unmerciful, selfish meatbag....and probably will for the rest of my life.EDIT :Since this is somehow once of the most popular reviews of the game (top 10) I rather expand my thoughts.This is pure and simple, one of my personal favorite games of all time. I just cant put into words how powerful it was to me. People will be against this opinion, but this is no doubts in my book the Culmination of what a game can be narrative wise. Last of Us, Undertale , nothing comes closer.So, as someone who digs story and literature, this game sounded like a treat! A great 3rd person shooter with unique setting and a good story. I quickly realized that it was a not mistake to go in full blind. Honestly, it was the most twisted , exausting, tense, emotion packed experience I ever encountered in a medium. The sheer raw brutality and straightfoward truth of the whole narrative drew me in from the get-go.Everything helped to make the game feel incredible (in a harmful way)The controls are a bit cluncky at first, but nothing some practice can fix. Its still a very accesible game, that anyone who played shooters (or not) before can handle.The voice acting is Oscar worthy. Not a single line was wasted or weak. Especially the main cast really nail the dialouge. Belive me when I say few times I really FELT a game protagonist was a human being. Nolan North really sounds like a tired, angry, traumatized war victim.The graphics, especially with everything cranked up to the max, are ****ing beautiful, the aestetic is superb and the levels are very well desinged.The sound is overall intense and loud, each fight is nerve wracking to the extreme.Soundtrack is outstanding and fitting to the themes.The overall story is open to your conclusions, which leads to very interesting interpretations from players.Multiplayer is NOT totally dead. A fellow user has made up a group that organises matches frequently. You can join if you want ! MP is sorta good. http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Expendables-realityI could go on forever, but I rather not saturate you.Just buy it whenever possible.This was the most incredible game I ever played, and I hope you can someday see why."We do what is nesessary...and If we are lucky, we just die".

content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												It's been a year since I picked up the game, and I still cannot bear to play it again when I think of what overcame me when I finished the game.As my playtime indicates, I finished this in a massive rush. I played from 11pm to 4am, expecting that the game was some sort of quick-play game that I could put down easily at any time, like, say, call of duty (oh good grief, even the comparison makes me cringe). I was so driven to finish the game (the mission, as it were) much like Walker was. This revelation made me hate myself beyond belief, as I realized the very same determination, the self-same urge to commit to a goal made me ignore warning signs all over the place. This game makes you truly explore yourself, the deepest darkest recesses of your psyche where the hidden threads of psychopathy lie. When I finally finished the game at 4am, I was unable to sleep. I stayed awake, tormented by what I had done and the face of the white phosphorus burnt mother and child. I kept telling myself: "This is a game. Get over it and get to sleep.", but I just couldn't get over the fact that at the heart of every human is the capability to take things to an extreme in order to pursue a perceived greater good. It is the very thing that drives the best of humanity and the worst of humanity. Medical scientists pursuing a cure, versus the extremists ♥♥♥♥ing up Syria as I type this. This game revealed an inner heart of darkness that needs to be understood, addressed and controlled. If only every one of us could think about it with the due weight and clarity that is needed in such a discussion.Play the game, and finish it, please. Do yourself a favour and finish it. Understand how dangerous it is to be unaware of your own actions, and bloody well learn from it.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
													Every once in awhile, what I call a crime is committed in this industry, a game will be released and end up being one of the greatest games I've ever played. However for one reason or another, it ends up doing horribly. Spec Ops: The Line may be the biggest crime I've ever witnessed...	 Spec Ops puts you in the shoes of Captain Walker, you and two squad mates are sent into a sandstorm destroyed Dubai to find survivors. At first glance the game may appear to be another Call Of Duty type of modern shooter. Disaster occurs and America comes in to save the day, but that is definitely not the case.	The first thing I noticed about this game is how beautiful it is, some may disagree, but Spec Ops on PC with max settings truly looks next gen to me, and this game was released a good while before next gen was a thing. The animation complements this point, for example since Dubai is a city destroyed by uncontrollable sandstorms, you will be traveling through a lot of buildings that are now buried deep below the sand. The moment when I first shot out a giant window I gleefully watched as the sand poured in and buried alive an entire squad of soldiers.	Everything that should be good in a 3rd person shooter gameplay wise is present in this game, but I do not want to waste any time so I'll just tell you about the one thing in Spec Ops that will make you love it, the story. This is hands down the greatest story I have ever had the pleasure of playing in a "Modern War" shooter. Within the first couple levels, Spec Ops shows you that unlike what other games will tell you, war nowadays isn't as clear as "America=good guys, Foreigners=bad guys". Without spoiling too much you quickly see other American soldiers killing innocent families. What choice do you have? Will you just stand by and let mothers and children get burned alive? No of course not, you are going to take action and start killing your fellow soldiers. While going through the campaign I couldn't believe the light Yager was casting on the American military...and I loved it. Just because you wear a uniform doesn't mean you are a good, or sane, person. Your squad has to witness the entire breakdown of a city, piles of bodies litter the streets, peoples are dying of everything you could imagine, soldiers killing the innocent for sport, but Walker keeps pressing on, because he believes he is doing the right thing.  	The voice acting is also great and it isn't just because Nolan North plays the main character, it is because not only do you see, but you also hear the changes these characters are going through due to what they are forced to live through. Once again I do not want to spoil anything, but Walker starts off as a by the book, top tier soldier, and North does an incredible job showing just how much war can change a man.	Spec Ops: The Line is an incredible game that will blow you away. The graphics are beautiful though the images you will see are gut-wrenching. The voice acting is fantastic though what these characters go through is horrible. The story is perfect, you will feel like you have walked through hell with these soldiers. If you are not interested in the "Modern War" genre because of it's glorification and unrealistic approach on war, play this game. If you do like the "Modern War" genre because it is fun, action packed, and brutally violent, play this game. If you haven't figured it out yet what I'm trying to say is Spec Ops is a game you should play, easily an unforgettable experience. Play this game and lets give Yager the praise and recognition they deserve.

number of helpful: 205 of 223 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												A series of dust storms has destroyed much of Dubai, leaving countless civilians stranded. The 33rd Battalion, a United States infantry unit, is sent to provide aid but soon disappears. In a last ditch effort, a three-man Delta Force team is sent in to find out what happened and rescue survivors. As captain of this reconnaissance team it is up to you and your teammates to fight your way across the city and find answers.Spec Ops: The Line is a third person shooter where you will find that you are heavily reliant on cover. You have the ability to command your teammates in battle, telling them who to target. Combat is fast paced and fun, albeit a bit generic. My main complaint with combat would be that the AI sometimes feels a bit clumsy, but nothing bad enough to be game breaking. The game is very story rich and is definitely worth paying attention to. Occasionally you will be forced to make some very difficult decisions. What I liked about this is that there is never really a “right” or “wrong” answer. Unlike some military shooters, this game does not glorify war. Instead it touches on the horrors of war and the profound psychological impact it often has on those who experience it.The environment is absolutely breathtaking, by far my favorite in any game ever. They did a wonderful job at making Dubai look so ruined yet beautiful, resulting in a few areas where you have to stop just to admire your surroundings. I realize that this can vary quite a bit from person to person but I was pleasantly surprised by the music used in the game. Quite a few classics including Hendrix and Deep Purple, as well as some more modern but worthwhile bands such as the Black Angels. If that’s not your thing, it’s still worth mentioning that the original score is pretty solid.  I’m normally extremely skeptical of military shooters, but this game is something else entirely and is now considered among my favorite games.  A bit shorter than I would have liked it to be, but still one that I would highly recommend.

Posted: June 5, 2016
												Right now, think of the "BEST" war movies that you can, just off the top of your head.You probably got "Apocalypse Now", "Saving Private Ryan", "Full Metal Jacket", maybe even "Come and See".It's weird that all the "fingerquotes" GOOD war movies are decisively anti-war (which, really, any realistic portrayal of the horrors of war will be seen as "anti-war", it's our natural human reaction) - and yet, all of the "fingerquotes" GOOD war video games are Michael Bay-level masturbatory murder-fests that run in the completely opposite direction...Spec Ops: The Line is the kind of game I've been waiting for, for a long time.  It is a "GOOD" war game in the sense that "Apocalypse Now" and "Saving Private Ryan" are good war movies.  It uses the video game medium to convey the horrors of war and a soldier's descent into madness in a way no movie ever could.  Admittedly, it's not the best gameplay you'll ever see...And yet this game has challenged every preconception I had about war crimes, and has completely changed my understanding of the difference between "what is right" and "what is necessary".GETDIS

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Pros:- INCREDIBLE story- Immersive environments- Appropriately timed battles- Setting actually feels like a post-apocalyptic Dubai- Interesting political twists- Vibrant graphics and texturesCons:- Controls are meh- Slow start (not in vain, however)- Gameplay is mundaneI enjoyed playing Spec Ops: The Line, but nothing blew me away, except for the story. It took me a while to really understand it, and the significance of the ending was a little bit Bioshock: Infinite-esque, so I'd really suggest paying attention to the cutscenes. The gameplay was pretty average and mundane for a third-person shooter, but the controls were the only nuisance I had. By default, they're unconventional and require some time to get used to. They remind me of the Mass Effect controls, but aren't nearly as polished. For example, sometimes I died from jumping over a box instead of taking cover behind it. Despite these cons, the atypical, dark, and twisting story overshadows its faults. The length of the game on the normal setting is just right. I can't think of any gaps in the plot that would extend the length. Overall, it was a comfortable game to play and I would definitely recommend grabbing it when it goes on sale.

Posted: November 14, 2014
tl;dr.If you think this is just another military shooter like CS:GO or Call of Duty, you couldn't be more wrong. You owe it to yourself to read this review and others like it :)full review.People who know me, know that on first blush "Spec Ops: The Line" is not my kind of game.  This game sat in my library for a long time collecting dust.  I am not sure what prompted me to load it up and give it a try....but will I be forever grateful that I did.  This has instantly become my Game of the Decade so far.  There are parts of this game that will stick with me for years to come.  To suggest that this is mearly a game would be an injustice; it is a masterpiece.  It is a well-crafted story that took me places I never wanted to go, and will never forget.  Like Oliver Stone's Platoon, it's a powerful story with a strong narrative and superb voice acting that must be experienced to be understood.  To go into any more detail, would be giving away too much. If you don't own this game; buy it.  If you have this game sitting in your library; play it. And tell everyone you know to do the same.PROS+ Strong, unexpected story/narative+ Well thoughtout and beautiful level design+ Killer game soundtrack+ Superb voice acting and compelling characters+ Intelligent and aggressive AI+ Excellent optimization / run it at 1080p 60fps on low-end cards+ Four endings, easily accessible from Chapter Select menu+ One of those games that gets better with a second play-throughMEHS= Solid cover-based shooting mechanicCONS- Tack-on multiplayer feature- Cover and melee mapped to the same buttonPlease hit the like button if you found this review at all helpful.  Thanks :D

And it works. After played this. I think I lost faith & humanity. I crossed the line that I've should never do it. It freeze me about a half hour to think what I have done. Am I a horrible person? content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
I will only review the Singleplayer aspect of the game.My ImpressionOk... I was about to write a negative review for this game - it was a really hard way for me to play through it, but I finally managed to, after completely uninstalling the game twice.Why I, despite that, do recommend this game and why I had so much difficulty getting it done I will tell you soon.SummaryYou might be able to tell from this short overview, otherwise, you just have all the points clearly visible.PositiveMediocreNegative+ Great Message+ Good Story~ quite short+ Cover System- Controls feel unresponsive and messy+ Realistic Damage- too slow recovery time~ I couldn't play properly with keyboard/mouse- aiming with a controller is a pain+ Using the environment, especially sand, to your advantage~ not possible everywhere+ Beautiful Dubai~ not so beautiful textures- Some really bad rendered cutscenes+ Cool and atmospheric music- Quite a few sound bugs+ Characters Evolve+ Choices matter~ or do they?The StoryA three-headed Delta squad led by yourself is sent on a rescue mission to the once beautiful city of Dubai - now a wasteland covered in sand. In this hostile environment you are to find survivors of the 33rd Infantry Battalion who volunteered to evacuate the civilians of the city, afterwards received orders to abandon them and leave but disobeyed and broke contact since.Throughout the game, you will see what happened in the five and a half months and how the order of command in the city turned around.As it is, I think it's not a great story but it is beeing told in a unique way that shows a perspective you are normally not shown by the media. At the end of it, you will be able to emphasize with everybody but yourself - you might hate yourself, you might want to kill yourself (not in real life, mind you, but as the character you are playing) and you will regret everything.The WorldDubai is beautiful - it has always been and even all those sandstorms couldn't take the beauty of the city away.What however takes aways it's beauty are the tributes of war and the things that have long left the definition of 'war' and go into the fields of mutilation and violation. There is quite a lot of detail - many posters and grafiti with different messages - some from the old face of Dubai like expensive cars and then the messages of the survivors, sometimes written in bloody red.The textures are ok for the age of the game I guess and they are not your main focus anyway, they are pretty mushy at places, though.The CharactersThe first man of your squad is 1st Lieutenant, heavy gunner, Alphonso Adams - a really loyal and devoted soldier - at the beginning, that is. However as the story progresses his attitude begins to change... for better?Additionally, there is Sergeant John Lugo - your man with the Eagle Eye and the trusted engineer of the force. He makes it pretty clear what he thinks of the whole mission and the choices you make and his opinion is mostly not in your favor - you can image that this will not become better in the hot wheater of the desert.Last but not least there is yours truly Captain Martin Walker, the character you get to play and make the decisions with, for your team. Decisions you won't like, decisions that are bad and worse - but that's just how decisions are in a war. His mental stability will begin to fade in the heat of battle and you won't know whats true and whats not anymore - whats good and whats bad - who is a friend and who is a foe. It becomes clearer that he suffers from PTSD[en.wikipedia.org] - which is not too unusual in the light of the situation.But wait? I am forgetting John Konrad - Colonel John Konrad, commander of the 33rd Infantry Battalion who intended to help the people of Dubai but damned them instead... or did he?The GameplayIt plays as a third-person shooter with quite a lot of tactical elements.Control your squad: You can order Adams and Lugo to attack certain targets, it is also possible to ask for a distraction in the form of a flashbang. However be mindful that in the case of them going down, you have to get your men back up.Stay in cover: The game has a simple cover system and you definitely have to use it - or die. Thankfully the linear levels are designed with a lot of cover in mind, so you will find something to crouch behind most of the time.Use your environment: Sand... sand everywhere - but why not use it? Shoot windows and glass roofs to unleash a sand avalanche upon the members of The Damned or make your bullets find some explosives positioned near enemy cover.To be or not to be: It's your choice - you make a call to live or let live... or do you? You get to decide between bad and worse, there isn't anything else in a war anyway... is there? Whatever you do, at the end of it, you have to go through with it and live with what you have done. You can keep telling yourself, that your hand was forced and there was no other way but is this what you really think?However, there is a big problem with all this: the movement. I used to play this game with mouse and keyboard, but just couldn't navigate really well from cover to cover like this and soon found a lot of bullets in my belly, so I switched to my XBOX360 controller which made moving easier but aiming all the harder. Therefore, I could only play on the lowest difficulty and still died quite a lot.Enhanced was this problem by the fact, that the damage you take is quite 'realistic', meaning you can endure some 3 shots at most. There is a regeneration system but it takes so much time to recover from just one graze that it makes the firefights feel like walking through instant glue.This resulted in me quitting the game so many times - I could play through it, after all, mind you, but it was no fun at the beginning.The SoundYou will get to enjoy quite nice and atmospheric music while you play - provided by Robert Darden - the Radioman of Dubai. The voice acting is good but not all too good in my opinion, at times it just wasn't matching the situation however at others it perfectly did.But I experienced a lot of sound bugs such as hearing my own steps behind me, noise while inside of a sandstorm - which was not resulting from it and the like. This often hurt the atmosphere and, therefor, decreased immersion.The VerdictAt the end of the day, the game has a great anti-war attitude which is shown directly through the eyes of a high-ranking soldier suffering  and losing himself in what started as a rescue mission and ended as a suicide commando. Nevertheless, it's being held back a lot by the gameplay, which feels poorly ported.If you can live with the problems it has and manage to maneuver your squad safely through the sandy wasteland you are in for good a story.NoteIf you have read this far - thank you.I hope this review helped you in deciding to buy this game and if it did, I would be grateful for a 'thumbs up', if you didn't like it, you can give me a 'thumbs down' but I would be glad to hear your opinion on what you didn't like.

number of helpful: 117 of 123 people (95%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is not a game. No, I refuse to call it a game. Instead, a more fitting way to label this piece of work would be, 'art'. Plain and simple. Just as the 'Fountain' by Marcel Duchamp was a big slap to the face for the art commmunity on 'What is Art?', Spec Ops: The Line does the same for the Gaming Community on, 'What are Modern Military Shooters?' It takes the Badass, Stone-Cold, Heroic and invulnerable killing machine protaganist typical in your everyday Military Shooter and tears it to pieces with its masterful story.This poigant work will really help making you wonder what it means to be a hero and needs to be played in order to be understood. To be honest, I feel like I ripped off the developers for buying this game when it was on a $6 deal.The less you know, the better the game.________________________________________________________________StoryDubai was hit with a series of sandstorm that ravaged the city and turned it into a Kid's Sandbox basically. Colonel John Konrad, a decorated Officer in the US army and the 33rd 'Damned' Infantry Regiment volunteered to help the evacuated the city. Nothing was heard from them ever since until 6 Months Later when a Distress Signal by Konrad himself reaches out to the world. This is where you come in. You're Captain Walker, leader of a 3 Man Delta Team Operative sent to investigate Dubai for any survivors. (Cliche, Badass 3 Man Special Forces Protaganist trying to get stuff done and take care of business where others failed.)This is about as much as you need to know to understand what's going on.________________________________________________________________Gameplay(AI)Enemy AI seem to be good enough, alway shouting out what their doing and responding to each other in turn. There are 4 types of enemies Regular, Close-Combat, Sniper and Heavy. * = can be armoured, ie more durableRegular* - The Grunts. SMG/Shotgunners/Assault Rifle all day, everyday. Shotgunners tend to charge at you which can be a dangerClose-Combat - Remember that Banzai Soldier from World at War? This is him except that its 1 hit kill, he dodges and insta-kills you with his knife when he gets close (Yes, no QTE)Sniper* - He snipes? Also has shiny red laser sight which you can see since its tagging youHeavy* - Always comes armoured and just like the Bulldozer from Payday 2, his face is his weakspot. There are 2 varieties of the 'Heavy', M249 Saw or AA12. Either way you're boned as they love walking straight up to you... JerksDon't worry about your AI though as they are okay-ish enough to get stuff done though they tend to go suicidal when you issue an attack order. They have no problem in getting kills or distracting enemies and will always shout out enemies of interest during a firefight such as, "Shotgunner coming from the right!". Take note that this needs to be heard as battle lines are not subtitled. What can be annoying though is when they take too much damamge, they need to be revived and you have a time limit but you don't have the ability to be revived (On Hard, idk about normal and easy)(Core)The meat of the game comes from being a Cover-Based Third Person Shooter reminiscent to that of games like Gears of War. Basically, you sprint form cover to cover (Using a Toggle Key 'Space') and rely on Regenerating Health. The lower your health, the more bloodied your screen becomes in addition to being Black and White (CoD anyone?). There are 15 weapons in total give or take which felt the same with only the diffference being its 'Alternate Function' key which is 'C'. There are also 3 grenade types, Frag, Sticky and Stun which are pretty self-explanatory. You can carry 2 weapons and all 3 grenade types at once. However, you are only limited to 3 grenades per type making the total number of grenades which can be carried to 9(3 Frags/3 Stickies/3 Stuns). Different from other games is how ammo is obtained here. While there is still the basic, 'pick up ammo from dead body so long as same weapon' concept, what Spec Ops has added to spice it up is that in this game is that you can actually Execute wounded enemies to get ammo for your current weapon type. Because you know.. Executions are fun. Be fast though or they'll bleed out to death(GoW anyone)In a nutshell, it's your run of the mill Third Person Cover based shooter like Gears of War or Future Soldier.. Just like any other games where you're the unstoppable saviour of your country.(Command)As Leader, you have control of 2 Squad Mates who use order via the MMB. They are:Lieutenant AdamsYour Heavy Weapons Specialist carrying the M249 Saw. Order him to attack an enemy so long as their close and he'll do two things. FIrst, he unleashes hell on them with suppressive fire from his weapon. Second, he throws a frag which finds its mark 90% of the time, the 10% due to the enemy running away from itSergeant LugoYour Sniper. Order him to attack an enemy from long range and he'll kill the guy so long as he has vision. Though it takes some time for him to pull the trigger, its usually a 1-shot killAs you can see, the command aspect in this game is very weak but simple enough to make life easy.(Environment)Alongside your Red Explosive Containers, you also have the sand which can either help or hinder you. Firstly, Sand can act as either an alternative form of Explosive Barrels. Secondly, throwing an explosive into a pile of sand would create a sand cloud which effectively stuns all nearby enemies for a nice amount of time, similar to Stun grenades if I'm not mistaken. Later in the game at set stages, you'll come across Sandstorms which does two things. Making you unable to issue orders and increasing weapon spread. Extremely frustrating, especially on harder difficulties (15+ deaths on Hard)Nothing revolutionary here really though I'll admit its interesting in theory.(Misc)Collectables are available in the game and are called Intels. The number of intels available in each level is shown by pressing Escape. It offers backstory to the world of Dubai and its inhabitants. As of the time this review was written, no Steam Trading Cards are available. Checkpoints in this game seem to be fair enough. 1 checkpoint pre and post engagement.________________________________________________________________Music and SoundI like the music. It's nice... very Vietnam War-esque and is also perfectly timed and well-executed. It's either Gung Ho adrenaline fueled action or music that make you muse over your actions.Sound also seems to be quite good though the sound of the AA12 doesn't seem to have too much force behind it. Other than that, the sound can of this game can really make firefights here intense, especially on higher difficulties.________________________________________________________________GraphicsIt looks nice enough if you really care so much about it. It's able to capture the violence and carnage you unleash (Yay carnage and violence cause that's what every military shooter needs right!... right?)________________________________________________________________MutiplayerThere are two types of Multiplayer here.Co-Op2 players, 4 levels. A bit of a challenge when communication between the two is lacking. Can be fun for the first few times though I believe that it will lose its charm as fast as you finish itCompetetive4v4 PvP from what I heard though sadly the cream of this game comes from the SP hence why I never bothered to try it out.________________________________________________________________OverallStory is honestly speaking the saving grace for this game. It's what made it so spectacular as the entire gameplay is bland, rehashed and has been done countless times though it can be argued that the very fact that it copies its gameplay from other Military Games is what makes this so good. This is because of how Spec Ops question our beliefs on said game. Must buy.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Being from a military family, and being a soldier myself, I know what war can do the human mind. Listening to kids wanting to join the military because they "totally are awesome at COD, which is the same thing" annoys the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me. I've had many of those kids play this game, and *No spoilers* when they reach a certain point in the game they actually get really quite and stop making jokes. This is a wonderful trip into the dark side of war; the side of war we never see, or hear about. They say there are always two sides to every story; well this is the story you never hear about. It's a beautiful mind trip into the (getting deep here yo) personal working's of the human mind, and the effects that war has on it. Very few games have actually made me feel for the consequences of my actions before. That is the sign of a game truly immersing you within itself. A wonderful buy, perhaps a bit generic with the gameplay at times, but the story makes up for it in all ways. You owe it to yourself to play this game.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Spec Ops: The Line is influenced by the novella "Heart of Darkness" and by the movie "Apocalypse Now" The Line is an emotional rollercoaster that makes you question your actions and motives.The Gameplay:Spec Ops: The Line is your typical cover based TPS (Third-Person Shooter). It features your average modern weapons that you can see in other shooters that take place in a modern day setting: Call of Duty, Battlefield etc.There is also the two gun limit like in many other modern shooters: Primary weapon / Secondary weapon.The gameplay itself is not innovative at all. It doesn't add anything new to the genre: Shoot, take cover, shoot, run to the next cover, shoot - repeatYou can assign different tasks to your two squadmates but you don't need to use them THAT much...or you barely use 'em at all. The tasks themselves are quite basic: "Mark and attack that target" "Shoot that thingy over there" etc.I have to say, though, that the gameplay in The Line is very smooth and the cover mechanics are one of the best i've seen. Sprinting to cover and vaulting over cover is very smooth. The gameplay is good, fast and smooth...very well done. It's just that it doesn't add anything new. The StorySpec Ops: The Line may seem like your average military shooter at first but make no mistake! It is quite the opposite.The game doesn't glorify war. You may play the game for 30-40 minutes and think that it's another one of these "murika fu'k yeh" games but it's not. The story will change soon and it keeps coming up with surprises till the very end of the game. I can't say much about the story without giving away spoilers but all you need to know is this: This game has a story that has NEVER been done before in the TPS/FPS genre. When it comes to video gaming then this story is an unique pearl.You have to trust me on this one.Alright, let's break it down, shall we ?Pros:+5 different endings+Very good voice acting+Very well done characters+Epic Story+Nice graphics+Awesome music (Hush by Deep Purple; Rooster by Alice in Chains etc)+Good and smooth gameplay+Can be challenging at times. Especially on the hardest difficulty+FREE Co-op DLCCons:-Gameplay doesn't add anything newGameplay: 7/10 - Very well done but it's the same old formula done a hundred times overStory: 10/10 - It's just perfect!Overall score: 9/10 - A must have!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)Game Name: Spec Ops: The Line Original Release: 2012 Genre Tags: Third-Person; Shooter; Story Rich; Action; Psychological My Overall Grade: A- Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 8-14 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseursREVIEWSpec Ops: The Line is a modern-combat, over-the-shoulder shooter set in a post-cataclysmic event themed Dubai.  Unrelenting sandstorms have all but destroyed the city entirely; and the evacuation (aided by the US army) was a failure.  You go in, with your two Delta Squad buddies, to try to assess the situation and rescue any survivors.The combat is solid, if not simple.  You take out enemies in standard over-the-shoulder shooter fashion mostly, with some ability to dish out commands to your squad members.  The atmosphere is top notch, and the visuals can be quite stunning.  The voice acting is solid, but some of the lines are cheesy in trying to be funny.  The controls are good, and the game itself is stable.  The gameplay is fun, but a little limited.  You won’t see very much variety in terms of squad commands, grenades, or guns; and can only have 2 equipped guns at a time—which fits the story but somewhat limits gameplay.  Still if you switch your weapons out here and there, picking them up from fallen foes (which you probably need to, as ammo is scarce) you can get just enough variety.One major strong point for the game is the story.  And not just the story itself, but the way it is told.  The pacing of the story keeps you moving from one combat scene to the next, intrigued with the notion of finding out what comes next.  There are some minor decisions to be made here and there; they don’t have a major effect on the progression of the game—they more so just allow you define the character you play.  The final decisions you make, however, will determine which of several endings you will see.  (You can see all endings by replaying just the last level, no matter the other decisions you made).Another major strong point for the game is the atmosphere.  The setting and general theme of the game are constructed quite well.  It is a bit Hollywood-style sensationalist with the sandstorms completely destroying Dubai; but at the same time it’s pretty awesome because it makes for quite a novel setting for a modern-combat game.  However, it does put a restriction on the variety of locales in the game, but that’s OK.All in all, Spec Ops: The Line is a very well put together, story-driven, third-person shooter experience with a great setting.  Highly recommended for fans of a good story, modern-combat FPS/TPS, and a powerful atmosphere.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												SO:TL is dark. Don't be fooled by the sun reflecting off Dubai's sand dunes, this game pulls no punches in bringing the horrors of war to you.The game plays like a standard 3rd-person cover-based shooter, but all the interesting aspects of the game simply use that as the foundation. You control a small squad as they search for what happened to the American troops that were sent to help evacuate Dubai, and slowly uncover the truth. Its all brought home by some stunning environments and incredible sound design, and the story itself challenges the player to maintain their own humanity when there's none left around them.The campaign is quite short, but I played it through on FUBAR difficulty as I enjoyed the game so much. There are a couple of scenes where the difficulty spikes (the "Freebird" scene being the main offender!) but for most of the game it is fairly well paced.There are plenty of twists and lots of clues as to what is going on, just sit back and enjoy the ride. Anyone who enjoys modern shooters owes it to themselves to complete this game at least once.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2013
												Spec Ops really is as good as people say it is.  I'm extremely surprised that 2K didn't promote it more, it just popped out of nowhere without much of an explanation.The game is a third-person cover shooter, which I thought was an odd choice given the type of game it is.  That said, it actually works very well.  While I'm not a particular fan of cover shooters, I actually enjoyed it here.  There's a decent variety of military weapons to work with along with several grenades including a sticky grenade which I'm pretty sure isn't real so I'm not sure why they included it.  It's fun to use though.Graphics are decent, nothing special.  It was designed as a console game with no special PC features so I was able to get a constant 60 FPS on a GTX 260 at max settings.The real strength of this game is the story.  It is extremely well written, perhaps one of the best written games I have ever played.  No other military shooter comes even close.  I'm not going to give any spoilers, but it really draws you in and makes you feel part of the story.  It is a lesson to the Call of Dutys and Battlefields how a single player experience should be.There are a few tweaks you should use to fully enjoy the game.  If you want to use keyboard+mouse like I did, you will need to visit the game forum and download an INI decrypter so you can disable the mouse acceleration (it's REALLY bad.)  Flawless Widescreen also has support for this game so you can increase the FOV.  Once you do that, the game handles very well, though the combo controls can be annoying.Pick up this game when you can, you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: March 14
												Spec Ops: The Line is probably the hardest game to play. Not so much because of its difficulty but because the theme it presents, the settings.You take control of a 3 man team, capt. Walker, Lugo and Adams are sent into the deep end of Dubai, tasked to find the 33 squad. But the more they go further, the more they realise that the once luxurious city became a living hell, where its every man for himself. There are no heroes,  there are are no good or bad choices you need to make: but to sometimes having to decide between the lesser evil. While many games nowadays tries to dehumanise war, this one pulls no string to show you the consequences of your actions, without trying to do any sort of guilt- tripping.   Even more depressing to think that while this may be just a game, in many countries this is an everyday reality.........The game  breaks the fourth wall at many occasions and among other things  asks one simple question to the player: "Do you feel like a hero yet?", which never felt as gutt-wrenching and tear-jerking as it did in this game.

Posted: February 6
												"It takes a strong man to deny whats right infront of him"This isnt a game This is a god damn mother♥♥♥♥ing masterpiece, When pepole throw around the term "Games are an art" This is the one that comes to my mind.You take the role of captin martin walker a member of delta squad alongside adams and lugo your squadmates.If theres one way i can think to describe this game imagine ghost recon futre soilder and appoclypse now had a baby this is the beautiful ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that would pop out. Its very rare that a game has made me feel such a range of emotions. Sadness, Anger, Despair. But this made me feel all the above listed and more. It explores the blatent corrouption and glorifacation of the american millatery. As you fight your way through the streets and rooftops of dubai. You will be faced with numerous decisions wich will tear your moral compass to pieces, Although it may be rather short the beautifuly crafted atmosphere and masterfully written story more than make up for it. 												I'm going to go ahead and say it: This is the best game ever made.If you were to ask me about this game purely based on genre, I would tell you it's a third person shooter where a yankee comes in a foreign land and shoots people. Sounds boring and overplayed, right? That is the impression I had when I bought this game. What I found, as stated beforehand, is the best game ever made.Sure, Grand Theft Auto V, San Andreas and the Witcher III all have large worlds to explore in and much to do. However, this game is the only one I have played up til now that is perfect. It is absolutely infalible.I've just finished my first playthrough of the game, and let me tell you that this game exposes me and humiliates me simply by giving me a situation where lives hang on the line and the choice on how to act. I have been kept awake by the decisions I have made in this game and what they tell me about myself.The blurb of this game says it's "designed to question players' morality".  You're damn ♥♥♥♥ing right it questioned my morality.  This  is what videogames can do that no other kind of entertainment can do: challenge the player. Give him responsibility and tell him to own it. I wasn't able to tell Upham to save Mellish  when he watched on in cowardice as he got stabbed,  so I felt free to trash him in frustration. I wasn't able to be mad at the dealer who shot the litle girl in Pac's "Dopefiend's Diner", so I felt absolved from guilt. Spec Ops: The Line put up a ♥♥♥♥ing mirror to my face and said to me you're no better than the rest of us and it was 100% right.To anyone who is reading this: Play this game and come back to this review. Do you feel like a hero yet?

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Full Review: Read at your own riskI have to be honest, this game got to me, got inside my head and made me feel things I didn't think a basic, cliché, third person shooter could. There are plenty of games that show you violence, plenty of games have you run through all sorts of firefights and battles that are visually stunning making you feel awesome. You walk away from most firefights in this game feeling many feelings; sadness, guilt, horror and sickness. You start the game as a strapping commander of a small team of Special Forces, the serious "Captain America" type and sarcastic joker. You are entering the city of Dubai, struck by devastating dust storms trapping the 33rd and all the civilians they were trying to evacuate and of course, you know the CO of that unit, he was a good man who helped you in a past theater of war. All very, run of the mill story of a canned modern shooter. This is remarkably misleading. As you work your way through the city you find that order has utterly collapsed, you help soldiers under fire from apparent insurgents and as you go farther, you find American soldiers rounding up and gunning down civilians. You are forced to defend yourself when the turn their fire on you. It tears your team up and it is simply the beginning. The game constantly confronts you with choices between one evil or another. No one is the good guy, each side commits atrocities against each other, and if you hope to survive, you have to do the same. There are literally a pair of achievements named "Damned if you do" and "Damned if you don't". The game drags you through the mud watching soldiers, civilians and even your own team die. Your character's dialogue slowly devolves from in control tactical commands to screaming obscenities at the enemy and eventual hallucinations. This game brings themes from Apocalypse Now and The Heart of Darkness into the gaming world and confronts us with the true horrors of this level of violence. You don't walk away from this game feeling good about playing it, the game even goes meta, insinuating that you caused this violence; you could have shut it down and walked away at any time, why did you keep going? They are questions that demand answers. It is a game I think all gamers should play; it rocks you, makes you feel uneasy and forces you to appreciate the true nature of violence. The gameplay itself is smooth and user friendly. Basic squad commands and different guns give you multiple approaches to different combat scenarios. The gameplay is linear and simply escalated as different guns and enemies are introduced with smarter AI and better fighters, much like most of the Call of Duty franchise, although this game, I enjoyed more. Overall, this game is deeply dark and challenges you to confront its own violence. I believe that anyone who plays shooters should play this game to remind them how horrific true violence is; there is nothing wrong with playing our video games that are violent, we just can't become numb to it and this game keeps us grounded.

content:
Posted: February 28
												This game is incredible. It's essentially a dissection and satire of video games themselves under the guise of a spunkgargleweewee dudebro action couch shooter. While playing the game, you see a group of gruff, hardened soldiers (stereotypical of those that you would see in CoD or Battlefield) deal with the harsh realities of combat. The combat and story all seem generic, but you will learn that this is intentional. This game really makes you consider the repercussions of your actions, and it forces you to make difficult choices. Make no mistake, however, there are no 'right' choices here... not even 'good' choices. Only bad choices and worse choices. Sometimes, you aren't even given a choice. People, for lack of understanding most likely, think that this reduces the impact of the results. If you think this way, you are really missing the point. Go into this game with an open mind and no expectations.I pity anyone who fails to realize this game as the masterpiece that it truly is. If video games were treated as serious forms of media like books or movies, it would be called a must-play, like how The Great Gatsby and 1984, for example, are considered some of the must-reads of literature, and Citizen Kane and 2001: A Space Odyssey are considered some of the must-watches of film. This game is on a level of brilliance only shared by the likes of Half-Life 2 and other landmark games, and is criminally underrated. Although it may be short, with me beating it in 5.3 hours on hard mode, it is well worth it. There is probably also some replay value if you want to see how much your choices don't matter. Don't bother with the multiplayer, it's some tacked on garbage that is dead anyway. I actually feel that the inclusion of multiplayer at all is actually satire that wasn't really intended to be played. Anyway, get this game because it is good.

number of helpful: 45 of 45 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												"It takes a strong man to deny what's right in front of him...."I would have never found out about this if it weren't for the multiple posts on Reddit claiming this to be one brilliant game. Do you want a game that leaves you satisfied, happy or fulfilled? Then don't buy this. Spec Ops: The Line will force you into the harsh truth of war.You play as Cpt. Martin Walker, a soldier sent to investigate a distress call alongside Sgt. Lugo and Lt. Adams, only to find out something more terrifying than what any of them expected.The story is set in a fictional Dubai where it is undergoing a state of emergency and destruction. Unlike other war games, the story has a really powerful impact on one's emotional and psychological health. There was honestly one point where I had to stop because it was all too much to handle..... It's one of the best war stories ever told in a videogame.Visuals look amazing, plus I haven't experienced any crashes or bugs and it plays really smooth. It's set in Dubai so expect lots and lots of sand, and repetetive locations. There some areas where the music feels satirical and I love it :) The ambience plays a huge role in story, so I'd say they did a pretty good job in making this game the way they intended it to be.Gameplay is probably their weakest point, it's awkward and sometimes will get you in trouble. Some buttons do multiple commands, depending on where you are and what you do and it makes the gameplay confusing at times. It's definitely not enough to ruin the experience though ^_^ I recommend using a mouse and keyboard primarily because of the aiming. I'd say the game can become brutal at certain points :( I played through this on normal and was killed several times to the point where I almost rage-quitted.Overall Experience: This game was very hard for me to finish because I don't want to keep playing it, not because it's bad but because it forces you to commit atrocities and actually shows you the devastating truth. I don't feel like a hero, I feel like a monster and this game shames you for the acts you've done..... I love this game and I hope I never play it again. I highly recommend that you experience this game at least once (I'm sorry) because it's horribly amazing.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												This is one of the only AAA games i can think of which actually attempts to say something to the player. I mean in the end it amounts to the ol' "War is hell" thing, but when EVERY other shooter game is trying to get you off on the violence and present you as the ultimate badass hero, Spec Ops says not only are you not the hero but you actually made things way worse than they would have been had you not intervened. The road to hell is paved with good intentions.It’s hard to go in depth on what makes the game unique compared to other shooters without spoiling the experience. The story carries the gameplay, unlike a "normal" shooter such as COD where the campaign mode is just there to have set piece after set piece. To be fair to COD there were times when it tried to say something. In COD 4 a nuke goes off and the character you played as on that level slowly dies from radiation as you crawl around on the floor. A powerful moment undercut in the next level when you just start as someone else and continue your killing spree.In Spec Ops the situation you find yourselves in just gets progressively worse as you go through sandstorm ravaged Dubai, and you either get tricked into doing things which have a bad effect on the civilians you are there to protect, or you inadvertently kill them trying to fight the enemy.The actual third person gameplay I found enjoyable, a lot of people don’t give the cover mechanics their due respect because the story is so far above the gameplay, but play Binary Domain (another third person cover based shooter) and then play this, Spec Ops is way less clunky than that one.I enjoyed it, when most other games don’t even attempt to say anything meaningful, this game goes all out trying to f*ck with you. I do think it’s slightly overrated, but that’s just because this is the only AAA game to try something different with the story so everyone crowds around it and champions it. That says more about all the other games that toe the line though in my opinion.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												This game is a fantastic story inside of a god awful game. If you've read a review of this game, it probably praises the story more than anything else, and rightfully so. Nolan North is his usual fantastic self, and the voice work of Bruce Boxleitner is always top notch. This game explores the psychology of the average military shooter protagonist and flips it on its ear and shows us how truly psychotic these people actually would be. It starts off fairly generic, but becomes something unique and special. Unfortunately, poorly designed gameplay mars the experience. There are bugs that will cause progression events to not trigger. The cover system sometimes doesn't work. Moving out of cover is dangerous because it puts you in to a sprint. Vaulting over cover requires pressing the same button that you use to melee, so you'll occassionally punch at the air above a chest high wall instead of going over it. On and on, I would run in to situations where the basic mechanics wouldn't work. I could forgive all of that if the actual shooting weren't so monotonous and boring.  The most intense fire fights become are pace killing once you realize that your best strategy is to move at a snails pace. Pop out, shoot, wait for health to regen. It's basically modern whackamole. This is a problem that these cover shooters have had for a while now, but the best games find a way to circumvent that inherent flaw. Not in this game. In some cases it takes one second to almost die, and nearly 15 seconds to get all of your health back. So slow progression and unspired game play put together means that the actual game is boring. I honestly just wanted it to end.  If you do buy this, it is the story that will get you to finish it. However, I don't believe story is enough to save a game. Novels exist. I'm judging this purely as a game, and as a game I don't recommend it.

Posted: May 1, 2015
												"The truth, Walker, is that you're here because you wanted to feel like something you're not; a hero."A savage deconstruction of the modern military FPS game, Spec Ops: The Line is one of those games you play for its story and little else. The gameplay is rather bland and isn't really worth talking about because its clear that that is not where the focus of this game lies. No... instead you are here to play a story campaign that digs into some seriously dark and unpleasant material, with particular focus upon wartime collateral damage and PTSD. For those who can't handle gruesome images, be warned that this game has them in abundance.And... that's pretty much all I can say because spoilers. In short,Spec Ops is a game with mediocre shooting, but an excellent narrative that serves as a much-needed criticism of modern war "America ♥♥♥♥ yeah" power fantasy games like CoD or Battlefield.Play it.

number of helpful: 41 of 48 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												This game is truly one you will never forget.There are a couple of aspects about this game, some are generic and familiar (like the gameplay, if you think Gears of War you've pretty much got the picture drawn for you), while others are not generic, like the storyline.We begin with the gameplay, which is actually very simple. A third-person, over-the-shoulder view. In the game you take cover, you shoot blindly or get up from your cover to shoot , and then move to a different cover. If one just goes all-out, you will be dead pretty quick, this game takes a little thinking and a wee bit of patience. Also, since the game is set in a post-cataclysmic Dubai, there is sand everywhere, including on top of buildings that have huge windows. Shoot these windows and watch the tons an tons of sand crush your enemies (even though you don't get the chance to do it that many times).The storyline is the driving force of this game, without it, it's not pleasant to get through some levels (in my opinion). This is one of the few games that will make you feel as if your brain was deep-fried, frozen, then smashed into little shards with a hammer. Seriously, this game is not for those who get shocked easily. It is gruesome, disturbing, and appalling. But at the same time, it has a feeling of serenity, ever so faint.It is an amazing game. Definitely worth the money, go buy it.Liked this review? Join my group and follow my curator page.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												I'd be lying if I said that this game was the best thing since sliced bread. The gunplay is fairly average, the cover system needs a bit more work and the sand mechanic is simply too contextual to be of any interest. However, the game contains what is quite possibly the most profound story I have EVER experienced in a game. This is story that won't just make you question the motives your character has for fighting, it will ask you in quite a lot of different ways "Why do you enjoy playing these sort of games? Do you enjoy butchering and slaughtering people on screen?". It is a game that will ask you, the player "Do you feel like a hero yet?". Couple this with fantastic environments and you will be in an experience you will NEVER forget. It may not be game of the year, but Spec Ops: The Line might be the most important game of our generation in terms of its story and the questions it asks.The Good+Gripping story+Brilliant post-disaster Dubai setting+Interesting, well-developed characters+The engaging narrative is bold, and flies in the face of its contemporaries+Beautiful locations and fantastic set piece battlesThe Bad-Can be frustrating-The spotty cover system-Sand amounts to being nothing more than an explosive barrel

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Intense would be a good way to describe this story. Shocking would be another.Although this is an average shooter, fun enough as it is, with a decent cover system, nice weapons, and good level design, including a few jaw dropping sequences, what really sets this game apart is its story. As far as shooters go, I cant think of too many that can rival this one in that regard, and it really elevates this game above most of its peers.It didnt take too long to finish (around 6 hours), and you don't have to replay the entire game to see all four endings, which is nice.this is a game you will definitely keep thinking about long after you finish it, revisiting a lot of the really, really disturbing scenes and decisions that led up to the variations on the ending, all of which have more to do with your characters ability to cope with what he did than the actual gameplay choices you will make throughout.This game is NOT for the overly sensitive. Some of the scenes might legitimately bring some tears out of you, and even if they don't, you wont feel great about them regardless. It's pretty rare that a game can mix action with such an evocative and emotional story.I give this game 9 out of 10, and I feel it is a must own, must play for anybody (but you should also be of age before giving it a go...definitely "mature" topic and content due to the intensity and violence.

												I never wanted to hurt anybody...Spec ops the line is something you can seperate from other shooters, not because of the gunplay, but rather the usage of the storyline.Now some choices may render obselete, which I find quite disappointing, considering they are there but do not have any impact whatsoever on the story finale. But where this game truly shines is its storyline, and Walkers journey throughout, where you expect a standard stopping-terrorists-saving-the-world scenario, they present you with a debacle of what you are doing is actually right.The gameplay is standard for TPS games and does not really bring too much new to the scenery and honestly gets quite boring after a while, or at least repetetive, but the game is quite short so you will not be suffering for long if you despise it.In conclusion, buy this game if you want a game with a great plot which seems to both make a great storyline and subtely mock other games in similar genres where everything is seen from a black-white perspective. If you are here for the gameplay exclusively, I would not recommend this.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												This is a cover based regenerating health over-the-shoulder shooter that has you roaming the desert city of Dubai with 2 other soldiers under your command. The game has a lot going for it, gorgeous vistas, licensed music, a villain that blurs the line of who is the villain, story choices, but the real thing Spec Ops: The Line can hang its hat on is the engrossing story. I'm not a story person, but this would make a great movie watching the story unfold. There are brief cut scenes here and there, but nothing that gets in the way of the action. You are even given choices, so there is some interactivity to the story, but the choices don't have any real impact on the story.The story is simple, subtle and deep all at the same time, you are sent in to find what happened to a group of soldiers in the 33rd and you quickly discover in the first 10 minutes they've gone rogue. You're not just fighting inhabitants of Dubai, but US soldiers and other factions that I can't name since spoilers. Dubai itself is in a post-apocalyptic state, because it has been hit by a major sandstorm destroying the city except for pockets of civilians and soldiers. You'll come across both. There are elements where you can use the sand to defeat your enemies, such as destroying glass will send sand oceans burying enemies. There are blinding sandstorms. The game makes good use of the environment and city. You'll be in the sand oceans full of wrecked yachts, on top of towering skyscrapers, inside falling buildings and junkyards, this game has a great variety of areas. Each area is gorgeous, no matter how depressing and shambled they are. When you execute enemies at close range, you'll see the detail on their faces. A lot of detail was put into this game beyond the gorgeous scenery.Since this is a cover based over-the-shoulder shooter, it feels extremely familiar to others especially Uncharted, especially when the main character is voiced by Nolan North who played Nathan Drake in the Uncharted series. Left stick to run, right stick to aim, left trigger to aim, right trigger to fire, left button to throw something, left and right on the D-pad to cycle through your grenades, Y to change weapons (between two, but you can pick up others), X to reload, B to melee, execute downed enemies and leap over cover. Up on the D-pad will let you alt fire weapons, but its mostly forgotten about. The only unique touch to this game is the right button will command your followers. Tap the right button and Lugo will send out a flash bang that on the PC seems virtually useless. I rarely see it even effect people. Holding the right button and aiming at an enemy will have your sniper take out a long range foe, but really when I'm aiming with the right button I can literally just shoot someone myself if I'm aimed at him. On top of that, it seems like commanding your sniper doesn't work on PC when it does on PS3. The final button is of course the all purpose A button that tap it to run, hold it to run and slide to cover, standing next to cover will make you stick to cover, but really this needs a lot of work. I find my character running in and out of cover or sticking to the cover behind me instead of in front of me. It is quite frustrating and results in most of the deaths I had while playing.The enemy AI seems smart enough and they will flank you, just like you can flank them with your squad. The enemies are similar for the most part, but with AI so good, that means every enemy can kill you. They boil down to standard soldiers, snipers, shotgunners that come to you, bladers that will run at you to knife you and heavy soldiers that walk slowly at you and take a lot of bullets to kill. Its a lot like playing the Uncharted series. You and your allies get put into big open areas with a lot of cover and you need to stay there until everyone dies. Your allies feel competent enough and will take out enemies on their own and call out things to warn you.  They will need to be resuscitated if they take too much damage, but that rarely happens and you can command the other one to bring the fallen back to life. Your teammates serve as guides without seeming too overbearing. The voice acting in the game is great and its probably an unseen high point in a game full of amazing highs.For the most part this feels like a fun game with an incredible story, despite frustrating cover and run buttons being the same. I can't say the game is worth $30 and I'm really surprised that its not $20 yet. Get it on sale. Its worth it for the single player.
