content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												This might be one of the few shooter games where killing an enemy puts me at unease.You play as Martin Walker, commander of Delta Forces, who is on Dubai trying to evacuate the civilians from sandstorm. The 33rd Divison went there first, but never returned, so it is up to you to continue their task... or not.I mispredicted the game would take the usual cliche "rescue mission gone awry because someone screwed it up" - but I was wrong, completely wrong..With its gripping storytelling, the game it delves to the traumas of war, the ambiguousness of war (that war isn't black and white), and. most importantly, how accustomed we are in murdering faceless people as entertainment. The game started with the usual heroic "we're going to save the day, lads" pro-war stance shooter games usually have, but as you progress, it turned its head to portray how terrible trying to act as an hero can be.I also like the minor details. In every cutscenes, you're given options how to deal with conflicts presented. E.g., should you rescue the civilians or an agent? Should you shoot the enemy or let them talk first? Should you shoot that guy, this guy, or... abandon order at all?The consequence doesn't have major effect, but it opens up different reaction and dialogues. Even the smallest ones like standing in front of your teammates while they are ziplining. The environment is also rich in details: barricades are destructible, bullet goes through clothes, etc; sometimes giving you different tactics to progress through the levels.The cons of this game - well, the covering system sometimes doesn't really work well. So sometimes it's kinda difficult to move from one cover to another. But mostly it's not really a problem. Also, the game punish you for running and gunning; it's more tactical shooter like, so if you're coming from Call of Duty or the like, you would need to adapt.This game has one of the most intense and gripping story I've played since long; I'd say it's fitting to say this game as a war thriller movie bundled as a third person shooter. The game deserves an award for its mind-blowing narrative.Where war games give you the ultimate feeling of completion, Spec Ops: The Line asked you the grim question, "do you feel like the hero yet?"

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Walking blind into the thought piercing sand granules of Spec Ops The Line, not knowing or understanding what lies in wait, is akin to drawing near the railing on the roof of the Burj Khalifa and looking out into a haze expecting to clearly see the now obscured majestic definitions of the Dubai landscape below.   Perhaps intentional design, perhaps not and most likely subject to the perceptive cognisance of those lost in the immersive sea of Dubai's blood stained sand.  For when the credits roll and you ponder the rich story inspired* by Joseph Conrad's novella Heart of Darkness and influenced by Francis Ford Coppola's iconic Apocalypse Now, Spec Ops The Line is elevated past common war time yarns denoted by the computer game genre.Where the repetitive Gears of War, run, cover and shoot mechanics overrun, thankfully the avant-garde psychical linear narrative blisters continuously, frequently exposing enough underlying ethical wounds to metamorphosize the title from combat to psychological horror.Endowed with multiple endings, I researched for a definitive authoritative source that would define which ending is lore and which ending was designed to be deceptively tangential, thus further encapsulating this deep and vividly imaginative work.Special mention for the soundtrack and the inclusion of Deep Purple and Jimi Hendrix.  Highly recommended.+ Reshade + SweetFX for post processing effects.+ Flawless Widescreen for FOV control.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
TL;DR: This game is missing the "Kill Yourself" button but otherwise plays just fine!Story time:Few of my friends already played this game, I played the demo, so it was on my wishlist for quite some time... so yesterday I bought it. Oh man.I knew this game was gonna be story driven and kinda dark.It firstly appeared as the two guys talked on the staircase, but I was like, "Hey, the game is just trying to scare me off, pfff!". Then there was the weird fact that the guy we just saved was more hostile towards us than the man we saved him from, but okay, the game has some character. The postapocalyptic atmosphere was nothing new, I used to read Metro series before going to sleep, I love that!Sure, when we failed to rescue the man AND it meant the civilians were probably going to die and the characters got all emotional over it, it was tougher, but I just thought "That's the basic 'dark game' stuff".But then it came.That moment.I already got spoiled that we're going to use white phosphorus to kill some enemies and I was mentally preparing for that. I told to myself "Hey, I play dark and deep games all the time, just turn off your brain for a while and let's do this".It was so easy. You were just pressing a button to fire. "Hey, look, the idiots are so close to each other..." ... But it started to feel bad when I saw how many of them were there "Huh, I get why it's so controversial, those will be some huge casualties".I thought it was over. That the 'look how mature our game is' moment passed and I can get back to saving people.Oh man, was I so wrong. SO WRONG.After all that, you have to walk RIGHT through the battlefield you just bombed with white phosphorus. You see the men dying there... some are trying to reach you and you want to help them, but you're afraid to touch them. "Oh sh*it, is this one missing a part of his leg... oh wait, so many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ dead here! This is terrible! ... Heads up, standing guy, there's gonna be a firefi-. Forgot I thought that. Forgot I thought that. This is terrible. So ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ terrible."Oh good, cutscene, wonder what's-And then you find out that... you killed... all the civilians. With white phosphorus.  All of them are dead. You see a woman with a child. There's still a part of her face left. I wish I didn't noticed that.Oh, and you wanna hear the best part? Really? Yeah, I mean it's really good, because the best part is IT WAS ALL ♥♥♥♥ING POINTLESS.I haven't finished the game yet. I'm not sure if I can do that. I'm afraid to hit the play button. And I feel like I'm not even close to the end....But hey, at least I finally remember what white phosphorus is. Education, I guess...Oh god...

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												The arrange of this review may seems a little confusing. But the game is "little confusing". It's like the movie "The Usual Suspects", you can't play the game with the same experience, twice. The players who completed the game knows that. That's why I want to make a spoiler free review. The Spec Ops: The Line is the 10th game of the Spec Ops series. A not very memorable and commercially successful series. That's why the publisher bets on the successful formula of the "generic third person console shooter" with exrtas-multiplayer; co-op, achievements. And they received by the developer a "generic third person shooter"..... or sort of...  The multi-player: There is a multi-player and co-op but it's deserted. No one plays it. The good thing is that there aren't achievements attached to it.  The achievements: Like I said, you will not be forced to play the multi-player just to get all of the achievements. There are only single-player ones. But It's hard to get them, not because the single-player is difficult. The single-player: Like I said, the game is a generic third person console shooter like "Gears of war". You command a team of two NPCs, you shoot people and you go from one area to another. Technically the game is good: no bugs or glitches. The control and respond of the NPCs may feels awkward only on the highest difficulty- they can die much more faster and thanks to this it's difficult to them to complete the given orders. But the "main problem" is that the developer took this generic formula and put one of, the best military story ever, in it. Not a "Michael Bay, Top Gun, Call Of Duty" kind of story. More like "The Deer Hunter, Platoon, Full Metal Jacket" anti-military kind of story. Some people are seeing this game as the newest modern multimedian adaptation of "Heart of Darkness", after the film "Apocalypse Now". Everything inside the game is design to support the grim story. The design of the enemies- Travis Bickle will try to stab you. The soundtrack resembles many anti-"Vietnam war" songs- lots of psychedelic distortion rock. Even the loading screens will start to give you "useful" information. The game will try to drown you into madness.I can even add that the use of the "generic" gameplay formula is adding much more darker (I think unintentional) ironic line into  the satirical part of the story. The story of game is asking questions about the violence in the same generic type of  video games. After finishing this game I doubt that you will have the will to replay it. (I said that, the achievements are hard to get;)  This game is "underground hit". It's a very mature story, some will not understand it. This is a "You must to have it!" game. The value of this game rises with every year, with every review. This is the end and probably, we will never see another game from the Spec Ops series. Or not as good, as this one. Maybe this game is not a commercially successful but it's definitely a cult classic.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: Spec Ops: The Line 

			Views: 3,479		

			Join Senior Reviewer Trent as he covers Spec Ops: The Line. Spec Ops: The Line is a game that is often overlooked but features one of the strongest and most mature narratives out of any game released...		

It would be easy to look at Spec Ops, groan and promptly write it off as another addition to the bloated cabal of modern military shooters, but to do so would be a mistake. What, on the outside, looks like a game about three hardened delta force commandos shooting up brown people in another sandy Middle Eastern hell hole defies outward appearances and proves to be a bit more clever and surprising. Given the fact that the earlier entries in the Spec Ops franchise preoccupied themselves with cut and dry tactical military action you would be forgiven for making such an assertion. The game opens with a bombastic set piece that seems to have been ripped out of Call Of Duty. It looks like a deleted scene from True Lies, with your character manning a mini gun, shredding lesser enemy helicopters between the sky scrappers of Dubai. You shoot through large glass walls at choppers on the opposite sides of buildings, one unfortunate bird smashes into a crane as things are constantly going boom. It's what we have come to expect from this kind of game. The sequence ends and you flash back to the beginning of the sequence of events that led to that point. No surprises so far. You play as Walker, a Delta Force operative (voiced by Nolan North of Uncharted fame) and are accompanied by Adams and Lugo, your trusty wing men, on a mission to rescue the people of Dubai and locate Colonel John Konrad. The narrative is loosely based on Joesph Conrad's Heart of Darkness and it takes a lot of cues from Frances Ford Coppola's Apocalypse Now, which is also based on Conrad's novella.   The not-so-unusual set up is followed up with some not-so-unusual third person cover based shooting as the game introduces you to Dubai and your squad mates. The shooting mechanics work well enough. You take cover, blind fire, pop out of cover to take precise shots, order squad mates to throw flash bangs and attack. Left to their own devices, Lugo and Adams prove themselves to be competent. They will kill enemies and they generally stay out of your way and make an effort to preserve themselves. It's very refreshing to have AI squad mates that do more than shout, “Reloading!” and “Stay frosty!” every five seconds. In short order, the first wrinkle to otherwise not-so-unusual formula is introduced—environment based attacks. You will find the sandstorm has left mounds of sand heaped behind fragile barriers that can be destroyed in an effort to bury your foes. These environmental advantages are sprinkled throughout the campaign and really brings the setting to life. Engulfing enemies in sand isn't enough to warrant playing any game, but from here Spec Ops only gets more interesting. The second major deviation this game makes is placing you in the middle of moral dilemmas. These sections don't have any lasting effects on the game's narrative but act as a means of reinforcing the game's themes. These are not about playing a “good” soldier or a “bad” soldier but rather having to make a choice you may not want to make. Making these choices strips any pretense of being a bad♥♥♥♥♥hero, they remind you that you can't save the the day all of the time and sometimes you might not be able to save anything at all... One of the most uninspiring and unappealing aspects of modern military shooters is the art direction. I can only wade through so many brown mud huts, gray warehouses made out of tin and steel, and dilapidated villages before I want to gouge my eyes out. In spite of all of the sand, Spec Ops offsets the sandy, sun baked sections with vibrant, colorful interiors. You wade through seas of abandoned cars on highways, blast your way through luxury hotels, crawl out of the apocalyptic center of the city, and bounce across glass filled rooftops. Dubai, as depicted in Spec Ops, is a surreal place. The art style lends itself to the narrative—more specifically the character's mental states. What you see may or may not be real. The characters themselves are detailed and they become more haggard and war torn as the game progresses, animations are altered a bit to reflect the change in characters. There are some visual metaphors sprinkled about if you pay attention (and you should) to the detailed and engaging setting. It's not the technical marvel that the more recent Battlefield games are but the art direction makes this infinitely more interesting to behold. Also the soundtrack deserves special attention. Dubai has also been rigged with speakers and a DJ, known as The Radioman, is broadcasting throughout the city. He sounds like an aging hippie and the music he plays kind of reflects this. Did you ever think you would have a shoot out in a modern military game while Deep Purple's Hush plays in the background? What about Martha and the Vandellas Nowhere to Run? It's fantastic. The juxtaposition of these tunes with the violence of the gun play creates and truly unsettling tone. It seems really obvious that Apocalypse Now was a huge influence on this aspect of the game. There are also some noteworthy ambient, largely guitar-based compositions that sew together the sections of the game that don't have licensed tunes playing in a cohesive manner. The voice acting is also commendable and the writing is very self aware of genre tropes and plays off of them. The whole game centers around critiquing and in some ways defying what you have come to expect from other games in this genre. You won't play anything like it.  What sets Spec Ops back, and is likely to turn off most gamers, is its short length. It is completable in a single sitting and most players will clock in about five to eight hours depending on skill level. The moral dilemmas are not designed to alter the game but rather to set the tone for your play through and experiencing their different outcomes really doesn't extend the game play experience in any meaningful way. Spec Ops was clearly designed as a single player experience and the multiplayer is best ignored altogether. Playing the game in co-op will only further shorten the experience. It's a shame that completing the main single player experience doesn't unlock bite sized missions or episodes from your squad's past. Given that PTSD and war induced stress are huge themes it would have been an appropriate way to add to the game's content without artificially extending the main campaign.  Spec Ops is one of the most mature and interesting games of the year. It is an experience. One unlike any other in terms of the way the game mechanics reinforce the themes and concepts put forth by the narrative. It should be on your radar but don't expect to put dozens of hours into it. In terms of gameplay it's competent rather than exceptional, but where it excels is where other games in its genre need to take a hard look at what they are doing. Games like Spec Ops and Bioshock will be important examples in video game history for integrating gameplay mechanics with narrative themes. This alone makes it worth playing and possibly revisiting in a few years time.

content:
Posted: January 21
												First things first, *NO SPOILERS*. I get this game during the Christmas sale last year, but I never get the chance, or the will, to install and play it. Friends have told me it was a game I have to tried, in which I felt a bit unnerved since I have also hear the 'notorious' reputation this game has. Now that I have installed and played it to the end, I am not sure what to feel.....Spec Ops: The Line is an old game (since I can run it on very high with my potato). On first glance, its main theme centers on shooting, and war. While it is played with 3rd person view, people will group it with other 3rd person view titles, such as Tom Clancy, or the other, more famous AAA titles, like Battlefield and Call of Duty franchises. In general, they have similar game modes i.e. multiplayer, in-game mechanics (although the latter titles are first-person shooters) i.e. vaulting over cover, melee attacks. Nonetheless, I had planned this game to be finished quick, and move on. I was wrong. The game-for some reason-from the moment I start playing it, I can't stop.The only time I stopped, it was to eat dinner, and sleep. Even then, I can't stop thinking about it. D:The game starts in an aerial fight scene, helicopters buzzing around, shooting other helis down using minigun. Sounds familiar? For people who have played other similar themed games, you would know what I mean. Then, the sandstorm comes in. *̶c̶u̶e̶s̶ ̶f̶o̶r̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶ ̶d̶a̶r̶u̶d̶e̶ ̶-̶ ̶s̶a̶n̶d̶s̶t̶o̶r̶m̶ ̶s̶o̶n̶g̶ ̶a̶n̶d̶ ̶m̶e̶m̶e̶s̶ ̶i̶n̶c̶o̶m̶i̶n̶g̶*̶  Then, a crash.Then, the game starts. In a desert, one plays as the main character, Captain Walker. Accompanied by his two subordinates, Sergeant Lugo and Lieutenant Adams to Dubai, trying to find Colonel Konrad and the 33rd Batalyon along with survivors. This 'search for survivors' does sound like an over-used plot device utilized by so many game companies, I had consider it to be the most basic 'norm' developers use to start any similar themed games. However, after the first few chapters where I somewhat understands the basic gameplay (cover and shoot, give orders, etc.) I did think that this is similar to Tom Clancy's franchises. However, as the game goes deeper, I start to understand why the game had the reputation which sets itself apart from other titles. The actions; words that the MC, Lugo and Adams used; enemy executions (Yes, there is an option for that); their clothes and wellbeing; the words on screen that appear when you die and restart from the last checkpoint; even the early game backgrounds when the game starts up, REALLY CHANGE as the game goes on. I start to question, what was going on.Then, at one point, one scene was particularly... unsettling. It was one of that 'What did I just do" moments. Through out the game, I was presented with choices that I have to make in a limited time. However, there are multiple times when one is presented with choices where choosing either of them will lead to bad situations.  In this type of moments, one usually chooses the one which is the lesser evil. Still, how do one knows that the choice IS the lesser evil? At that moment, no one knows. Only later on in the game, one finds out and it is not a pretty one. The later stages in the game are a bit frustrating since I failed and died a few times (which even prompted the 'do you want to lower the difficulty' sign). I have to remap the controls since vaulting over cover and melee attack are mapped originally at the same key, which made it difficult. Ammos are also limited, forcing you to drop and switch weapons to deal with certain situations i.e. snipers, juggernauts. Movements are a bit mechanical (which caused several deaths) but I put it down to my ability since I was not accustomized to the playstyle. I have to give props for the AI enemy who are particularly challenging (even on normal difficulty that I was playing) which will force you to get out of your cover by throwing grenades, flanking you and will kill you when they had the chance i̶n̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶ ̶m̶i̶d̶s̶t̶ ̶o̶f̶ ̶r̶o̶c̶k̶ ̶m̶u̶s̶i̶c̶ ̶b̶l̶a̶r̶i̶n̶g̶ ̶o̶v̶e̶r̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶ ̶s̶p̶e̶a̶k̶e̶r̶s̶ ̶a̶s̶ ̶b̶u̶l̶l̶e̶t̶s̶ ̶w̶h̶i̶z̶z̶e̶d̶ ̶p̶a̶s̶t̶ ̶b̶y̶ ̶a̶n̶d̶ ̶g̶r̶e̶n̶a̶d̶e̶s̶ ̶c̶a̶u̶s̶i̶n̶g̶ ̶a̶ ̶m̶o̶m̶e̶n̶t̶a̶r̶y̶ ̶s̶t̶u̶n̶. AI friendlies are surprisingly useful, helping during tough battle scenes, even though sometimes they went down because they just stand there while the enemy shoots at them. :/Into the 5th or 6th hour, in my mind, I started to think how does this game end? How? Who is Konrad? The earlier chapters I have played is already.... confronting enough. And then I played the last few chapters. Watching everything I hold dear, MC, the other guys, break and fall. Sometimes I don't even know if these guys could've reach this far, considering what they went through. Then, the final chapter, and epilogue came. It was... an emotional rollercoaster. For the first time when I play a game, as the credits roll, I tried to gain some understanding on what had happened up there. For the first time, when I played games of such genre, I feel... mainly upset. However, to call it just upset is not exactly correct.  Of course,  I feel upset that I had played this game, as one starts the game thinking of what was the general norm in such games, and in the end... felt empty inside. There is also a combination of conflicting and mixed feelings of confusion, and relief. Why I put relief? Because, I get the chance to play this game. It was one of those games where you just have to experience it once, without spoilers, and knowing nothing about the game at all. I have been particularly late in playing games that are not popular anymore but people still consider it timeless. It has been the case for a few games I own i.e. Bioshock, Bioshock 2, Bioshock Infinite, and Walking Dead: Season 1. I was glad, I had the chance to try a game that invoked such conflicting emotions and thoughts, even after the game have ended.8.5/10Oh, yeah. I don't feel like a hero anymore.:(

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line may seem like a typical military shooter at first, but it isn’t... not at all. Its strongest point, the story, makes up for every flaw that this game has. I won’t give you any other detail about it, with the exception that it is one of the most intense stories I’ve heard from a game and you just have to trust me and play through it. I don’t believe that there is any other game with such an unique plot and, in terms of how good the narrative is, it can be easily placed at the same level with other good story-driven games like The Last of Us and Alan Wake, which I highly recommend if you are interested in intriguing stories. Also, it is filled with lots of action, which makes it a good choice, even if you want to play something just killing some people, but, in my opinion, if you choose to play this game without paying attention to the story, you are simply wasting your time, as probably there are other mindless shooters out there which excel at this category. The cover system is pretty well done, even though your character will sometimes get into the wrong cover, which can instantly lead to your death if you are already being shot, especially on harder difficulties.  The AI of the squad mates sometimes made my enemies' lives easier, by going out of cover in critical situations and dying, which, combined with a hard difficulty, made it impossible for me to get my squad mate revived. Neither of the above is game breaking and, fortunately, these things rarely happen, so I can say that the gameplay itself is well polished. One thing I want to point out is that the enemy AI is pretty challenging, forcing you to take tactical approaches instead of getting out of cover and shooting everyone. Also, I feel that the sand mechanics were not used at their maximum potential and the developer could do much more with the idea.The sound is another aspect of the game where it can be seen that the developer put a lot of effort.  The voice actors did a tremendous job, succeeding in making players easily cope with the characters. Fun fact: every single line of the script was recorded in just one day. You’ll probably think that the actors didn’t manage to do this without getting tired. Firstly, that’s the point: the developers wanted the voice acting to closely follow the game, which, with the help of the actors, they did. Secondly: you are talking about professionals. Should I mention that the main character is voiced by Nolan North, the one who was featured in games like the Uncharted series and The Last of Us? Also, the OST fits the game perfectly, giving you an adrenaline shot every time you find yourself in front of many enemies. (I have to admit that I’m into rock/metal music, but in my opinion, the music you’ll find in the game is best suited for this genre.)The graphics are pretty amazing! Everything takes place in a post-sandstorm Dubai, which was very well represented by the developers. You get the opportunity to see a beautiful sight of the ruins of Dubai from one of its tallest buildings. Also, the great lightning effects and the attention to details makes up for some minor texture loading issues. There isn’t really anything else to complain about the graphics! I didn't experience any FPS drops, graphical artifacts or any other technical problems throughout the whole campaign.I was looking for a game with a good story and I gave this one a chance when I caught it on sale. I have to admit that I don’t regret a single penny I spent on this game and even if I had to pay the full price, I would not complain, because it is one of the few games that sent chills down my spine. So, if you are wondering whether to buy this game or not and it happens to be on sale, do yourself a favor… buy this game. I can assure you that you won’t regret it at all.

Posted: April 29, 2015
												We begin the analysis of Spec Ops: The Line from the element characterizing the entire experience, or the environment and - in principle - the story that, while not being able to completely leave out the door certain naivety typical of militarism gaming, It tells something really unusual. The thing is already apparent in the first minutes of the game. Despite the first sequence seems taken directly from the market of ideas badged Tom Clancy, the home screen instead shows an American flag upside down and a hymn US entrusted with the notes of a distorted electric guitar. The thin line of ombraUn'immagine that provides a strange impact, considering the context of a video game from the apparent military realistic tone. On the other hand, as we reported previously, the narrative model taken as inspiration by developers is not exactly trivial, since the Heart of Darkness by Joseph Conrad. A model that is not immediately apparent from the context and from the action of the game (aside direct references such as the name of Colonel Konrad, a sort of mix between the writer's name and that of Kurtz, from the same book), but that plan emerges plan, as covered by sand windy, when we realize that the mission of recovering the Colonel turns into something different and deeper, reflective, like a voyage of discovery and formation within a wild environment that has lost all its landmarks, returning to the primeval chaos. The thin line of ombraUn strange place where the misery of survival lies between jewels and opulent furnishings, the legacy of a rich and hedonistic humanity on which nature has returned to take over, throwing strong man into chaos. Then you realize that crossing the desert ruins (but not empty) is really "like taking a trip back in time, to the beginning of the world" and that "in the warm, thick and heavy", as in the book of Conrad, "There is joy in the shine of the sun." The experiment of Yager, as a shooter in the third person from entering the structure on a substrate rather mainstream narrative has a certain importance and originality, he certainly succeeded.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
												To save a fellow American soldier or a civilian. To follow orders or go against them. By the end of it all, are you done serving your country?Brief game summary:You play as Captain Martin Walker who is accompanied by a Delta Force team sent to Dubai to rescue civilian survivors. But as you progress through the game, you are faced with betrayal, horror, hallucinations, and a heck load of sand which forces you to make moral decisions. Ultimately, whichever decision you make, you'll have to live with it. As you spiral down the horrors of war, your fellow squad mates will react differently to your chosen paths. Review:This game takes on a perspective where you place yourself in the shoes of a soldier tasked on a rescue mission. Throughout the game, you'll be faced with moral dilemmas, just like the trolly effect, and you will have to choose your own path. I really like the story line (hands down, the best story line I have ever seen) and the combat in it was entertaining enough. You have to use your environment, which is sand, to your advantage. Your 2 squad mates, unlike other game bots, are very effective. You are literally in control of the outcome of the game. #1 PTSD simulator.-Storyline: 11/10 (Hit me right in the feels)-Gameplay: 8.5/10-Combat: 8.5/10-Graphics: 9/10-Sand: infinityEDIT: Finally completed the game and will very likely be playing it again. Storyline again, is beyond phenominal which also made an impact on me while playing--had to take breaks in between because it got really intense after a few unfortunate  events where it made me feel like sh*t. won't spoil it for the unlucky people who haven't played yet. Unlike other war games, this game takes you on a different perspective, you experience the horrors of war, the aftermath of war, the PTSD experience, and most importantly, it forces you to make unspeakable decisions under very stressful circumstances, in which you would have to deal with the consequences of your actions.I can definitely say that if you were Anakin Skywalker, you will probably sit this game out. But you're not Anakin! Sand doesn't scare you! So what are you waiting for? There's a demo for you to try, however it'll probably end before you even get to the good parts. Or even better, you can just get the game during a sale and experience it yourself.In the end, do you choose to save a fellow brother in war? Or do you finish what you were sent to do?

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
Survivors... one too many.Spec Ops: The Line is the latest installment in the until-release relatively obscure Spec Ops series, and on the surface looks, sounds and plays like your incredibly generic Gears of War game, with a hint of tactical shooter. However, it is a very plot heavy game. The game's premise is set around the attempted reconnaissance and rescue of Dubai's remaining citizens, after vicious sandstorms have all but razed the city to the ground.Everything is presented as a generic shooter. Everything. You have achievements and awards, multiplayer, co-op, difficulty selection, and a trio of military grunts fitting the charismatic leader, wisecrack cold sniper and big scary black dude tropes to the letter.Graphically, it is decent. A selection of "filters" let you play the game with vibrant and saturated colours, the standard settings or the overused "real is brown". Main character textures and models are good, though the facial animations occasionally look odd, and their details clash with the otherwise technically unremarkable world and enemies. That isn't to say a destroyed Dubai isn't something to stop and gawk at - it's a sight to behold no matter where you're from.Voice acting is superb, an essential part of character development. Sound effects are on point. The music is pretty banging when it kicks in.Gameplay, again, is your bog standard cover shooter. Hug that chest high wall like your life depends on it, because more than likely it does. Sandstorms are an occasional gameplay element, which ruin your accuracy and your mobility whilst allegedly doing the same to enemies. They still hit you pretty often. The tactical gameplay extends to ordering your squadmates to focus fire on a single target, which may or may not simply make them run into the open and get themselves incapacitated by the other 200 enemies.Past this point, dissecting the motifs, the game's design and characters, will be marked as a large block of spoilers, so you're free to skip it towards the conclusion.Before gameplay ever happens, Dubai is ravaged by sandstorms, and the United States moves in to organise an evacuation and rescue the survivors. The 33rd Batallion moves in. The initial evacuations turn into a disaster, so they're forced to hunker down and instate a draconian martial law on the remaining survivors, to ration their dwindling supplies. They act as the only law in an otherwise chaotic region. The CIA is tasked with wiping out the 33rd and any survivors, to ensure no hostilities break out between the United States and the Middle East.Months pass. After a lone transmission from the 33rd reaches the US, Delta Force is sent in to investigate, recon and call for support. Very shortly, hostilities engage with the local insurgents, who were likely afraid Delta Force was part of the CIA. They push forth to uncover the truth behind the hostilities and to investigate on their captured American comrades. In no time flat, twisted fate has them now shooting at American forces, the Damned 33rd. Delta Force continue pushing deeper into Dubai to find the truth about Col. Konrad's motives for the 33rd's actions, and to attempt a civilian evacuation. They go past the point of being able to safely leave the city. They're faced with lose-lose decisions. They begin commiting attrocities without intending to. The single most controversial moment in the whole game happens halfway through the campaign, the aftermath of which Delta Force's confidence is visibly shaken as they're "turned into f-ing killers". They thought they had no choice otherwise. They, shortly afterwards, unwittingly take part in the CIA's plan to kill off the remaining Dubai citizens by destroying the last remaining water supplies. They become the mockery and scourge of Dubai.Captain Martin Walker, the leader of Delta and the player character, continues putting the blame on Col. Konrad and intends to get revenge on him. The truth is, Delta has already caused more death and destruction than the 33rd under Konrad's leadership, and Walker tries coping with the crushing guilt of his actions by using the 33rd as a scapegoat. He hallucinates Konrad everywhere. The unfolding devastation mirrors his degrading mental state, manifesting through gameplay on more than one occasion. Walker's leadership is questioned by his squadmates, who revolt at his decisions and his plans despite having gone through the same ordeal as he has.The finale is the turning point, the "Wham Episode" where all of Walker's actions were meaningless, his pursuit for revenge: pointless. It is up to the player, now, to judge Walker and decide his fate.This is a shooter game that viciously deconstructs the "America Saves the Day" mentality; the moral choice system from other games; the heroic, altruistic, "go the extra mile" attitude; and the player's gleeful, oblivious enjoyment of the torment caused to (admittedly virtual) soldiers and civilians caught on the battlefield. You can even say the monotonous, uninspired, "seen-it-a-million-times" gameplay is done on purpose to detract from any satisfaction. It has a pretty potent anti-war message (despite the developers clarifying that this wasn't their intended statement), but it is especially designed, overall, to make the player question their decisions in other shooter games, why and how they derive enjoyment from inflicting pain and destruction. The player is instead punished as they continue playing the game, both in the form of greater damage done to Dubai, and as literal mockery on the loading screens and even as a subtle part of dialogue.There are plenty of advocates in favour of the game's meaning, theme and execution thereof.. and just as many who oppose it, based on its overly pretentious premise. Its linear story structure works as either replicating the protagonists' despair and lack of real alternatives, or as an act of severe railroading that you get punished for following through. There's also the hypocrisy of playing the exact kind of game that is being heavily deconstructed through the story. While the developers have anticipated the kinds of responses usually garnered from players, it is still odd that a game, which costs money, is asking the player to stop playing it.It is heavily divisive, but what it can be applauded for is having the balls to attempt delivering such a controversial message, when several other games have tried but failed.The story is short, around 5 hours max from start to finish on Normal difficulty. While it is flawed and extremely divisive, Spec Ops: The Line is nonetheless a unique experience and a fresh take on a tired genre. Its message and execution have sparked numerous discussions and essays that analyze its story, motifs, symbolism and so on. It is best you go in as "blind" as possible, though - it is a very plot heavy game. And if you do buy it - and I suggest you do, if only for its unique approach to the shooter genre - play only the campaign. You may replay it once or twice to see some previously unseen details, but you can't go back and experience it like it was the first time playing it any other time.Even now, after all you've done, you can still go home. Lucky you.

												I just finished this game for the first time and i can say without the slightest doubt that i will carry some of the things i saw and did in this game with me forever. Now dont let that discourage you from playing this game, the controls and the gameplay are visceral and deliver a feeling of gritty, disheartening realism that the typical shooter could only hope to achieve. Let it be known this certainly is not a game for everyone, but that doesnt mean you shouldn't try it. So after this rambling i can assure this game is well done the controls are tight enough to not hold you back from continuing and the story is byfar the most gritty and well done i've ever had the pleasure of playing.An assured reccomendation and what is probably going to remain one of my favourite games of all time.

												Holy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥! This game was absolutely amazing. I enjoyed every minute of it, and I recommend it to everyone! I received this game through a Humble Bundle, and man, I am not disappointed whatsoever. The gameplay is on point, the story is on point, the characters are on point. You feel like you ARE the main character, Walker. And Walker is voice acted by Nolan North? Hell to the yes. The choices you have to make are brain teasing, rage inducing, and wowza!However, there is only one con, the game is extremely short, I beat it in exactly six hours. For me, that was only two sittings, but I still got very involved into the story. I felt as if I was actually there, suffering from PTSD. I picked all the choices based on what I would do in real life, and I'm not regretting anything. Amazing story! Amazing everything! Buy this immediately if you haven't already.

												sᴘᴇᴄ ᴏᴘs' ʀᴇᴀᴄʜ ᴇxᴄᴇᴇᴅs ɪᴛs ɢʀᴀsᴘ ɪɴ ᴍᴀɴʏ ᴀsᴘᴇᴄᴛs: ᴜɴɪᴍᴘʀᴇssɪᴠᴇ ᴘᴀʀᴛɪᴄʟᴇ ᴇғғᴇᴄᴛs, sᴛɪғғ ᴘʟᴀʏᴇʀ ᴍᴏᴠᴇᴍᴇɴᴛ, ᴜɴᴅᴇʀᴡʜᴇʟᴍɪɴɢ sʜᴏᴏᴛᴇʀ ᴍᴇᴄʜᴀɴɪᴄs ᴀɴᴅ ᴀɴ ᴀᴡᴋᴡᴀʀᴅ ᴄᴏᴠᴇʀ sʏsᴛᴇᴍ. ᴛʜᴇsᴇ ʜᴜʀᴛ ᴀɴ ᴀʟʀᴇᴀᴅʏ sᴛᴀɴᴅᴀʀᴅ ᴛʜɪʀᴅ ᴘᴇʀsᴏɴ sʜᴏᴏᴛᴇʀ.   ʜᴏᴡᴇᴠᴇʀ, ғᴏʀ ᴀʟʟ ɪᴛ ʟᴀᴄᴋs ɪɴ ɢᴀᴍᴇᴘʟᴀʏ, sᴘᴇᴄ ᴏᴘs ʜᴀs ɢʀᴇᴀᴛ ᴠɪsɪᴏɴ - ғᴀʀ ᴍᴏʀᴇ ᴛʜᴀɴ ᴡʜᴀᴛ ᴛʜᴇ ɢᴇɴᴇʀɪᴄ ᴀᴀᴀ ɢᴀᴍᴇs ɪᴛ ᴄʀɪᴛɪᴄɪᴢᴇs ᴄᴏᴜʟᴅ ᴇᴠᴇʀ ᴀᴄᴄᴏᴍᴘʟɪsʜ.   sᴘᴇᴄ ᴏᴘs ɪsɴ’ᴛ ᴀʙᴏᴜᴛ ᴀ ᴡᴀʀ ᴏʀ ᴅᴇғᴇᴀᴛɪɴɢ sᴏᴍᴇ ᴇᴠɪʟ ᴛʜʀᴇᴀᴛ -- ɪᴛ's ᴀʟʟ ᴀʙᴏᴜᴛ ʏᴏᴜ ᴀs ᴛʜᴇ ᴘʟᴀʏᴇʀ: ᴛʜᴇ ᴇғғᴇᴄᴛs ᴏғ ʏᴏᴜʀ ᴀᴄᴛɪᴏɴs ᴀɴᴅ ᴇᴠᴇɴᴛs ᴏᴜᴛ ᴏғ ʏᴏᴜʀ ᴄᴏɴᴛʀᴏʟ. ɪᴛ ᴅᴇғɪᴇs ᴛʜᴇ sᴛᴀɴᴅᴀʀᴅ ᴇsᴛᴀʙʟɪsʜᴇᴅ ʙʏ ʟᴏᴡ-ᴀɪᴍɪɴɢ ᴀᴄᴛɪᴏɴ ɢᴀᴍᴇs, ʙᴜᴛ ɪᴛs ʀᴇʟɪᴀɴᴄᴇ ᴏɴ ᴄᴏɴᴠᴇɴᴛɪᴏɴ ᴅᴏᴇsɴ’ᴛ ᴅᴏ ᴀɴʏᴛʜɪɴɢ ᴛᴏ ᴇʟᴇᴠᴀᴛᴇ ɪᴛ.   sᴍᴀʀᴛ ᴀɴᴅ sᴜsᴘᴇɴsᴇғᴜʟ sᴛᴏʀʏʟɪɴᴇ ᴛᴀᴋᴇs ᴘʀᴇᴄᴇᴅᴇɴᴛ ᴏᴠᴇʀ ᴇᴠᴇʀʏᴛʜɪɴɢ ᴇʟsᴇ, sᴇᴛᴛɪɴɢs ʟɪᴛᴛᴇʀᴇᴅ ᴡɪᴛʜ ʙᴇᴀᴜᴛɪғᴜʟ sᴛʀᴜᴄᴛᴜʀᴇs ᴀɴᴅ ᴀʀᴄʜɪᴛᴇᴄʜᴛᴜʀᴇ, ᴄᴏᴍᴘʟɪᴍᴇɴᴛᴇᴅ ʙʏ ɢʀᴇᴀᴛ ʟɪɢʜᴛɪɴɢ, sᴜʙʟɪᴍᴇ ᴠᴏɪᴄᴇ ᴀᴄᴛɪɴɢ. ᴛʜᴇ ɢᴀᴍᴇ ʜᴀs ᴠᴇʀʏ ᴍᴀɴʏ ᴍᴇᴍᴏʀᴀʙʟᴇ ᴍᴏᴍᴇɴᴛs ᴀɴᴅ ǫᴜᴏᴛᴇs.  9/10 ʏᴏᴜ ᴀʀᴇ sᴛɪʟʟ ᴀ ɢᴏᴏᴅ ᴘᴇʀsᴏɴ.

Spec Ops: The LineReleased in 2012, Spec Ops: The Line Follows an elite Delta Force team on a Recon mission to  a post-catastrophe Dubai, after a series of powerful dust storms. Pros:+ Fantastic, Shocking Story.+ Choices to be made in key points of the story.+ 4 Different endings.+ Sand affects the battles in interesting ways.+ Great Graphics. (still looks great)+ Great Art direction. (This, along with the graphics, makes for some awesome environments)+ Nice weapon selection.+ Competent gameplay. (but not very innovative)+ Runs great on my PC, zero performance issues.+ It's constantly on sale and gets very cheap. + Not too many collectiblesCons:- A bit shortThe game at first feel like a standard third person shooter, but as the story progresses, It shows War in a different way, focusing on the horrors of war. It has one of the best, darker stories I've ever seen. A very different look at war from the constant "America hero, ♥♥♥♥ yeah!" on games like CoD.I like to reinstall and beat it every once in a while, It's that good. Completely recommended. "Gentlemen, Welcome to Dubai!"

number of helpful: 19 of 22 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												Spec-Ops: The Line is a squad-based third-person shooter, but really this is just a cover-up. The game is actually an experimental arthouse game that tries to challenge conventions of the modern game industry, narrative, and ask the player what they really want from games.Spec Ops: The Line is the 11th game in the Spec-Ops series, but you'd be forgiven for not knowing that, as the series wasn't particularly great and hadn't had a new entry in its series in over 10 years before this game came along. However, Spec-Ops: The Line is more of a stand-alone game, and you need no knowledge of the previous Spec-Ops games to enjoy it.You play as Captain Martin Walker, who comes into the town of Dubai under fictional settings that its been ravaged and left for dead by rampant sand storms and riots in the town. A US team, known as the 33rd, was sent there to help keep things under control. The last the city and the 33rd team were recorded doing was trying to form a caravan to help save the survivors of the city. However, all contact was lost, and the city was declared a no-mans land, with access to the city barred off by the UAE government.Our main character, Walker, comes in with a small team, with the only other members being Lieutenant Alphonse Adams and Staff Sergeant John Lugo. Walker has a personal stake in all of this... The leader of the 33rd, Colonel John Konrad, is a personal hero of his, someone who saved his life on the battlefield. This man changed Walker's life, and is the sort of man Walker inspires to be. So when a communication message from Lugo gets out, he takes on the mission very personally, and is determined to do whatever it takes to save him.Spec-Ops: The Line is a very beautiful game. Countless scenes and imagery are backed by fantastic artistic design, and one sometimes can't help but to just sit-back and appreciate the aesthetics of it all. The characters are well animated, the effects of things like sand and water are impressive, there are some gorgeous overlooks of the city at various points in the game, and visually stimulating environments that range from theaters to malls to aquariums to the natural desert itself.The soundtrack is also very stimulating. The game features a variety of licensed music, ranging from Hush by Deep Purple to Star Spangled Banner by Jimi Hendrix. The original soundtrack is also rather interesting, featuring rather ethereal sounds, industrial, and pseudo-rock to home in the tones of each scene. The voicing is handled fantastically, and fits each character rather perfectly.But there is something looming over Spec-Ops: The Line almost the entire time that may turn off a lot of people. The game isn't really all that fun to play. It's serviceable and not badly made, but something about it makes the gameplay never really a fun experience. And as odd as it may sound, I think this is what the developers were going for. There comes a tedium to the combat, a sort of unfeeling to it all. It can be a struggle at times, and there are some moments that are really cool from a visual stand-point and conceptually so, but it still somehow remains unfun.Also as someone who played the whole game on hard difficulty, I recommend you do not. I usually play games on the hardest difficulty available as I find it fun to be challenged, but in the case of Spec-Ops I'd argue it actually actively worked to try and make me enjoy the game less. I wasn't having fun with the harder challenges, it didn't feel satisfying to overcome difficult segments, and it caused me to repeat several segments over-and-over again, and not in a way that it was enjoyable.But I'd still say Spec-Ops is worth experiencing. While the game poses as a third-person shooter, and there is definitely third-person shooter gameplay here, that isn't at the same time really what the game is or is about. Talking about Spec-Ops is difficult, as I believe it is best to go into it without knowing almost anything at all. But at the same time, there is a tedium, a drudgery to pull through in the game.And that arguably is part of the game, and is part of the point of the game and its themes. Spec-Ops has a lot of thought put into it, and is a case where the narrative, atmosphere, and overall experience is much stronger than the gameplay.Here's an odd analogy; This game is essentially to Shooters what Silent Hill is to Survival-Horror or Braid is to platformers. The games are well-made, but gameplay isn't the focus. Other elements take the lead, and the games have rather strong emphasis on its other elements. The gameplay without these other elements is arguably rather lackluster, or kind of tedious. But with the other elements, the games rise from this to become a rather interesting experience in game form. Some may never see the enjoyment of a game that isn't fun to play from a gameplay perspective, but if you can, there is a lot to love in Spec-Ops: The Line.It's depressing, sometimes hard to swallow, and you may not honestly understand everything the first time you play it. However, it is likely to stick with you, and really delves into a sort of symbolic social message on shooters and war, and how the general public see's it. It's not very fun, but Spec-Ops is still an experience worth undertaking.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a much needed breath of fresh air for the "modern shooter" genre. The game play is 3rd person, coverage based shooting. Its good, not great....just good. The atmosphere is great in the sense that ammo is scarce and you have to constantly switch between your weapon and the weapons your enemies drop. This creates a fun conflict within the gamer, "do I hold onto this gun I really like, with very little ammo? Or take the downgrade with more ammo?"Where this game truly excels though is in the arena of story telling. Story telling and character development being two things that seem to escape the vast majority of today's writers of games, TV and movies. The game is a roller coaster of conflict, internal and external. It follows 3 Delta Squad operators as they make decisions (most of which have potentially horrific backlash) most people would be too afraid to make. One of the game's central themes is a subject that we in America seem to shy away from. Shell-Shock, or as the modern "news" media has ordered you to call it "post traumatic stress disorder," and the terrifying physical and psychological effects it can have on these young men that our "leaders" send half way around the world. You watch as the humanity of these young men is completely burned away as they become hardened killers, despite the desire to just leave and go home. One character for example, goes from a happy go lucky jokester,  to having a near breakdown from the consequences of his, and more importantly YOUR, actions. This may sound difficult for a game to pull off in a believable manner, and that's because it is. Most writers would have dropped the ball on this subject so hard the ball would have fallen right though the crust and mantle of the Earth. But Spec Ops handles this very smoothly and paces his evolution (or devolutions, depends on how you view it) in a way that it feels very organic and genuine. I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone looking for a well told story about the horrors of war.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												READ FIRST: I finished this game originally on a console before but bought It again on Steam because I'm primarily a PC gamer. I finished this game twice to make sure I got the facts and the story straight.INTRODUCTION:Do you feel like a hero yet?, this is tag line that will haunt you all throughout the story of Spec Ops the Line.At first glance this game looks like your average American Action War Hero game much like most modern day military shooters but it's not, its something else.PROS:+ Great story and unexpected plot: -Most games glorifies war and conflict but this game oddly focuses (in a good way) on the horrors of it. It takes unexpected twist that makes you question all the decision's you've made through the game. Gameplay wise (see Cons) you can call it generic, the thing that carries this game however, is the story.+ Graphically pleasing: -Given that most games right now has stunning visuals, this is unique in it's own right, adding small details such as sweat, grime and atmosphere makes into a nice experience.+ Sound : -Very nice voice acting that draws you into the story.+ Healthy Game Time: -Not too long, not too short, it doesn’t overstay it's welcome but long enough to make the price tag reasonable.CONS:- Gameplay: -Aside from the added "sand" feature, it's a generic 3rd person cover based shooting game much like Gears of War.- AI (both allies and enemy): -Some parts of the game, your allies act like real Special Forces, but in some parts they act like a clueless kid playing a multiplayer match. The game artificially increases the challenge by enemy numbers and bullet damage, but does nothing to improve the enemy AI's survivability. Would have been nice if they properly used cover and flanking moves (like FEAR 1).Conclusion:GREAT GAME for someone looking for a good story and plot, Spec Ops The Line has that movie "Apocalypse Now" feel to it.NOT for people who are looking for a Gung Ho, Rambo, "look at me I'm the best" storyline. For that I can recommend something else.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

"Do you feel like a hero yet?""This isn't my fault...""It's time for you to wake up.""What happened here was out of my control...""Can you even remember why you came here?""I-I didn't mean to hurt anybody...""If you were a better person, you wouldn't be here...""You're not real. This is all in my head.""Are you sure? Maybe it's in mine." ...+ Graphic+ Atmosphere+ Soundtrack+ Brutal, original story and awesome plotwist+ Sand and Sand storms+ Voice acting+ Coop seems like fun+ Loading screens+ Dubai+ Cover system+ More endings+ One of the best examples of PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder) in videogame- Repetitive gameplay- Multiplayer- Checkpoints- The form of sprintSpec ops: The Feels give me chills like no other game about modern war ever.This game is totally underrated and that's a big shame.It show many horrors of modern war and how hard it is to do things and decisions that are needed (or not?) and how they're all trying to mentally cope with what's happening around them.It's a great ride, with lots mind blown moments.4/5

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												At first glance it looks like a generic shooter. It starts like a generic shooter. Then it transforms to something... Different. Unique. It kicks you in the balls and doesn't let you get up. The game reminds me Kane & Lynch: Dead Man. Both games are typical third person shooters, withself regenerating health, cover systems and dynamic camera. But their story makes them unique.What is this game about? Basicly it's a adaptation of Joseph Conrad's 'Heart of Darkness'. It starts as a story about 3 commando soldiers on a rescue mission in Dubai.Because of misunderstanding and coincidence it turns to something much worse. In my opinion it's a game about war crime, about sacrificing morality or humanity for accomplishing your goals.It shows how easy war can change into total massacre because of small factors.You should play SO:TL and interpret it for yourself.Graphically the game is really OK, mostly because of original location and beautiful map design. What's really important - the game is very detailed. As our characters get deeper and deeper into Dubai conflictthey are changing both physically and mentally. They're getting wounds, their equipment is getting damaged, they speak and act differently. They are even executing the enemies with more aggression and hate. Even the tips showing during the loading screens are becoming cynical. The game itself is criticising your actions, it oftens breaks the 4th wall.The shooting mechanics are good, same as the camera. I didn't have any problems with the technical aspects of the game. What makes the game even better is the soundtrack. It suits every single scene in the game, and makes me want to listen it even after the game. If you've watched 'Apocalypse Now' - you'll feel familliar.Try it. You will get suprised, how this seemingly generic shooter is going to shock you. It's brilliant. It will definetely put your morality on a test. Like no other shooter previously.

content:
Posted: April 11
												Spec Ops the Line At first Spec ops the line is a normal modern first person shooter like Call of Duty and or Battlefield, you play as Captain Martin Walker who has been sent into Dubai some months after a series of horrific sands storms have totalled the city. We hear that the military was involved in evacuating the city but it turned sour for reasons not clear at first. When you start this game it seems like any common garden shooter complete with wise creaking companions and an ‘America is so great’ vibe that constitutes most modern 3rd person FPS. However, over the course of the campaign that vibe melts away to show a truly disturbing story of the horrors of war, PTSD and how even the best of intensions can lead to the worst possible outcomes. I want to call it horror as it does have its fill of really heart wrenching, visually distressing sequences that would classify it as horror FPS. The game play is bog standard and nothing special, it is kind of clever in that respect as it allows the player to focus on the story aspects but it does not excuse it entirely as even games with the best of stories should have great game play to back it up (Dark souls, Undertale and Blood borne to name a few). I cannot really say much more about Spec ops the line. I wish I could, I really wish I could but I don’t want to spoil it for you. If you are prepared to experience a terrific story that is going to make you feel really depressed and shocked at what happens then please pick it up. This game is something special and must be supported.Just as a side note to anyone who picks this up. Watch the main menu.“Feel like a hero yet?”

Dust and bodies lieQuestion rattles in my mindHow evil am I?Outstanding game.Highly recommend this cover shooter. As a shooter in itself, it is competent. You will enjoy the gun play, the hit boxes, the graphical impact. On higher difficulty, the game is challenging but not stupid and incompetent, like Call of Duty series is, at this point.But the meat of the game, the attraction, is not in the shooter itself but in the story it weaves. That story could have been told in any medium and any genre of game and it would still be phenomenal. Don't read about it if you still haven't, just get the game and follow through and enjoy.Once done, try not to overthink it, a lot of critics are all over it already, just feel for yourself the impact it makes. You'll be able to talk about that game with anyone who played it for quite a while.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2013
												Games don't affect me.I mean, sometimes you're playing a game, you blow someone's head into a pile of gore, and you sit back and wonder what the hell you're doing. Then you shrug it off and do it a few hundred more times. You beat the game, you do something else, the shock forgotten.I've been there.So I wasn't expecting much from Spec Ops: The Line, a game I'd heard had a deep and moving story and would mess you up. I thought maybe there'd be a lame twist, a heavy-handed moral, and then a shock ending that would leave me nonplussed. Honestly, for the first half of the game, I thought I was right. I felt like everything was progressing naturally, that I would wind up disappointed. I even got sick of the game about halfway through and left for a while.I'm glad I finished it, though. Here's why.Spec Ops drops you into the sandy combat boots of Captain Walker, a man with a gun and a couple of companions. Seems about par for gaming. Two squadmates, one a heavy gunner with explosives and one a long-range specialist. Average.It prods you through a few levels, and I have to say that's one thing Spec Ops never disappointed me in: these levels are great. They're full of color and design variety, and I actually stopped and looked around admiring the view whenever the combat would let up. Which lets me segue into a quick point before I get back to the main one: Spec Ops: The Line is very by-the-numbers, as far as the actual combat mechanics go. Two guns, some grenades, the lightest of squad-command mechanics, a cover system, and waves and waves of enemies to shoot. It never progresses, save for dropping you into a couple on-rails segments, and it's the only real flaw I have with the game.That said, about halfway or so through, I was just about done. I'd shot some people in the head, shot some more people in the head, shot some people I wasn't sure I should be shooting in the head, walked through beautiful landscapes and disgusting squalor and I'd seen some serious♥♥♥♥♥♥I was about done. The game was dragging, and then it led me to a slightly-different segment. I won't go on about it, but I thought it was pretty boring and I guessed what was about to happen. I was right, but I wasn't prepared. It finally shocked me, and my character's expression mirrored my own. I tuned out everything else. I was thoroughly engrossed and a little bit repulsed. I took a break for a while, letting everything sink in, and I set off again on my trail of shooting people in the head.The game funneled me through wave after wave of enemies, punctuated by comments from other characters and general story beats. It was fun, I had the right emotions, I was in the groove. When I got to the final levels, major♥♥♥♥♥♥was going down. I was pumped. Bad things happened. I got to the end. The game threw me for a loop, and I was forced to reflect on a new reality.I faced the last of a few major moral choices.I made my choice.The credits rolled. A song played. I sat back in my chair, stunned.Had all that really just happened? Had a video game just done all that? Not all of it made sense. Not all of it had to. That was the point.Spec Ops: The Line had caused me to think, it had caused me to feel, it had caused me to reflect on my actions in a video game. Had that happened before? Surely. Of course it had. But Spec Ops did it in a unique way, and I want to congratulate it. The writing throughout was top-notch, set the mood, and progressed the story. The characters were fleshed out, deep, and believable.I also give a nod to the soundtrack, with various tracks all ready to pump you up, get you in the mood, and keep you heading forward.Do I recommend Spec Ops: The Line? Yes. It's full of gore, guns, explosions, and buff men. It has you shooting people in the desert, it's got on-rails sequences.Even with all that, it's still unique. It's still full of heart, or soul, or charisma.It's not without flaws, of course. It is, however, worth playing.9/10

number of helpful: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
Do You Feel Like a Hero Yet?Dubai was hit by a devastating sandstorm. The 33rd infantry battalion, on their way out of Afghanistan, was volunteered by their leader Colonel John Konrad, to assist the evacuation of the citizens. However, when the storm wall hit Dubai, evacuation became impossible. Months later, they attempted to convoy out of Dubai. However, the evacuation failed horribly, resulting the loss of “too many” soldiers and civilians, and there wasn’t any word about them ever since.Spec Ops: The Line is a third-person shooter set in the modern day post-catastrophe Dubai. It was developed by Yager Development and published by 2K Games in 2012. In-game, you will follow as Captain Martin Walker as he and his team of Delta Force operatives are sent on a reconnaissance mission to Dubai. Their objective was to locate any survivors and radio for evac. When researching about this game, I was surprised that this is the eight title of the Spec Ops series. This is apparently a reboot title, and the last Spec Ops title was released in 2002 for the Sony PlayStation. I bought this game from playfire.com as a promotion for the 34th Golden Joystick Awards in October 2016. It was bundled with two other games, Sid Meier’s Pirates! along with a random game. So essentially, I only paid $0.33 for Spec Ops: The Line.I didn’t know much about this game before playing it. In late October, I played the first few chapters and I thought it was just a generic and bland third-person shooter. However, in late November, I decided to give it another try, and boy I was wrong about the game.GAMEPLAYThe gameplay is comparable to other third-person shooters, you can use covers, sprint, pickup items like any other third-person shooters. However, what makes Spec Ops: The Line gameplay stands out is that you can issue orders to your squad. Your squad members can be ordered to focus their fire on a targeted enemy, snipe far away enemies, and even throw flashbang or grenades at the enemy. The AI for your squad members are quite smart, so they won’t get in your way as they can move on their own as you progress, find covers by themselves, and you only need to issue those commands at certain situation. Some weapons have special abilities such as having a grenade launcher attachment, laser sights, scopes, and more that you can toggle depending on your needs. There are three types of grenades, frag grenades, sticky grenades and flashbangs. Sometimes you can eliminate your enemies by using the environment to take the fight at your advantage, such as shooting gas cans or even shooting glass walls to bury your enemies with sand.And speaking of enemies, there are several types of them that you will encounter as you progress. Aside from regular enemies with guns, there are the fast-moving melee specialists, and the heavy armored troopers. The enemy will always try to find a way to flank you, thus you need to be aware of the position of the enemies and stay mobile. Some covers can be destroyed so you must be wary of what you are using as cover. There are also collectibles that you could find throughout the game, and each collectible you find will tell some story elements of the game.The single-player consists of fifteen chapters in Spec Ops: The Line, with 4 different difficulty levels to choose from. It should take you up to 6 hours to finish the game. There’s also a multiplayer mode and a cooperative mode. The multiplayer is class-based, with all sorts of game modes. You can also level up your character and unlock new weapons that you can use in the multiplayer games. You can connect to both cooperative and multiplayer mode via Steamworks and LAN.POSITIVESThere are a lot of things I like about Spec Ops: The Line, one of them is the atmosphere. The city of Dubai looks beautiful with its ruins of tall skyscrapers, combine that with amazing graphics and you will end up with a game that looks breathtaking. The lighting, particle effects, and textures for a game of that time looks amazing. I would consider Spec Ops: The Line as a very optimized game, as I have never encountered any FPS drops and it could run quite nicely on a slower system. The music really fits the atmosphere of the game, and the voice acting is very genuine and believable.The developers put a lot of details into the game, such as when you land a sticky grenade on an enemy, he will immediately run for help to his nearest mate to remove it. Sometimes it ends up with blowing them into chunks together, or the mate would just run and abandon him. Ammunitions are very scarce, so you are forced to use your weapon effectively and switch weapons from time to time. I also like how the main menu changes as the game progress. The enemy AI is fantastic as they will always try to flank you. The level design is excellent in my opinion and the weapon’s special ability also adds more depth to the gameplay.What a lot of people praise about this game is the storyline, which I myself agree. It really escalated from being a cheesy cliché into an intense and unforgettable story. It’s really unlike any other military shooters which glorifies war, instead game focuses on the horrible things that happen in wars. It really makes you think about what is right and what is necessary. The story really impacts the player, and accompanied with a great character development makes Spec Ops: The Line’s story a masterpiece.NEGATIVESOne of the things that I don’t enjoy is the finicky controls. The cover system is quite unreliable sometimes and would often get you killed. Such as the time when an enemy throws a grenade at me, I sprint away, but I ended up latching on the cover behind me and died from the blast. It is also hard when using a sniper rifle or a scoped gun as the mouse acceleration is too fast. The combat gameplay alone is quite lackluster in my opinion.Some people will find the story to be too short, as it only takes 6 hours to complete the game. I tried to play the multiplayer via Steamworks, but there isn’t seem to be anyone playing it. However, all achievements can be obtained from the single-player campaign, so it’s possible to get all of them. There are some minor issues such as lack of Steam Trading Cards which I would prefer for a game like this. I also wish some special units, such as the melee specialist would appear more often as they only appear a few times in the game. SUMMARYTo wrap it up, Spec Ops: The Line is truly a fantastic game. The smart enemy AI and the great level design make up for the lackluster combat, and the finicky controls. The multiplayer is just there, so it’s primarily a single-player game. However, I can honestly say that the story and the visuals are the ones that make this game great for me, as it really hooked me to finish the game. The story was unlike any other war games I’ve ever played, it was very dark and grim and it truly captures the horrors of war. I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												Yager Development has created art. Spec Ops: The Line is a third-person shooter that takes so many unique directions that it is a wonder 2K approved it. The game takes place in Dubai after being destroyed by sandstorms (rather than war) and the city is substantially distinctive from other Middle Eastern locales frequented in military shooters. Dubai is full of giant skyscrapers with beautiful interiors and an insane amount of sand thanks to the sandstorms. The enemy is a welcome change because it is not the typical terrorist cell or communist army. The combat is generic but that is by design – it is meant to lure you into thinking you are playing an average war game. Whether or not that is a poor excuse, Spec Ops: The Line is still fun. The only problem I had was that the difference between weapons felt scarce; I didn’t feel obligated to pick up a new weapon because the starting weapon sufficed and ammo boxes seemed to be around every corner. Of course, what makes this game so notorious is the narrative. I do not want to spoil anything so just take my word for it: it is beyond fantastic. I was impressed with the characters, how they change over the course of the game and how that was reflected in gameplay. Executions become more brutal and the characters angrily yell when confirming a kill rather than the calm “enemy neutralized” you hear in the beginning hours of the game. As for performance it ran well on my PC and I do not recall any specific performance or graphical issues. I did not even bother with multiplayer and neither should you. Even the developers thought it was a “cancerous growth”. If you are looking for a fun military shooter to play with friends – this isn’t for you. Spec Ops: The Line is less of a game and more of an experience.I paid $6 for Spec Ops: The Line during a sale in June 2014.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line isn't a perfect game. The multiplayer is essentially a miss, the gunplay is somewhat formulaic, and the controls have a bit of a snag, but it is a great return to the franchise.Were it not for some technical issues and console-related shortcomings, Spec Ops: The Line would be one of the best games for 2012. But, things being as they are, it remains merely a diamond in the rough, destined for wicked crazy status within the following years. Spec Ops: The Line proves that, with a steady vision and soul, a genre so clichéd like military shooters, can not only surprise us pleasantly, but totally overwhelm us. A solid third-person shooter that delivers intense action and a compelling setting, but relies too much on established mechanics, rather than delivering something new. The story however really stands out - a grim and challenging reflection on violence is something you won't find in any typical shooter. Fortunately it's also missing that dull patriotism you've come to expect from today's military action games.It truly deserves applause for the courage to confront us so harshly with our own character, even if our choices sometimes seem forced or useless. Spec Ops: The Line tries new and interesting ground on storytelling, but falls short on the action department. Still, it's worth playing through for the atmosphere and few different endings alone.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
 Spec Ops: The Line This isn't the run of the mill shoot em' up. At first glance this game looks like the average shooter with no meaning what so ever but this is not the case. Spec Ops: The Line is a deep emotional ride through the mind of one man in dire situations. This games story kept me enthralled and entertained at all times. The story takes a few chapters to piece itself together but after a few painless chapters it comes together. Visuals - This game isnt the newest game on the block but there is no lack of beautiful vistas and cut scenes. The characters transition from the begining to end is all envolping in facial features and body language. Nothing short of awe is captured from start to finish in the vast vibrant yet desolate Dubai. I ran the game on ultra with absolutley no hicups.   Gameplay - The line, to me, leaves something to be desired in this department. While the shooting and such serves its purpose it feels somewhat hollow. Now don't get me wrong when it comes down to it there are some scenes where it is down right awesome but i think that comes more from the visuals and story and not so much the game mechanics itself. I found myself missing environmentals and just running through waves of hollowed "baddies" to progress the amazing story. If i had to compare the gameplay itself id say its not all to disimilar to Army Of Two (1). Overall this game is overlooked all too often and should be taken seriously for the heavy amazing story that ensues. I give this game a  4.5/5

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												This game is a masterpiece. It's one of the best games I've ever played, and it's one of the rare games that I know I'll still be remembering in 10+ years. I've played it when it came out (2012) and I still shiver whenever I read about it or hear the soundtrack.A few things to consider just so you're not disappointed :1) You're buying this for the SP campaign. MP isn't great.2) The campaign is maybe 7 hours long. It's the perfect length for this kind of game.3) Since the game is "short", I HIGHLY recommend trying to beat the game in a short period of time. Ideally in 2-3 sessions, unless you're willing to clear it in a single sitting which I'd recommend if you can. The story is intense and can be quite confusing, so waiting weeks between 2 gaming sessions could have a negative impact on your appreciation.4) Don't read anything / watch anything about the story or pretty much anything about this game before playing (even some reviews). Spoilers would ruin it.5) Don't give up on it too early because the first hour or so is average at best.6) Should be obvious but anyway, make sure to play with sound on (music, sound effects, voice acting). It's not a game you want to play while the TV is on or while talking on Skype.7) Pay attention to the little details. Hints : Title screen, voice acting, flow of the game, etc. This is part of why it's a masterpiece in my opinion.8) If you're not great at shooters, don't hesitate to play at an easier difficulty. Seriously you're not playing this for the challenge / gameplay. Some parts near the end can be annoying, and there's no real point in playing this at a difficulty where you'll have to restart often. Just make sure you're comfortable for the ride and enjoy it.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												A third person shooter that defines not only for its superior military shooter experience, but also for its gripping story. The whole game is intense, unique and will certainly stand out from other third person shooters of the like. Graphics: 10/10You’ll be greeted with a sand-filled Dubai metropolis and a vast desert environment full of dangerous hazards. The lighting, shadows and the small details is what makes this game stand out in the graphics department. It really wants you to see the small details that would usually go unnoticed, nice touch. Storyline: 10/10It places the player in a situation where a choice must be made whether the player likes it or not. You have come to Dubai for one purpose and one purpose only and that is to locate survivors and radio for Evac. But instead you find this city in the middle of war and the sole purpose of the mission is lost.Sound: 10/10Gunshots, the sandstorms and voices sound very clear. There are almost no distortions in the sound that could be heard. Each and every weapon in the game sound different from one another. The character voices sound deep and clear, which is a positive aspect of this game.Gameplay: 7/10The third person shooter style gameplay is just like any other generic third person shooter, it’s nothing special I’ve seen before. But that’s not to say this is a bad game, of course it’s not. It plays out smooth with no significant frame drops from location to location. The controls, the movement speed and the weapon recoil are all very well implemented. Price: 6/10Coming in at a premium price of £19.99, it is on the expensive side when it comes to the ‘pound per hour’ basis. It’ll only take you around 5-8 hours to finish the game, so it only gets a measly 6 for me. You are better off waiting until this game goes on sale for it to be worth buying.

												This game. How should I start.You're Walker, a Delta Operator who's sent into Dubai, to find the missing Konrad, and to locate any survivors, then evac.Simple as that, right? Except it's not. At some point things start to go wrong...(I'm not gonna spoil the story)For gameplay, this game is just a typical 3rd person shooter, you get behind cover, aim, shoot, clear a path and move foward. There're not too many guns, attachments are fixed too, like, M4A1 carbine only comes with a detachable silencer.However, there's one thing that's done well: You won't carry lots of ammo, and you can't really recover all the ammo from enemy(as ammo is considered quite rare in Dubai), I like that.But there's something you gotta know: The gameplay isn't the point, the story is.You gotta make choices in this game, difficult choices. The farther you go, the harder the choices are.Also, you think you're hero? Think again.This game makes you think about different stuff, you'd still remember what happened after you finished the game, and think what you've done during the "mission".Do you feel like a hero yet?

content:
Posted: December 28, 2012
												Many have dissected, analyzed, and downright devoured Spec Ops: The Line. Many theories have been concocted regarding the game's complex and incredibly disturbing narrative. But only one thing is certain: The Line is the most mature, intelligent, and introspective video game ever created. I would go as far as to call it the first post-modern video game ever made.It is, thus far, the only video game in existence that manages to ask so many questions of the player in such unbelievably subtle and imperceptible ways. It may be the first video game that truly is about something. And not only is it the only video game that truly made me question my perception of reality, it's also the only video game that made me truly question the ending I chose. But did I actually choose at all?Well, whatever Spec Ops: The Line is, it's well worth the price of admittance. The gameplay can be lackluster, at times (it's still very much playable and enjoyable, though), but the profound and compelling story more than makes up for any of its faults.

												Honestly way better than I expected, it's not too often a game makes me feel like I'm a bad person. Gameplay wise it's a third person console port so there are the expected bugs with moving around and aiming but nothing that really got in my way aside from not being able to move my mouse much while scoped.
