number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												Dude, Spec Ops: The Line, what a trip to hell... if you like stories, not the stereotypical stuff with the happy ending and♥♥♥♥♥♥ im talking about something to make you think, something to make YOU feel... anger, sorrow, guilt, madness, then you're in for a treat with this game.I should say that some games have evolved so much that they are also an expression of art, not only in the visual context but in the narrative side, putting you in the perspective of the protagonist, making your choises somehow important to the development of the plot, which is also fun as hell, these games are the artform from the present era.About graphics, i loved them, Dubai city is presented in such great detail, even the climate is represented accurate, always seems to prevail a horrid heat wave and the characters sweat and get injuried in a realistic way. About the cutscenes, the editing technique is very well done and the graphics are the same as the rest of the game keeping the action style, the main character suffers an insane transformation to get the end of the game, you can see him as a wild animal cornered trying to save his life by destroying his hunters, look at his eyes.About the sound, is all realistic about gunshots, blasts and enviromental, the voice acting is superb, i read they hired Desmond from assassins creed, in that game he kinda sucked but here he really delivers all his lines, the interaction with the characters is also really good, lets say something like at the begining he sounds like all technical and professional soldier, but later on he becomes sadistic and full of rage and you can hear him getting all psychotic, its insane.About playability, what, lots of guns, explosives, properly represented-- and is really friendly to master combat techniques, there is also some interaction degree, like firing heavy machine guns or issuing orders to squad members, also destroying certain parts in the map to let sand bury your enemies alive, all the good♥♥♥♥♥♥ but is in the command to your guys stuff that i found the weak point in this game, The AI is mostly lame as it gets, if you fail to cover them, your guys will run into certain death and that is more troubles for you. About the dificulty level, easy is for dumb ♥♥♥♥s, on the other side, FUBAR dificulty will get your♥♥♥♥♥on the grill, hard as nails, it is a big challenge.Last words.. man i loved this adventure, but it left me with a weird feeling in my soul (?), something other war games failed to portray, lets say call of fruty, where enemies fall just like shapes under your relentless gunfire, this game will make you think over your choices, war is not fun, i really dont know when we desensitized so much about killing other humans, i know ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, its just a game but think about it, you're getting used to the idea of unloading your mag upon other humans without feeling anything, thats not right. We need more games to think about it, we need to THINK more.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Prefer engaging storyline over gameplay? Then this is the game you are looking for.Can't stand a game if gameplay is too linear? You'll probably get bored real soon.Know what to expect from a game before playing it & you are gonna enjoy.Gameplay wise Spec Ops The Line doesn't offer much of a variation really & fails to distinguish itself from being too niche & generic like other typical war shooting games. Basically shoot everyone you see.But you hardly care about that as you already find yourself engrossed in the atrocious turn of events that's been occurring around you. The story & the protagonist, despite being a work of fiction, feels very much real & human-like & is an impeccable example of the viciousness of war which can drive even the strongest minds into the pitfall of despair.P.S.- Play it in the highest difficulty possible to really enjoy it!Welcome into the madness, Captain!

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												A really good game with OK gameplay as in you go from cover to cover and you shoot the bad guys and throw grenades and stuff, however the ability to give your squad members commands such as attack, stun and heal the other squad mate is KINDA unique.The real cream of the crop here is the story. It is pretty short though, you can complete it in about 5 - 7 hours on the normal difficulty. After replaying this game about 5 times to get every single achievement even the one for completing the game on FUBAR (which was brutal and almost made me commit a war crime on my computer) I can safely say that I understand the story of the game (at least that's what I say to look cool). I won't be revealing details about the story for people like Vikezor who don't want anything to be spoiled for them even though they may never even play this game in their lives, but what I WILL say is that it isn't your typical military shooter story about taking out a terrorist leader threatening to blow up Pluto or something. The story is pretty unique and left me questioning ''What happens next?''. The story makes you think about war and the attrocities people commit under speciffic circumstances. It also has multiple endings about 4 I think and a few descisions you have to make during the story. The soundtrack to this game is also amazing, it fits the story pretty well and makes me wanna replay it to be able to battle enemies while listening to some rocking tunes. Without going into the hostile spoiler lands I can't really say much more so I will cross the border into them for a few seconds to say this:SPOLERS YO KIDS SPOILERS RIGHT HERE The game left me wondering what happens to Walker after he leaves Dubai in that one ending where you shoot at Konrad in the mirror and don't kill the US soldiers that arrive to extract you. Questions like ''What's he gonna do now? Will the things he's seen and done haunt him forever? And did he even have any family to return to?'' popped into mind while watching Marty boy leave Dubai.	END OF THE SPOILERS KIDSIn general I personally think this game is amazing because of the story. However the developers have revealed that they won't be making a sequel or another game in the Spec Ops series for a while because as amazing as the game is it didn't make them a lot of money, not as much as they hoped for at least.Final score: 578/603P.S. Bailey shut the heck up.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
Para análise em português, leia mais abaixo.Spec Ops The Line - Review: Lost and DamnedDubai. An oasis of technology and lust in the middle of desert. Magnificent buildings in a developed city. But nature is always more ruthless than our ability to oppose. Destroyed by intense sandstorms, a city in ruins. The 33rd Battalion of the American army is sent to town for a rescue and extraction operation of the survivors. And then, they disappear from the map.You are Captain Martin Walker, leader of an elite team of Delta Force of the Army of the United States of America, leading his fellow Lieutenant Alphanso Adams, heavy gunner and Sergeant John Lugo, sniper. Sent to Dubai after a transmission captured after six months without contact, his mission is to locate, reunite and rescue possible survivors.Beautiful scenarios, even among ruins. The opulence of Dubai can be seen in the ruins and in few places that remained intact. Even the desert, displays an exotic beauty that brings a melancholy tone to the game.Spec Ops is not just a shooting game in third person. It is a psychological plot. Every dialogue, every action, every event in this journey shows you more than bullets flying. Dubai is alive. Dubai is at war. And war... war never changes. The horrors of war are not shown as simple digital polygons falling to the ground with AI off. You will really feel them. You will hesitate. You will have anger and and will be thrilled. And maybe you even cry. You'll be confused. Do not stop. Go straight. Reflect, try to understand. Do not come to this game to play. Come to this story to live it. And so, you will not regret it.Gentlemen, welcome to Dubai.  My Personal Score   Fun: 9/10   Gameplay: 9/10   Ambientation: 9/10   History: 10/10   Replayability: 6/10   Multiplayer: 1/10 --Spec Ops The Line - Análise: Perdidos e CondenadosDubai. Um oásis de tecnologia e luxuria em pleno deserto. Construções magníficas em uma cidade extremamente desenvolvida. Mas a natureza, é sempre mais impiedosa do que nossa capacidade de nos opor. Destruída por intensas tempestades de areia, uma cidade em ruínas. O 33º batalhão do exército americano é enviado a cidade para uma operação de resgate e extração dos sobreviventes. E então, eles desaparecem do mapa.Você é o Capitão Martin Walker, líder de uma equipe de elite da Força Delta do Exército dos Estados Unidos da América, liderando seus companheiros Tenente Alphanso Adams, artilheiro pesado e Sargento John Lugo, franco-atirador. Enviados a Dubai após uma transmissão ser captada depois de 6 meses sem contato, sua missão é localizar, reunir e resgatar possíveis sobreviventes.Belos cenários, mesmo entre ruínas. A opulência de Dubai se destaca em traços que podem ser percebidos nas ruínas e em poucos lugares sobreviventes. Mesmo o deserto, exibe uma exótica beleza que traz um tom melancólico ao jogo.Spec Ops não é apenas um jogo de tiro em terceira pessoa. É uma trama psicológica. Cada diálogo, cada ação, cada acontecimento nesta jornada te mostra mais do que balas voando. Dubai está viva. Dubai está em guerra. E a guerra... a guerra nunca muda. Os horrores da guerra não são mostrados como simples polígonos digitais caindo ao chão com IA desligada. Você realmente irá sentí-los. Você irá hesitar. Você terá raiva e se emocionará. E talvez, você até mesmo chore. Você ficará confuso. Não pare. Siga em frente. Reflita, procure compreender. Não venha a este jogo para jogar. Venha a esta história para vivê-la. E assim, você não irá se arrepender.Senhores, bem-vindos a Dubai.  Minhas Notas Pessoais   Diversão: 9/10   Gameplay: 9/10   Ambientação: 9/10   História: 10/10   Rejogabilidade: 6/10   Multiplayer: 1/10

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												This is the most terrifying game I have ever played. Period. Spec Ops: The Line is a dark and horrifying examination of the evil that lurks within the human heart and the true cruelty that mankind is capable of when they believe that their actions are justfiied by "heroism." It's also an incredible deconstruction of the modern military shooter genre (eat your heart out, Call of Duty) that examines how truly ♥♥♥♥ed up games like that are by showing the reality of what would happen if people actually acted the way those games did. Written by an actual soldier, this game displays the true horror of war and the consequences of PTSD in ways no other game can. This is one of the most incredible stories in gaming and you CANNOT afford to miss it.

												Spec Ops: The Line is possibly the most riveting, most intriguing, most powerful shooter I have ever played. Whilst the gameplay mechanics are pretty traditional and bring little to the table, the story is fantastic. The Line is a linear game through and through but does a very good job of making the player feel responsible for the actions they carry out. Part of this is due to the illusions of choice that occasionally pop up through the game, allowing you to feel as though your decisions will make a difference. Multiple endings add a bit of spice to it as well. Without a doubt, Specs Ops: The Line is the best third-person shooter I've ever played that had me on the edge of my seat and constantly thinking about it when I wasn't playing it. Opinion:LAWesome

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												If not for a well constructed and deep story, this game would be just another cliché TPS.The gameplay is the standard of a TPS based on Unreal Engine, you control a squad with 2 more members, characters who make constant part of the plot and are not just there to shoot. There is a good variety of weapons, although the enemies are repetitive. Despite not having fantastic graphics, the artwork is very well done, with beautiful and detailed scenarios. We can also highlight the sounds, well made and with an exciting soundtrack!The plot is amazing, can involve you and make you reflect on the events in the game, on the effects of a war. There are moral choices to be made that although not changing the final, have a psychological aspect involved. The ending is unexpected and impactful.The low point for me were the controls, tricky to get used, it is also a very short game, but I think they did well not to extend it too much because it could become tiresome and repetitive. AI also is not the best, but either way, I recommend!8/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a game about morality and introspection. An action/adventure title which grips you with just above average game-play mechanics. Along side that, there is profound situational scenarios that forces an analytical and emotional side from you, with every decision. It may seem like you start as, just, another soldier given, just, another mission. Although, as you act in what seems to be an orderly manner, you begin to question the authenticity, or integrity of such orders. You begin to question because of the veracious nature of these orders. It becomes difficult and even, regretful, when you persist to just 'follow orders.' It is a game which for the most part of the story, is confusing. Your distaste by all the violence you do as this character, I don't want to give any spoilers but there are some really deep philosophical questions that the game provokes from you, after these unfortunate situations. All that thought, accumulates into a severe confusion and doubt about where this is all going. Why so much pain? So much death?...Well, the ending holds a powerful question, the question is what will you do?In regards to the game-play mechanics, they're inherently superficial and refined. This allows for the player to not completely focus on just the action, but the scenery, the sounds, the presentation of a doomed Dubai. There were many breathtaking scenes, in which I have numerous images for.There is only one reason one should purchase this game, it is if you are looking for a intellectually provocative game. Take head tho, there is alot of filler action. Seemingly useless scenes of violence. Furthermore, I would like to add, that discussing such an issue, as this game does, with such a small script, was impressive. I hope the studio is working on the next of the series, maybe one that jumps further deep into the monstrous acts of war, and the repercussions of those wars.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a prime example of ho-hum gameplay, but a powerful and engaging story. This game will make you feel like a monster at the end. You'll see the destruction you caused, the violence you inflicted on people, and the deterioration of your soldier's mind. The gameplay in Spec Ops is really nothing special. It's a Gears of War-type shooter. You're in third person, you shoot enemies, you hide behind cover, you make things go boom, so and so forth. Playing a demo of this game will not do you justice. Sampling a portion of this full course will either make you crave more and throw it away. If it needs to be experienced, it needs to be experienced in it's entirety. Through out the 14 chapters, the gameplay stayed mainly consistent, with turret sections and tons of cover shooting. It's simple, and can get repetitive very quickly. There's nothing special about this gameplay. Some scripted sequences are definitely pretty cool, but other than that, you're going to be shooting and hiding behind cover for most of the time.Spec Ops is all about story, though. You might think that story has no impact on a generic military shooter like this, but you would be wrong. The story in this game is incredible; it's like a good book you can't put down. It's very well written, and in the end, you'll transform into a hurly, burly tough man into a hollow shell of a human being. I highly recommend playing this game. First time I played this, I felt that it was just a simple third person shooter with nothing to offer. After friends told me about it further, I tried it again and realized it was about the story. I was super impressed with this game. If you do choose to play it, make sure you don't look up any info of the story on the internet, it will give stuff away. You'll want to experience it for yourself.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												Game reminds me a LOT of Binary Domain; another third-person shooter (wall humping and military lingo included) with average gameplay and a fantastic plot. I'm not gonna dwell too long on the game mechanics. It's typical stuff with nothing impressive or worth mentioning. This is one of those games that's more about everything BESIDES the gameplay, which says more about the writing than anything negative about the gameplay. I will only complain about one thing: the game has mechanics that are severely underused. Specifically, silencers, which would let you sneak around getting kills if the game dedicated more to that aspect.Anyway, the plot is fantastic, and its SPECTACULAR how it handles good and evil. Ultimately, the paradigm (big word alert) is meaningless here; everyone has their motives and reasons for doing what they do. The game weaves a complex narrative that ultimately pins you as neither a 'good guy' nor a 'bad guy'; you are merely someone doing what he believes is right. Emphasis on ''believes'' because all supposedly moral actions in this game are subject to questioning. I love the title for that alone. I love when villains are given motives and reasons for their actions other than ''I am bad raawr come get me in my evil evil castle''. They took it a step further by making the protagonist's morality ambiguous as well, and you get to shape some of it along the way. There are some segments where you have to make choices, and the writing makes it so that each option in these segments is a valid choice. Moral choices in games tend to boil down to ''kill grandma; don't kill grandma'', so there's never really any critical thinking involved; developers take note, this game does it right.I could go on and on about how the pacing is done very well and how I love the narrative. But I'll end on a few unrelated notes:-For a console game this♥♥♥♥♥♥looks great. This dude's bald head is so...so bald. -The menu changes as you play the title, which is a cool touch. It's little things like that that give a title some flavor.-The game is loosely based on an old novel from the 19th century. So, like Binary Domain, it isn't exactly original.-You might not get sound in pre-rendered cut-scenes. It's a bug having to do with NVIDIA cards or some♥♥♥♥♥♥ Anyway, the fix is insanely simple and there's a thread on the forums about it. Or you could watch pre-rendered stuff on youtube.The game's pretty short and straight-forward. I love strong narratives so I can't recommend this enough. And while you're at it, pick up Binary Domain as well.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Holy crap. I didn't think it possible for there to be a game whose story made me feel these strong of emotions, yet here's Spec Ops: The Line. Corniness aside, this game's story really is absolutley fantastic. It begins like any other military shooter, seeming cliched and even a little unlikeable character-wise, but that soon fades quickly with the situations the characters find themselves in. What makes this game's story and themes so effective, is that in most shooters, war and killing are portrayed as being glorious and even fun. In this game, however, war and killing are portrayed being much more gritty and unpleasant. Many parts of this game made me full of disgust, terror, and some particular scenes made me feel physically sick. It questions why we so often use war as a form of entertainment, when in reality, it causes much suffering and pain. In several points throughout the game, you are given a moral dilemma, and are asked to make a choice. None of them are simple, and none of them are easy. It really makes you question your own morality in what is right and what is wrong, especially in a warzone.The major problem with the game though, is the gameplay. It's just simply not very interesting or engaging. You do get to command around the two soldiers that tag along beside you throughout the game, but you don't have many options for them. You're pretty much only confined to telling them which one enemy you want them to kill. Usually, though, just taking the enemy out yourself is a lot easier and faster. The tactical element feels rather barebones, really. Also, at times the enemy AI just didn't seem that great. They sometimes stood right out into the open ready to be shot, or charged straight into oncoming fire. The gameplay isn't totally awful though, the actual shooting is satisfying, and there are variations on any given enemy's tactics based on what weapon they have, which is more than a lot of other shooters can say. Story-wise, there is not a lot that The Line gets wrong, only that it's not very subtle in it's message and theme, but that can be forgiven for how good it is presented.Some people have pointed out, however, that you're not supposed to totally enjoy the combat, that killing other people isn't supposed to be fun or enjoyable. Whether you may think that was intentional or not, this game is still great for it's accomplishments in its story and themes. Those alone kept me hooked and those alone are far more than enough for my reccomendation.

												I found the game pretty boring. Clean up the area, maybe pick up a new weapon, repeat. Linear as hell. You can't plan your assault, just appear in a new location and the enemies show up around you. Like shooting grounds with different decorations. Stealth mode is laughable, you may kill an enemy or two before everyone spots you and the action starts.One of the reasons to buy the game was allegedly good story-line. Well, I found it being stupid, like "we did very bad things but we didn't have a choice, or, wait, maybe we did, which makes us very bad people". This is repeated over and over. I don't feel sorry for the main drama-queen character although the game really wants me to.The abundant corpses and burning people are desperately trying to add up to the drama, but they look pathetic and excessive.What I did like are some interiors. They look good, but lack details like things you can interact with.The game is not all bad, I would give it 3.5 stars out of 5. But since I can only choose between Yes/No, the choice is no, I don't recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is awesome and amazingly underrated. It looks great (that setting! that landscapes! every room is different! that graffiti! characters become dirtier and dirtier as plot advances!), has awesome music (astonishing selection of vocal tracks, including Jimi Hendrix, Deep Purple, Mogwai and Bjork, and instrumental depressing post-rock ambience) and terrific story (it wil make you feel the feels, man, I guarantee it). The only complaint is monotonous gameplay  and a couple badly designed parts (mostly it's because of lack of checkpoints) which were too difficult (at least for me) AND MADE ME ♥♥♥♥ING RAGE MY♥♥♥♥♥OFF ARRRRRRGGGGHHH (almost threw my gamepad against the wall; btw — I do not recommend playing this on gamepad, use keyboard & mouse, it's  much better); still the game has better gameplay than Call Of Duty or single-player Battlefield campaign  (lol, haters gonna hate).Everything else is totally cool, final plot twist and overall plot awesomeness is comparable to that of Bioshock Infinite.Also very enjoyable collectibles, every one of which has some plot exposition (again kind of like Bioshock Infinite with its collectable voxophone records).Very nicely done. Good job, devs.9/10, one of my favourite story-driven games of all time.

												Spec Ops The Line is by no means a perfect game, the gameplay is basic, it's a third person cover shooter set in the desert. The mulitplayer while a nice bonus is an odd inclusion considering the tone and content of the story. Even though the gameplay is standard and basic the story is where this game truly shines. This game achieves through its single player campaign what games like Call of Duty, Medal of Honor, Battlefield and countless other war games have tried to do. It puts you in the middle of a harsh war scenario where you have to think on your feet and make moral decisions. If you're going to play one game about war I highly suggest this one.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
Underrated Masterpiece(This review is only for the single player part of the game)I only bought this game because it is available on Linux and I heard it is kind of good. "Kind of good" is an understatement. I was really amazed by this game, it's one of the most profound games I've ever played. It can be seen as an "Anti Call of Duty", because the setting of the game could also be as well the setting of the next Call of Duty edition. But the story develops in a direction where Call of Duty (most likely) never will go: no glory, just madness. Even though the game starts in quite a standard way (not only in terms of story and setting, but also in terms of gameplay), the direction changes quite fast.Speaking of gameplay: it is a solid cover shooter. The cover mechanics work quite well (most of the time), the shooting part is good and the AI of the enemies is really good. They are more than just cannon fodder and put some real pressure on the player. The gameplay itself might be standard nowadays, but the implementation is top-notch. The overall game experience is what you would expect from a AAA title, which is a big surprise, considering the topics covered by the game's story.I have a few points of critique, but those points rather fit to modern shooters in general:It is rather short (it took me ~13h to finish the game on the hardest difficulty, and I'm not really experienced in playing cover shooters and thus was dying a lot)The levels are very linear (but you can also see this as a metaphor for the freedom of choice you have or haven't in the game)This game is one of the most underrated games in recent history. Apart from the story it fulfills all the criteria of a successful AAA title. It is really a pity, since this is the only AAA game (I know) that is brave enough not only to be mature, but also to raise unpleasant questions to the players and it didn't get the appreciation that it deserves. Seems like in future this will be only done by indie games.Anyway, I was very surprised (in a positive way) by this game and I can recommend to everybody to see, what can be done with the medium computer games.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												Spec Ops for me was a harrowing experience. You do not play this game for the purposes of 'fun', you play it to experience what amounts to a character study of the main characters slow trip into madness. The combat is not 'fun'; it can be repetitive, frustrating, and depressing. There is no satisfaction gained by killing waves of enemies. The story is brutal and depressing (catching a theme?). It creates false choices, a sense of distance from your 'character', a general feeling of detachment from your actions and a nagging sense of hopelessness. So why on earth would you want to play a game that actively tries to prevent you from gathering any amount of enjoyment from it? Because this game is a work of art and a compelling experience. It was conceived as the Heart of Darkness/Apocalypse Now of video games and it uses every tool available inside the medium to create the mood achieved in those works. To put it bluntly, nothing about this game will make you feel accomplished and in the rare points that you do, it takes that away from you, through both gameplay, cinematics, and even the loading screens. Late in the game when you die the loading screens will mock you telling you things like "Do you even know why you are here" and "He would have most likely suffered from PTSD, dying made him the lucky one". This game is not for everyone, especially those who just want to turn off or want to only have 'fun'. This game is for those of us who want to see video games tackle major topics maturely (in this case; war crimes) and do so with respect. If you are sketchy, I would wait until the price drops. With only a 7 hour campaign and almost laughable multiplayer, this game is not going to give you 50 hours of game play. Over all I am very glad I now own this game and really encourage all of you to play it in some way.

content:
Posted: January 8
Product received for free
 Could have been great, but fell short Overall this game had a lot of potential and it really delivered in some aspects. The graphics and the feel of the guns when shot are still great even after a number of years. Warning slight rant incoming But that's it really, if I'm being honest.The combat is great at the start, until you reach sections of the game where enemies spawn in waves after waves and you gun them down with no problem. The game actually gives you a lot of ammo when you're low, so it wasn't as punishing as I initially thought. The melee units are a joke and even the special troops near the end of the game are easily taken out. The only trouble would be the heavy units, but even they're done in with a shotgun to the face a couple of times. All in all not a very difficult combat system, and in a vacuum, would be actually fun to play once in awhile.Until you mix that with the A.I.Now, the A.I of the enemies is actually pretty good for a game from 2012. They flank, they wait for you to pop out to shoot, they cover each other and pin you down when other enemies move up. Nah the enemy A.I is commendable. The only problem is your teammates. The dumb soldiers do the worst possible imaginable thing almost every time. Attempting to melee enemies in full armour and an LMG is a common one. Running towards grenades is also pretty much the norm for these great american troopers. Time and time again I would have to restart simply because the 2 dumb bumpkins the game calls soldiers would rather hug each other and cry when a grenade lands at their feet then move to the adjacent cover about 2 metres away. It would have been acceptable if it had happened once or twice, but the exact same scenario happened at least 5-6 times in a row.The biggest issue I have with the game is finally here. Something so easily changed and tweaked almost had me wanting to throw my pc out the window with Dark Souls levels of rage.The controls and autolock.So many times the leader of Delta team (i.e you) would get gunned down because he couldn't lean on a pillar to literally save his life. Alternatively, would get his legs blown off by a grenade because he  covered himself in glue and smeared himself all over the walls . The janky♥♥♥♥♥controls was the main thing making this frustrating to play and the game would have gone so smoothly. The biggest qualm I have with the game.Had the fairly common audio bug where some or all sound in some cutscenes would not exist, e.g no sound at all in a cutscene, or no dialogue audio in another cutscene. Tried fixing it a few times throughout the game, but gave up around the same time I gave up on the game.The story was rather eh. You get dropped off with no idea on what you're doing and the game just throws some expo and leaves you to figure it out. Granted, its not a whole bunch of names and expo dumps but it still leaves you with a sense of "uhhh...?" for half the game, and the next half you're not paying attention because you really don't care by that point.  Spoiler up ahead   The whole napalming of civvies didn't really affect me, because after a certain point you really don't give a flying♥♥♥♥♥♥ By the time Lugo died, I just gunned down the surrounding civilians because I really couldn't have cared less by that point. And at the end, I just shot whats-his-face immediately, and gave up my gun to the soldiers because I just wanted to pump this review out and go to bed. Overall okaish game with decent combat, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ A.I and such broken♥♥♥♥♥controls it would make Sean Murray (circa No Man's Sky launch day) blush.  No hate, I just needed an example  . I can definitely see why the game's story would be a major appeal for some, just not for me. Sad really, was excited for the game and had high hopes after hearing from friends and other reviews.tl;dr just get it on sale with low expectations, won't be too disappointed like that.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												It's hard to recommend this game. It's hard to enjoy it and even harder to like it. Why the thumbs up then? Because it's bad for all the right reasons. Let me elaborate:MILD SPOILERS AHEAD!The game starts as a typical military shooter but as you go about shooting "bad guys" things get F.U.B.A.R. real fast. Your character is forced to commit a series of war atrocities, each worse than the last one. The gameplay in between is dull and repetitive but this is a very conscious design decision on the developer's part. While you get bored your mind wanders and you can't help but think about what your character has done. As you try to rationalize his actions you go through some of the same psychological changes that shape his mind during the game. These changes are further pointed out by the exceptionally good voice acting.This game leads you on at first, reinforcing your childish, video-game/action-movie inspired expectations. And then it shows you what killing hundreds of people in a single day actually does to a person's mind. It gets in your head and hammers the point home by breaking the fourth wall and messing with you, goading you to simply stop playing. You're not supposed to have fun while playing this and the game itself is perfectly aware of that. If you do decide to play it to the bitter end it will simply leave you feeling drained and dirty.Spec Ops fails as a game on purpose to prove a point and teach you a lesson. I can't help but respect that.

number of helpful: 20 of 37 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												This is a poor squad based 3rd-person cover-shooter that has some interesting story ideas about the nature of war. It isn't subtle about it and there is little that draws you into feeling any real remorse or even shock for your behaviour in this theatre of war. The cover mechanics are clunky and at times infuriatingly broken as you'll find yourself under heavy fire and unable to duck behind cover for no particular reason and needlessly dying over and over again (my play-through was on hard...and as with most shooters that equates to nearly all enemies focusing their god like aim solely on you...and your team-mates suffering a lobotomy). The action itself isn't the worst but certainly isn't anything special either. If you've played a cover shooter you've played this game. And as with most cover-shooters repetition is the name of the game and boredom will soon settle in as there is little variation in the enemy types and the weapons you can pick up. Throw in a couple of bog-standard on-rails duck-shoots and this all seems very familiar and uninteresting.  As the story unfolds you'll be made (forced) to question your actions on the battlefield, the trouble is as you aren't really given much of an option, your actions aren't ever really in question, as it is the actions of the non-descript-mercenary-meathead type you are aiming the crosshairs for. I didn't really care and just wanted to carry on shooting more repetitive bad guys. War is very bad and sometimes rather unethical actions are unfortunately called for. I'm pretty sure most people would have worked that one out without it being rather crassly explained in some poorly acted CGI.   So, a cover-shooter where the cover mechanic is pretty terrible and the shooting is nothing but bog-standard fare. But at least it tried (and failed) to pose some morality questions. But ultimately this is not worth your time.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												A commando guided by the captain Martin Walker is sent to Dubai, that has been destroyed by a violent sandstorm. They have to investigate on an entire US batallion that vanished during the evacuation operations in the city. Desperately trying to accomplish his mission, the captain begins a descent into darkness and madness. Spec ops: the line is an important piece of videogame narration that is entirely based on the topic of moral responsibility. The player has to confront with extreme situations of war and to elaborate on the consequences of his own actions. To me, this is a great strenght of this product, overcoming other lacks in the general gameplay. As a tps, there is not so much variety, but at least the battle environments are challenging and appreciable. Someone criticized the game because of bugs and malfunctions. I didn't find them. 8/10: sufficiently entertaining, intelligent, well-narrated and deeply dramatic.

												You've probably heard most of the praise to be given to this game by now, so I'll skip the part where I suck this games♥♥♥♥♥♥for as long as it ♥♥♥♥ing wants and stick to facts:Gameplay (because this SHOULD be your first concern): - Shooting is solid and the guns (for the most part) actually feel like they can do some damage which seems to lack for most games. Hit detection never betrays you and you rarely feel cheated.- Difficult...I mean...enemies can actually pose some form of challenge. They WILL flank you and they WILL toss grenades World at War style but you are usually given a decent enough warning that if you die, it was probably your own fault.- Close encounters/executions are brutal and the game teaches you this rather quickly in a way that doesn't break the immersion.- It's actually fun to play. *OPINION WARNING* I genuinely enjoyed playing through it more than once and will be doing it again in the future.- Both keyboard+mouse and controllers feel good and neither is necessarily preferable to the other.Story:- It's a ♥♥♥♥ing bloodbath of a war/rebellion-torn Dubai ravaged by mass sandstorms...survive.- Okay, there is an initial objective but I don't like spoilers, let's just say there are genuinely concerning questions posed by the twists of a generally taboo topic...think about it...what if the Americans weren't ALWAYS the good guys? Mind-♥♥♥♥ing-explosion, right?!Visuals (last because it's a ♥♥♥♥ing video game, shut up and play the damn thing):- On a high-end machine, it's absolutely stunning the amount of detail placed into the game.- Even on a lower-end pc, the game looks solid and if you don't want your pc game looking slightly worse than on xbox, ♥♥♥♥ing buy it on xbox. Problem solved. - Small stutter upon checkpoints but you'll survive.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												This game. This ♥♥♥♥ing game.I'm a guy who is typically emotionless: I barely feel empathy or sympathy for anything. Right, now you have some background.Now, I had heard for awhile that this game was "chilling" and♥♥♥♥♥♥but never thought it would affect me, nor did I ever really have any interest in picking it up. I ended up doing so, however, when I required a new game and this one came on sale.It was the worst mistake of my life.I bought it, jumped in, and prepared for just another modern military shooter. It didn't dissapoint me in that regard, with the exception of the fact that it had an interesting plot.No. The ♥♥♥♥ing game waited for some hours before showing me what it meant by "chilling" and "disturbing".[SPOILERS AHEAD] In one sequence, you come upon the victims of a bombardment. But not just any bombardment; one of White Phosphorus. For a background, that♥♥♥♥♥♥is illegal under international military law. Fine, so our enemies commited war crimes; great way to dehumanize them, right? We'll get to that in a second, but for now, here's what you see: a bunch of screaming, squirming men on fire. Here, I met the "disturbing" aspect of the game. I even found myself wasting 5-10 bullets killing these guys out of mercy, because I legitimately felt saddened by their pain.But turns out that was just foreshadowing, because guess what you get to do 20 minutes later? You get to ♥♥♥♥ing use the WP yourself to wipe out an enemy position. Yeah. And guess what? You also end up killing a bunch of civilians. You have to wade through mangled, burnt corpses, and realize just how ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ war is.That, my friend, is why you buy the game. Not as a game, but as a way to convince you that you should never, ever, take war for granted.So what about the rest of the game? Eh, like I said, just another modern military shooter. But then again, like I said: you don't buy this game for the gameplay.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a solid 3rd person shooter that focuses on the horrors of war. It's kind of like "Apocalypse Now!" with Dubai as the setting but that comparison is giving it a little too much credit.  It's more like an ultraviolent summer blockbuster war movie. The story and dialogue come off hamfisted and silly at times. The voice acting is decent for the most part and the sound design is good. I would've liked the guns to be louder and bullet snaps would be great for immersion. The shooting mechanics are satisfying and the intensity of the combat is what kept me coming back to 100% this game. It's no "Red Orchestra" immersion wise, but I think it illustrates the horrors of war well in some ways. Enemies collapse and some suffer while clutching wounds or crawl away. They cough and whimper as blood pools around them. One thing they never do is surrender, which is an annoying trope of modern shooters. At least there are unarmed civilians on some levels, which goes against convention. The game also forces you into some bad situations with civilians which is a great way to show the ugliness of war.The game looks fantastic, even years later and it's surreal to see Dubai turned into a wartorn blood soaked ruin. Every firefight is fun and challenging if played on the harder difficulty levels. It would've been nice to have stealth be more viable. It's also a little funny that a 3 man squad kills off thousands of enemies. I know it's supposed to be somewhat of a satire on the modern military shooter but I would've rather had "Rainbow Six" style squad selection/commands and losses than 2 invulnerable baby sitters. I hope more games try to execute a "military shooter gone horror" vibe. I really like that the game is a train wreck of bad events and it tries to make you feel responsible and bad for it, kind of like the Kane & Lynch series. It was just a little too hamfisted, on rails and "gamey" for that feeling to hit me, but I enjoyed the horrific descent into madness nonetheless. If you are looking for a solid 3rd person shooter with an intense atmosphere, definitely grab this game.  7/10

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												First off, BUY AND PLAY THIS GAME!, It's absolutley fantastic!Secondly, here's why:    The story is simply too original to describe, People may overlook this game as a basic mil-spec shooter, but it is NOT! The main focus here is the EFFECTS of war on the soldiers not the shooting, although the mechanics work great and the gameplay feels solid too. The story follows 3 soldiers stranded in a dying Dubai, a Dubai they thought they were there to save. Surrounded by a raging sandstorm that is too strong to break through they fight their way through hostile sand covered streets and buildings to reach their goal of saving the civilians trapped there. Although nothing is what it seems.The twists and turns the story takes almost put the writing of games like Bioshock and GTA to shame.GamesRadar.com reviewed the game in their "The best videogame stories ever" article and I feel a direct quote would be sufficient:"Military shooters don't often rank high on the narrative front, usually favoring gung-ho G.I. Joe antics and flag waving over character development. And, at first, Spec Ops: The Line falls right in line with that stereotype--you take control of Walker, a soldier sent into a sandstorm-ruined Dubai to find a missing general. But as time goes on it becomes more and more obvious that there's something more devious afoot, and the shooter's story transforms from run-of-the-mill to one-of-a-kind.What unfolds is a damning criticism of shooters themselves, questioning everything that gamers have grown accustom to. Walker's journey sends him marching into the nucleus of the genre, playing with the storytelling in ways no other game has. By the end you might feel anger or sadness, but the important thing is that you'll feel something, and that's pretty rare in military shooters."I truly feel anyone who can play a shooter, even poorly, NEEDS to experience this game!Side note, I know it reads out I only have 2.5 hours, but most of the time spent playing through the SP was offline while my internet was disconnected lol.

content:

"The war is over for me now, but it will always be there, the rest of my days."-PlatoonThe many people I heard telling that Spec Ops was a retelling of Heart of Darkness and Apocalypse Now weren't lying. It's exactly that.The story, dialogues, design and voice acting are perfect.Plus, for once, it's not just a game about glorifying war but about how war can screw people up real hard and real fast.But I've got a serious problem with this game.the "game" part.I'm not big on TPS, I mean the only other TPSs I liked were Binary Domain (who had both a good story and decent gameplay) and Vanquish (0 story, all gameplay, all fun). But even like that i can tell you that Spec Ops is probably one of the most awful TPS, gameplay wise, ever made.It's especialy true on FUBAR when you suffer the most from the clumsy control, stupid AI of our teammate and fake difficulty (The helicopter at the end of chapter 6, the enemies with unlimited grenade supply in chapter 13, the stupidly scripted fight in chapter 14, etc).But still, even if there's not much "game" to play around, it's a great story to live and it is very well told.PS : Don't bother with the multiplayer.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Where to start with this game? Brilliance in the form of a storyline. I was not expecting this game to be all that great. I gathered from most reviews of it that it wasn't, but I still did purchase it. I can very gladly say that I was happily proven wrong. The storyline is so very well structured, with actions, even small ones, having a massive affect of the gameplay. I finished this game feeling terrible. Not many games have done that to me. The morals in Spec Ops: The Line are also represented on a very small scale, such as deciding whether or not to excecute a dying enemy for ammuntion. The gameplay element of The Line isn't the greatest: average is probably a good way to put it. Particular guns, like the snipers and heavier weapons, are completely overpowered in comparison to the others. It does cover based shooting fairly well, though it is a bit buggy in places. Overall, this game is a true emotionally-inducing adventure. It is an absolutely brilliant buy at $20-$30, and well worth it.Score: 7.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a Third Person Shooter that's focused around story rather than gameplay.This game has a pretty unique blip on my radar, and for good reasons. Simply, all I can say is the story alone is worth purchasing this game. The basic premise is about three Delta operators: Adams, Lugo, and Walker. They were sent out on a mission to rescue any survivors found in the desolated sand-wasteland of Dubai. You play as Walker, leading your squad to carry it out.Now this doesn't sound like a complex plot, it sounds incredibly simple, even. But the whole undertone of the story is what it's all about. Without giving away too much, Walker has the good intentions of saving all the civillians he can, and eliminating all evil that walk around them. However, it gets very psychological and personal, as Walker, and you, realize that the choices you thought were justified and well, turns out to be the exact opposite of what they are. It mentally breaks Walker down, trying to lead with his mind intact, trying to figure out good from evil, what he's doing right and wrong. The choices you make, sometimes there's never a good choice, it could be a lesser of two evils, but that's not saying much. War is hell, and sometimes, your best isn't enough. This is what the entire game is focused on: this, and the deeper meaning. It's truly an engrossing story that will leave you wanting more. I promise you won't regret it.The gameplay is less spectacular, it's your standard cover-and-shoot type. It's pretty textbook if you wanna look at it that way, as there isn't much to do besides... Well, cover and shoot, but there is a good amount of different weapons to use. One thing I do like though is that battles take place in lots of locations, the desolate presentation of Dubai is very immersive and nice to look at, so you can be doing close quarters battle in a broken building, fighting on a large battlefield, or snipe from across buildings. The varying locations do mix up gameplay a little bit, but it's still rather basic. It does work however, and it is still fun, just nothing really pops out.The game isn't too long, it could take you about 4-5 hours to finish the campaign. However if you wanna play the story again but with different choices, you can probably clock in another 3 if you skip cutscenes.Multiplayer is there, but this game has a very low population, I doubt you'll find anyone, so I can't give off my impression there.There is a Co-Op mode where you can play the campaign with a friend, who plays as either Lugo or Adams. That's very fun and it works pretty well. If you got someone to play with and wanna enjoy the story together, that brings up something fun to do as well.Overall, Spec Ops is an amazing game with a deep, enriching plot that is sure to leave a lasting impression on you, that's what it's all about, even if the gameplay is pretty textbook stuff, and the short length. However, you won't regret buying this, I recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2013
												Spec Ops: The Line is my top shooter of 2012. That said, it's hard to critique it in the same way I do other games. It has generic gameplay and I'm not a huge fan of cover based shooters, but the idea behind the game and the narrative it takes you through makes it something unique and unexpected in this world of Call of Duty and Battlefield shooters. Nolan North (of Nathan Drake fame) gives an outstanding voice acting performance, as do the rest of the VO team, giving true character development to the main protagonist and his squadmates. This voice progression is coupled with physical and emotional changes throughout the game - this makes Spec Ops easily the most in-depth shooter to date, but the list of plusses just goes on and on. It has cool little things such as a "bullet in the chamber" addition to the reloading mechanic, as well as semi-destructable environments, bullet penetration, and phenomenal music choices throughout the game. While the explosions in the game felt a little lacking to me, the story, oh god the story, was one of the best I've experienced in a shooter for a long time. The environments were cool and somewhat varied (although the sand is ever present, but it does add some cool environmental "kill" options) and there was a neat mechanic where every time you got a headshot time would slow down a little bit to let you revel in the destruction you've caused.I'm not going to go through a pros and cons list as I feel that would be detrimental to the game and the experience it provides, this is truly gaming as narrative at its finest. I will also neglect it a letter grade, and simply state that this is a phenomenal game that *every* gamer should play.If you enjoyed the story and narrative of Spec Ops and want to further your understanding of it, I recommend reading the ebook Killing is Harmless by Brendan Keogh. It's an essay/short novel on a playthrough of the game and, although it is a little heavy handed at times, gives a great insight into the game and what it is trying to do and make the player experience. TL;DR: Everyone should play this game.

												Interesting story.  A whole lot of grit, just like a war game should have.  I enjoyed it.I haven't touched a single player war game in years, it just seems to me that every single one has a story line about how some group gets their hands on a nuke, and you've got to stop them.  It's refreshing that this game went in a different direction all together.  The story is somewhat dark, and gave me a sinking feeling more than once, it's nice to get some emotional feedback from a video game.Ammo is scarce so it adds some stress to the fire fights.  Two gripes:1.) The console like controls, where 1 button handles multiple functions depending upon the situation, but once you get in the groove it works.2.) Sometimes incoming grenades seem like they should have gone far past you, when in the game they are still close enough to kill you.  Reloaded more checkpoints than I care to think about due to this.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												At first glance, Spec Ops: The Line might seem to be another Call of Duty clone, but actually it is so much more than that. Quite honestly, I'm not really into military shooters, but I enjoy playing this game. An amazing story sets the pace with many unexpected twists and turns. This game shows perfectly all the brutality of war. The plot is constantly keeping you guessing and the ending is very mind blowing. Yes, some of it could be a little quirky, but it is still one of the best stories I've ever encountered. Also, the game has excellent character progression.However, the 3rd-person shooter gameplay is pretty unimpressive: the cover system is temperamental, the aiming sucks, the weapons are boring, and stealth is rarely possible. It ends up being repetitive as do most cover-and-fire games. So, to be honest, the gameplay is nothing special and could be considered  quite bad, but I guess that is not what this game is made for.The graphics are quite good, the soundtracks are also amazing and only bring more depth to the game. On top of that, the noise and effects are genuinely special, sounding real and effective. Furthermore, the voice acting is top-tier and sounds very real.Overall, if you go into playing Spec Ops: The Line with the mindset that it is a run of the military shooter you will be disappointing, but if you play it looking for a game that's story is both gripping and thought provoking, try this out. Trust me, this shooter is an outstanding piece of art when it comes to terms of story and picture. Give this game a shot, it might change your perception of the whole genre more than its technically superior counterparts ever could.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a Third Person Shooter that's focused around story rather than gameplay.This game has a pretty unique blip on my radar, and for good reasons. Simply, all I can say is the story alone is worth purchasing this game. The basic premise is about three Delta operators: Adams, Lugo, and Walker. They were sent out on a mission to rescue any survivors found in the desolated sand-wasteland of Dubai. You play as Walker, leading your squad to carry it out.Now this doesn't sound like a complex plot, it sounds incredibly simple, even. But the whole undertone of the story is what it's all about. Without giving away too much, Walker has the good intentions of saving all the civillians he can, and eliminating all evil that walk around them. However, it gets very psychological and personal, as Walker, and you, realize that the choices you thought were justified and well, turns out to be the exact opposite of what they are. It mentally breaks Walker down, trying to lead with his mind intact, trying to figure out good from evil, what he's doing right and wrong. The choices you make, sometimes there's never a good choice, it could be a lesser of two evils, but that's not saying much. War is hell, and sometimes, your best isn't enough. This is what the entire game is focused on: this, and the deeper meaning. It's truly an engrossing story that will leave you wanting more. I promise you won't regret it.The gameplay is less spectacular, it's your standard cover-and-shoot type. It's pretty textbook if you wanna look at it that way, as there isn't much to do besides... Well, cover and shoot, but there is a good amount of different weapons to use. One thing I do like though is that battles take place in lots of locations, the desolate presentation of Dubai is very immersive and nice to look at, so you can be doing close quarters battle in a broken building, fighting on a large battlefield, or snipe from across buildings. The varying locations do mix up gameplay a little bit, but it's still rather basic. It does work however, and it is still fun, just nothing really pops out.The game isn't too long, it could take you about 4-5 hours to finish the campaign. However if you wanna play the story again but with different choices, you can probably clock in another 3 if you skip cutscenes.Multiplayer is there, but this game has a very low population, I doubt you'll find anyone, so I can't give off my impression there.There is a Co-Op mode where you can play the campaign with a friend, who plays as either Lugo or Adams. That's very fun and it works pretty well. If you got someone to play with and wanna enjoy the story together, that brings up something fun to do as well.Overall, Spec Ops is an amazing game with a deep, enriching plot that is sure to leave a lasting impression on you, that's what it's all about, even if the gameplay is pretty textbook stuff, and the short length. However, you won't regret buying this, I recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												I'd class myself as a bit of a pessimist about raving reviews that give 10/10 saying things like ' the most electrifying game since x' etc these days, as there are very few honest reviews around as they've either been paid for by the developers, or it's people kissing major♥♥♥♥♥so they can be looked upon favourably by developers in the future.I picked this up last year on sale for around £4.00 as I was looking for something a bit different to your COD's and Battlefield's in terms of a singleplayer story driven FPS and actually, was quite surprised at the level of detail and immersiveness it offers.You play the leader of a small squad tasked with trying to find a general believed to still be alive somewhere in a ravaged Dubai. Pretty soon♥♥♥♥♥♥(mixed with an unfeasibly large amount of sand) hits the fan, and being such a badass your character is increasingly more determined to find out wth is going on.As the story progresses you are faced with some plot changing ultimatums which will have an impact later on, the more you get to these stages of the game the more you are drawn into this world and the story itself.If you can set the detail level and textures to max on your PC, then i strongly advise to do so. So many times i'd completely forget about the objective and just stop and look around in awe at the strange mix of a half destroyed metropolis, really quite impressive considering it was released a few years back.Difficulty is actually quite challenging and can be brutal in some places, it's a fairly short game but dying so many time got a bit more longetivity out of it. Both your squad AI and enemy AI are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in places but it can be forgiven for the times that your tactics work like clockwork, hit and miss.Even i'm getting bored of this review now, so all I will say is that if you're into challenging immersive games, with ultimatums, well written story and a bit more level of tactical awareness needed than a bog standard FPS, then pick this up in the sale and you'll be glad you did.Oh yeah, and don't buy it if you're easily grossed out or offended - aka: a massive crybaby

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												A game you will love or hate, absolutely. As a military shooter, it's a generic but functional game with a useless tacked-on multiplayer mode that the developers have openly disowned. As a story-based singleplayer experience, it's notable for taking what starts as the most generic story imaginable and turning it into a meta-narrative that questions the the nature of video games while the protagonist questions his own heroism. While not perfect in its storytelling, it tries something that flies in the face of current trends and is essentially a giant middle-finger to Call of Duty and its imitators. Either you'll be on board with the idea and enjoy its ambiguous storyline, or you'll find it a pretentious attempt at an art game built on the back of a mediocre shooter. If you're curious, it's worth the time and money simply because it exists.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Nothing good ever happens to anyone in Spec Ops: The Line. It starts with a rescue, a rough situation destined to get worse, and unravels in a downward spiral where only bad things happen to good people. By the end, physical, mental, and moral disruption leave each character in a very different place than they started. You almost expect it to have been written by Game of Thrones author George R.R. Martin. This isn’t a good thing for Captain Martin Walker, our intrepid hero whose will weakens with every enemy encounter. He transforms from a cheesy cliché to someone you sympathize with, and then develops into something despicable. How he gets there isn’t up to you -- what it ultimately means, though, is entirely your call. Story is Spec Ops’ strong suit, and while the inconsistent combat isn’t ideal, the gameplay does a great job of facilitating that narrative between intense encounters. In fact, The Line accomplishes something most shooters don’t bother with: It makes violence meaningful. Every firefight ends with Walker and his Delta Force squad regretting what they've done. The Line puts them in the precarious position of fighting their brethren. Rogue American soldiers who’ve abandoned their duty in Dubai attack on sight, and not without reason. The city is a wasteland, the environment is as hostile as the refugees, and surviving requires aggressive self-defense. Dubai hosts a civil war between multiple factions trying not to die. The Deltas are just one of these groups. As Walker, you’ll discover dark and disturbing things about Dubai and the people stuck within it. In your mission to save civilians and make contact with a former commander, you’ll make tough decisions that aren’t like other video game choices. Morality isn’t a feature or mechanic in Spec Ops: The Line -- each ethical quandary Walker confronts are subtle story beats dealt with by in-game action rather than a separate yes/no mechanism. You project their meaning and importance onto your character without seeing substantial in-game consequence. Deciding which of the bickering, increasingly angry teammates to side with, or who lives and dies, doesn’t affect the outcome of your rescue mission. In fact, the finale has a greater effect on the six hours leading up to it. Choice changes what it means to be this man. He makes the inevitable bad call and deals with it, nothing more. On the other side of every door and dune are conspiracies, betrayals, and mysteries waiting for Walker. The battles on the way to each one strengthens The Line's constant tension. Walker is just a man, and bullets rip him to pieces. He’s vulnerable and his enemies are aggressive, which encourages intelligent tactical combat. The Line introduces new variables in each fight. Sometimes sandstorms, sunshine, or objects obscure your vision. Fast-moving melee specialists, heavy gunners, and grenadiers force you to stay mobile and risk exposure. Destroying walls to drown enemies in sand is as viable a tactic as taking a turret, popping out of cover with a SCAR, or commanding squadmates. Marking targets keeps you safe while slipping from one unreliable cover point to the next, and issuing commands to stun soldiers with flashbangs keeps them from suppressing you. Walker’s commands are simple and few because he doesn’t rely on them. When they’re not shooting at walls, Lugo and Adams -- Walker’s left- and right-hand men -- are capable of dealing with waves of attackers. They saved me from dying multiple times when Spec Ops’ mechanics failed me. On multiple occasions, Walker didn’t slide into or sprint out of cover properly. Half the time I tried protecting myself, my character stopped dead before dropping dead. Vaulting over objects is an issue as well because its input is the same as the melee attack, meaning Walker would sometimes punch the air instead of hop over a barrier. With no evasive roll to dodge effectively, control problems hung me out to dry. Unpredictability and variety are the saviors of Spec Ops’ standard stop-and-pop formula, and neither exists in its online multiplayer. The adversarial side of The Line is an empty experience that relies on your lust for unlockables without presenting a reason to care. Getting new guns, protective gear, perks to boost stats, and cosmetic apparel is fun, but playing eight-player deathmatches on large yet cluttered maps is hardly a thrilling method to earn them. The reward system itself is a letdown, too. The prizes for leveling up are similar weapons with minimal improvements and too-familiar ballistics. The beacon of hope in multiplayer is the objective-based Buried mode, which tasks two teams of four to sabotage the enemy HQ while defending their own. It’s a tense tug-of-war full of panic and planning -- it’s a shame such a smart game type is trapped in the shell of an unremarkable online afterthought. Multiplayer lacks the aesthetic spirit of the single-player campaign as well. What begins as a drab, brown desert shooter suddenly develops a gorgeous, colorful personality. The purples, blues, greens, reds, and golds of the campaign's incredible interiors leave lasting impressions; you'll associate red and green with different but equally unsettling events. Color certainly exists in the multiplayer maps, but it isn't spotlighted or emphasized in a meaningful way. Meanwhile, the rock music of the early game gives way to somber acoustic melodies as the Delta crew deteriorates, further establishing the unforgiving tone in and out of combat. When all's said and done and the dust has settled, Spec Ops puts players in an interesting position. The endings -- whichever one you get -- are open to interpretation while still offering closure. The new information shines new lights on various spots in the story that warrant a second run through the campaign. The depth of these convincing characters is clearer when you know the fate you're responsible for. You see Dubai and those left behind in a new way. Most importantly, you finally understand Walker, which could well change the way you act on his motivations. What you regretted the first time could eat you alive when it's done differently. This is why Spec Ops is a daring experiment worth celebrating. For the first time, a game with guns doesn't want you to be the hero -- it wants you to feel terrible about trying to be one.THE VERDICTSpec Ops isn’t about a war, protecting the world, or defeating some evil threat -- it’s about you, the effects of your actions, and events that are out of your control. The sum of Spec Ops’ unexpected story is an army shooter that makes killing people mean something. This, along with its thoughtful aesthetic and intelligent enemy encounters, defies the standard established by low-aiming action games. Multiplayer can’t muster up the same courage, though, and while the hollow online experience doesn’t detract from the single-player campaign’s accomplishments, its reliance on convention doesn’t do anything to elevate it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												I would describe the core gameplay as a competent shooter. Nothing too unique. I have become tired by repetitious shooters over the last few years when I just have so many other options in regard to games I can play. What makes this game recommendable is everything else about it. Most obviously the story - its great, and it actually feels pretty important. Its similar to Apocalypse Now but in modern Dubai rather than 70's Vietnam. The story, once it gets rolling, asks you to question how you as a player of a shooter video game can convince yourself that it can ever be right to take the life of another human being - and the lengths we go to make rationalizations for killing. The game is an exercise in cognitive dissonance; you're forced to question the act of killing and come to terms with the consequences of taking another person's life, but at the same time you're supposed to kill hundreds of people. People who thrash about near-death on the ground, coughing up blood, frantically asking for help with what little breath they have left. The story is thoughtful, the voice acting is great, the sound design and implementation of soundtrack are both great, and the game looks great. The core gameplay itself, though, is still pretty average for third-person cover shooters.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												A spectacular game, the scenery is amazing, the story is captivating and the gameplay is perfect.This isn't the only game I've played where you're aren't the good guy, but what makes this game unique is its the first one that doesn't even try to justify it, if anything it rubs in that horrible truth. The story line is fantastic, and is filled with choices that basically boil down to, "Do you really want to do it the hard way just to spare some civilian lives?"The gameplay on, normal difficulty, was perfect for me. Easy enough for you to mow down enemies if you play right, and hard enough to where it messes you up the second you get cocky. The ai and levels are designed to force you to change weapons 2-3 times a level keeping the experience fresh and fun. The AI is pretty smart as well, they have scripted flanks and occasionally you get to hear them talk about their personal lives, reminding you that these are people you are killing.Like most FPS these days the game is littered with collectables that have their own mini story to tell. Usually I collect them for the sake of collecting them, but these were so good I'd find my self searching dark corners of the level just for a little more story.OVERALL, it was a great game, I only picked it up because I heard it was a bit unique and it was on sale for like $3. I got lucky, but if I had got it at full price I'd still be very happy. My only complaint, the take cover and sprint button are the same key, it can be as annoying as Assassins Creed's run and climb button from time to time. 9/10 When bullets are flying, sometimes your character might decide that instead of diving out of the way, he wants to die a rhino.

												Whoooaaaaaaa, dude! What a game! I beat it 3 times and I still feel like doing it again. A mindblowing experience. I still don’t fully understand the story, but I’m not supposed to. Out of the 4 different endings, the one I liked the most was the one that gives you the Too Late The Hero and The Road To Glory achievements. It fits well with the level of craziness going on in this game. I’m really proud of myself for getting the Sierra Hotel achievement while on Suicide Mission difficulty and beating the game on FUBAR difficulty. By my third playthrough, I had gotten pretty good at getting headshots, so while it wasn’t a walk on the beach, it wasn't that hard. Enemies don’t respawn forever, so you just have to take it slow and deal with one at a time. The attack order was bugged for me in certain resolutions though, which was really annoying since I had to lower the resolution to 800x600 for it to work properly.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												"Aw jeez... where's all this violence coming from? Is it the video games? I bet it's the video games."I'm just going to start off with overall ratings as I know some people don't like lengthy reviewsMajor aspects:Gameplay: 9/10 Very good for this style which has become so rare (a third person cover and shoot)Story line: 10/10 The best I have ever encountered, far better than even games such as the Telltale's “The Walking Dead” Immersion/atmosphere: 10/10 The atmosphere was incredible, this game is one of the rare games that you can truly lose yourself in.Graphics: 10/10 Despite the game being a few years old I have never seen a game with better graphics.Minor aspects:Realism: 8.5/10 Aside from the lack of friendly fire and the fact that you face hordes of enemies while surviving (though your health is relatively low), this game is rather realisticSmoothness (gameplay): 9/10 This game felt very nice to play and its only fault would be occasionally I would not duck for cover unless I pressed the button several times. Voice acting: 10/10 All the voices suit the characters very well and there is not a single voice actor that taints the immersion of the game.Player involvement (choices): 10/10 The choices were incredible, however I would have preferred it if there were a few more. Overall:I don't really base the score from the minor aspects so the score (from critic point of view) is:9.75/10Though, personally, I believe this is the greatest game I have ever played and would rate it:10/10General review:When I first decided to play this game I thought it was a typical trashy shooter. This was reinforced by the single player being referred to as the "campaign" and even more so when the game started off with a typical Gatling gun in a helicopter scene. However, a few minutes into the game I was proven wrong, this game has the greatest storyline I have ever seen, there aren't really any incredibly “tear jerking” moments as there are with games such as the walking dead, however the game still does an incredible job to connect with the player emotionally as well conveying the emotions and journey of the protagonist. Without trying to give too much away, the game also includes a variation of choices that effect the game and also lead to multiple diverse endings.The game play mainly consists of finding cover, coming up from cover and shooting enemies. Though the gameplay is repetitive the various amounts of guns, enemies terrain variations and other things, make the game continuously enjoyable. The animation of combat is very nice as well, the darting for cover and switching to different cover was a very nice animation that made the game feel extremely nice to play.The atmosphere in this game, contrasted with the outstanding graphics, creates a unique world for the player to experience. The atmosphere in this game is unlike any other shooter and truly makes you feel like a real soldier, rather than just an emotionless killing machine, this is reinforced by the two soldiers under you command that are polar opposites, I won't go into that though for it would spoil a large portion of the game. Overall I cannot recommend this game any more highly, it is easily the greatest game I have every played and the only real drawback would be the length. The game has everything that you could possibly ask and so much more. IT is incredibly unique and simply extraordinary, it is definitely worth buying and playing.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game left me in a pensive zombified state for at least a week after completing it. It plays like your typical third person shooter, but this game throws extremely difficult decisions at you that leave you second-guessing your morals throughout the length of the game. At least twice I had to stop and really question myself. Messes with your head man. I highly recommend it for anyone who likes to be touched by the story in a game and I definitely recommend it for fans of war movies. You really begin to notice gradual changes in the characters as they get sucked deeper and deeper into the♥♥♥♥♥♥ Their war cries get more blood-curdling and frantic, their executions become more brutal, and eventually it just seems like they've snapped.Only con is that there isn't great replayability. Sure you can go through it again at higher difficulties and go achievement hunting, but ultimately its the same story. HOWEVER... you can try making different decisions on a second or third playthrough and you may even notice subtle foreshadowing and weird mind-♥♥♥♥ visuals that you didn't notice before. Personally, I find myself wanting to come back to this game a few times a year just to re-experience the feelings that come with completing it.I will never forget this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												I don't review games often but this one really smacks you in the face. When you watch a movie and you're still thinking about it days later, you know you've seen something special. I am having that same feeling with this game.I am not a big shooter player so I won't comment in detail on the gameplay mechanics or the difficulty, I found them both great, but the story and the artwork was incredible. I found myself rationalising the protagonist's choices as if they were my own. Even as events started to spiral out of control, I found myself trying to think about what I would do if it were my boots in the sand. I couldn't ever question Walker's decisions because they were always based on a truth he had compiled from an incomplete understanding of the situation, which was something I shared with him. It's a three dimensional look at war, imaged in breathtaking scenes and with commendable voice-acting. Oftentimes, war is not as we traditionally define it. Decisions are not always based on what is good or bad, heroic or cowardly. They are often driven by interpretation of orders and gut-feel. And when dreadful things happen, do we really fully appreciate the toll on those that felt they had to pull the trigger, squinting though the fog of war? This is a visceral and engaging experience which I highly recommend to gamers looking for something a bit different.
