number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Nothing good ever happens to anyone in Spec Ops: The Line. It starts with a rescue, a rough situation destined to get worse, and unravels in a downward spiral where only bad things happen to good people. By the end, physical, mental, and moral disruption leave each character in a very different place than they started. You almost expect it to have been written by Game of Thrones author George R.R. Martin. This isn’t a good thing for Captain Martin Walker, our intrepid hero whose will weakens with every enemy encounter. He transforms from a cheesy cliché to someone you sympathize with, and then develops into something despicable. How he gets there isn’t up to you -- what it ultimately means, though, is entirely your call. Story is Spec Ops’ strong suit, and while the inconsistent combat isn’t ideal, the gameplay does a great job of facilitating that narrative between intense encounters. In fact, The Line accomplishes something most shooters don’t bother with: It makes violence meaningful. Every firefight ends with Walker and his Delta Force squad regretting what they've done. The Line puts them in the precarious position of fighting their brethren. Rogue American soldiers who’ve abandoned their duty in Dubai attack on sight, and not without reason. The city is a wasteland, the environment is as hostile as the refugees, and surviving requires aggressive self-defense. Dubai hosts a civil war between multiple factions trying not to die. The Deltas are just one of these groups. As Walker, you’ll discover dark and disturbing things about Dubai and the people stuck within it. In your mission to save civilians and make contact with a former commander, you’ll make tough decisions that aren’t like other video game choices. Morality isn’t a feature or mechanic in Spec Ops: The Line -- each ethical quandary Walker confronts are subtle story beats dealt with by in-game action rather than a separate yes/no mechanism. You project their meaning and importance onto your character without seeing substantial in-game consequence. Deciding which of the bickering, increasingly angry teammates to side with, or who lives and dies, doesn’t affect the outcome of your rescue mission. In fact, the finale has a greater effect on the six hours leading up to it. Choice changes what it means to be this man. He makes the inevitable bad call and deals with it, nothing more. On the other side of every door and dune are conspiracies, betrayals, and mysteries waiting for Walker. The battles on the way to each one strengthens The Line's constant tension. Walker is just a man, and bullets rip him to pieces. He’s vulnerable and his enemies are aggressive, which encourages intelligent tactical combat. The Line introduces new variables in each fight. Sometimes sandstorms, sunshine, or objects obscure your vision. Fast-moving melee specialists, heavy gunners, and grenadiers force you to stay mobile and risk exposure. Destroying walls to drown enemies in sand is as viable a tactic as taking a turret, popping out of cover with a SCAR, or commanding squadmates. Marking targets keeps you safe while slipping from one unreliable cover point to the next, and issuing commands to stun soldiers with flashbangs keeps them from suppressing you. Walker’s commands are simple and few because he doesn’t rely on them. When they’re not shooting at walls, Lugo and Adams -- Walker’s left- and right-hand men -- are capable of dealing with waves of attackers. They saved me from dying multiple times when Spec Ops’ mechanics failed me. On multiple occasions, Walker didn’t slide into or sprint out of cover properly. Half the time I tried protecting myself, my character stopped dead before dropping dead. Vaulting over objects is an issue as well because its input is the same as the melee attack, meaning Walker would sometimes punch the air instead of hop over a barrier. With no evasive roll to dodge effectively, control problems hung me out to dry. Unpredictability and variety are the saviors of Spec Ops’ standard stop-and-pop formula, and neither exists in its online multiplayer. The adversarial side of The Line is an empty experience that relies on your lust for unlockables without presenting a reason to care. Getting new guns, protective gear, perks to boost stats, and cosmetic apparel is fun, but playing eight-player deathmatches on large yet cluttered maps is hardly a thrilling method to earn them. The reward system itself is a letdown, too. The prizes for leveling up are similar weapons with minimal improvements and too-familiar ballistics. The beacon of hope in multiplayer is the objective-based Buried mode, which tasks two teams of four to sabotage the enemy HQ while defending their own. It’s a tense tug-of-war full of panic and planning -- it’s a shame such a smart game type is trapped in the shell of an unremarkable online afterthought. Multiplayer lacks the aesthetic spirit of the single-player campaign as well. What begins as a drab, brown desert shooter suddenly develops a gorgeous, colorful personality. The purples, blues, greens, reds, and golds of the campaign's incredible interiors leave lasting impressions; you'll associate red and green with different but equally unsettling events. Color certainly exists in the multiplayer maps, but it isn't spotlighted or emphasized in a meaningful way. Meanwhile, the rock music of the early game gives way to somber acoustic melodies as the Delta crew deteriorates, further establishing the unforgiving tone in and out of combat. When all's said and done and the dust has settled, Spec Ops puts players in an interesting position. The endings -- whichever one you get -- are open to interpretation while still offering closure. The new information shines new lights on various spots in the story that warrant a second run through the campaign. The depth of these convincing characters is clearer when you know the fate you're responsible for. You see Dubai and those left behind in a new way. Most importantly, you finally understand Walker, which could well change the way you act on his motivations. What you regretted the first time could eat you alive when it's done differently. This is why Spec Ops is a daring experiment worth celebrating. For the first time, a game with guns doesn't want you to be the hero -- it wants you to feel terrible about trying to be one.THE VERDICTSpec Ops isn’t about a war, protecting the world, or defeating some evil threat -- it’s about you, the effects of your actions, and events that are out of your control. The sum of Spec Ops’ unexpected story is an army shooter that makes killing people mean something. This, along with its thoughtful aesthetic and intelligent enemy encounters, defies the standard established by low-aiming action games. Multiplayer can’t muster up the same courage, though, and while the hollow online experience doesn’t detract from the single-player campaign’s accomplishments, its reliance on convention doesn’t do anything to elevate it.

												Whoooaaaaaaa, dude! What a game! I beat it 3 times and I still feel like doing it again. A mindblowing experience. I still don’t fully understand the story, but I’m not supposed to. Out of the 4 different endings, the one I liked the most was the one that gives you the Too Late The Hero and The Road To Glory achievements. It fits well with the level of craziness going on in this game. I’m really proud of myself for getting the Sierra Hotel achievement while on Suicide Mission difficulty and beating the game on FUBAR difficulty. By my third playthrough, I had gotten pretty good at getting headshots, so while it wasn’t a walk on the beach, it wasn't that hard. Enemies don’t respawn forever, so you just have to take it slow and deal with one at a time. The attack order was bugged for me in certain resolutions though, which was really annoying since I had to lower the resolution to 800x600 for it to work properly.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												When a city of millions sinks into the sand before descending into anarchy and chaos who should the powers that be call to restore order? If you this game up that would be you.This is a vastly under-rated third person shooter. The gameplay is rock solid and fun with action and excitement oozing from every place that oozes such things. The gun play is engrossing and offers everything you could want from a shooter. The guns themselves have a good feeling about them and really do kill the fudge out of everything standing in your way. That being said play on the harder difficulties unless you want to mow down everyone in your way without breaking a sweat.The storyline is very unusual for a title such as this; it’s actually good for a change. Spoiling nothing for you but you will want to find out the truth and face all the horrors along the way. The writing team behind this is seasoned and it honestly shows. No faults there at all.What really drew me in though was the world itself, a real decaying beauty in everything. It really does feel like a city torn apart and rebuilt in a mad man’s image. The set pieces are stunning and the vistas throughout the game will leave you wanting moreI whole heartedly recommend this game to everyone. With a plot like this and the mechanics to back it up it is well worth your time and money.Have fun ^_^

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												First off, BUY AND PLAY THIS GAME!, It's absolutley fantastic!Secondly, here's why:    The story is simply too original to describe, People may overlook this game as a basic mil-spec shooter, but it is NOT! The main focus here is the EFFECTS of war on the soldiers not the shooting, although the mechanics work great and the gameplay feels solid too. The story follows 3 soldiers stranded in a dying Dubai, a Dubai they thought they were there to save. Surrounded by a raging sandstorm that is too strong to break through they fight their way through hostile sand covered streets and buildings to reach their goal of saving the civilians trapped there. Although nothing is what it seems.The twists and turns the story takes almost put the writing of games like Bioshock and GTA to shame.GamesRadar.com reviewed the game in their "The best videogame stories ever" article and I feel a direct quote would be sufficient:"Military shooters don't often rank high on the narrative front, usually favoring gung-ho G.I. Joe antics and flag waving over character development. And, at first, Spec Ops: The Line falls right in line with that stereotype--you take control of Walker, a soldier sent into a sandstorm-ruined Dubai to find a missing general. But as time goes on it becomes more and more obvious that there's something more devious afoot, and the shooter's story transforms from run-of-the-mill to one-of-a-kind.What unfolds is a damning criticism of shooters themselves, questioning everything that gamers have grown accustom to. Walker's journey sends him marching into the nucleus of the genre, playing with the storytelling in ways no other game has. By the end you might feel anger or sadness, but the important thing is that you'll feel something, and that's pretty rare in military shooters."I truly feel anyone who can play a shooter, even poorly, NEEDS to experience this game!Side note, I know it reads out I only have 2.5 hours, but most of the time spent playing through the SP was offline while my internet was disconnected lol.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Note: This only covers the singleplayer expereince. I didn't play the coop or multiplayer. Look at the other review that talk about them. Pros:+ Amazing story+ Gameplay is fun+ Graphics are pretty good (not amazing, but you can't really complain)+ Nice voice acting+ Multiple endings+ The way your character changes over the course of the game is a nice touch.Neutral:+/- The AI isn't the best, but it works+/- The gameplay can be a little repetitive. You take cover, shoot, and maybe throw a grenade. Cons: - It's pretty short- [MINOR SPOILER]  Some of the choices you make in the game don't actually affect the ending - Not a fan of the controls- I don't like how you die. When you are killed everything goes into slow motion and slowly fades to black. Then before it goes to black it says "You Are Dead" in blurry white text. It's not very dramatic. This is something that really only bothers me so feel free to disregard this.Conclusion:Highly recommended game, but I wouldn't get it for full price if i only wanted it for the singleplayer.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
"The war is over for me now, but it will always be there, the rest of my days."-PlatoonThe many people I heard telling that Spec Ops was a retelling of Heart of Darkness and Apocalypse Now weren't lying. It's exactly that.The story, dialogues, design and voice acting are perfect.Plus, for once, it's not just a game about glorifying war but about how war can screw people up real hard and real fast.But I've got a serious problem with this game.the "game" part.I'm not big on TPS, I mean the only other TPSs I liked were Binary Domain (who had both a good story and decent gameplay) and Vanquish (0 story, all gameplay, all fun). But even like that i can tell you that Spec Ops is probably one of the most awful TPS, gameplay wise, ever made.It's especialy true on FUBAR when you suffer the most from the clumsy control, stupid AI of our teammate and fake difficulty (The helicopter at the end of chapter 6, the enemies with unlimited grenade supply in chapter 13, the stupidly scripted fight in chapter 14, etc).But still, even if there's not much "game" to play around, it's a great story to live and it is very well told.PS : Don't bother with the multiplayer.

												it has been said many times before but ill say it again..this game is ♥♥♥♥ing great. probably the best storyline i have ever experienced in a shooter.pro:-nice graphics-cool soundtrack (also includes some 60s/70s music)-great story (seems like the devs watched apocalypse now and other anti war movies and thought: hey can we make something like this into a game?)-challenging difficulty (at least on the "hardest" difficulty. i didnt play the game on the one you have to unlock though)-not 2 pricey-radioman (robert ♥♥♥♥ing darden)cons:-not a very long game (took me about 8 1/2 hours to beat. and i died a lot!)-while i personally enjoyed the combat a lot of people think its kinda mundane. (its just not something special but i think its fine for what it is.)-might not have a lot of replayability (though there are choices to be made and multiple endings but overall the game is fairly linear)spec ops really DOES make you think of the horrors of war. some scenes will make your stomach turn and your soul die! by the time you reach the ending you will feel kinda sad. but youll  still be happy about having experienced this little gem. sad this game flopped. id take this over CoD and other generic jingoism crap ANY DAY.i can highly recommend this game. you should definitely play it if you have no problem with its short lenght and not-so-special combat mechanics.DONT be fooled by the crap trailers. they deliberately give a false impression.things are not as they seem in this game.if you happen to buy this game : welcome to dubai!thx for reading

Posted: January 14, 2016
												How many times have you played a videogame where at the end you had to question your actions? Question the game? Cry in the bathtub?  With a breathtaking narrative, fantastic visuals and top notch OST you will feel like♥♥♥♥♥♥ But you'll be happy you played this gem. The only downside of Spec Ops The Line is the gameplay. Not that it's bad, it's actually very solid. But it's unoriginal and feels like a chore when there is so much more going on. The rest of the game breaks new ground, the gameplay is just bland. In the end, I think the problem was really what the Publisher wanted to sell as opposed to what the developer wanted to create. If we look at all the promotional material and even the forced multiplayer, the generic (yet popular in other games) that's the conclusion I get to.In any case, the story is fantastic and you should give this a shot.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Part of me wants to make a humorous review like "10/10 Would be a hero again!" but in all honesty, I think this "average" shooter deserves better. And it is an average shooter, there is no denying that. I died quite a few times because of the occasionally wonky cover mechanics. The thing about this game that I think everyone should experience, is the story.What a story it is! I shall not spoil anything but it is pretty mundane for the first bit and even an early big shocker isn't super impactful (in my opinion). But the ending! Oh the ending! You can't just watch it on youtube, it's something that will only have any impact on someone who has actually played through the whole thing. There were a few intense choices at the end and I'm actually amazed at one of the choices the developers allowed the players to have.There will be no sequel to this game (it doesn't need one), but I hope the writers/developers go on to make more things that make me think while simultaneously ♥♥♥♥ing with my head.[Note: I don't think this is a $30 game but I'd say it's more than worth it when it goes on sale for ten or less.]

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												This game is one of a great game that I will strongly recommend - but not to everyone. Indeed, it is both very similar to the basic TPS and very different from the other "common" games. For a start, the game mechanics don't really stand out from other shooters. The cover system is quite classic, the various weapons are nothing but well-made, enemies will most likely be coming by everywhere while shooting and yelling, the different AIs are correct, although your teammates will most of the time die while running, and there are shining red barrels that will explode when shot, as well as turrets and miniguns. Multiplayer is not worth the single player, and coop consists of alternative 2-players missions. Still, there are quite some original things, such as the contextual sand that will often allow you to get rid of a bunch of angry people or some eye-candies like the trees, walls or towers that fall when shot at.That brings us to the fact that the game also looks like a movie. Indeed, it's very linear, as the main storyline can be summed up with a map. But it's also pretty scripted, and every single detail seems to have been done with care : the crashing helos, the falling towers, the blowing glass roofs, the collapsing quicksands... and even though sometimes, the action is spoiled by the too obvious script, it still succeeds in stressing the player, who'll eventually have to choose between four pretty different endings.But the biggest part of the game revolves around the story. It may be a little hard to get why you get shot at so much in the beginning, but except a few odd things, the struggle between morality and immorality, allies and enemies, life and death is surprisingly thorough for a videogame. Indeed, there is nothing silly, as it's not a simple confrontation between good and evil, but rather a showdown of cruelty, selfishness, and deceived ideals meant to ensure the survival of a few people - or to wipe out guilt -, even if it leads to the death of dozens of - more or less - innocent people. There is no one truly good, not even civilians, and no one truly evil, not even soldiers, and there is thus no right choice to do : whatever you do, people will die, and you only can determine who - to some extent. Indeed, you'll end up doing things totally against common sense, only because it's the only way to face the others, who are already doing crazy things : it's a shocking experience that to burn people with white phosphorus and watch them burn while speaking to a dying burnt man. The dialogues are, by the way, pretty interesting, and the characters' psychologies are really profound, as both of your two teammates will have a different position on what happened, what you've done and what to do next. The interesting part is that it's hard to tell who to follow, as no one seems to be wrong, and in the end, you'll be the main problem down there - but you won't realize it before the last few minutes.In the end, the story can be summed up as a descent into hell of a mad soldier caught in the spiral of violence and guilt, and the whole game leads the player through sceneries of despair and desolation, all along a depressing story tainted with blood. But if that game is a masterpiece, it's also thanks to the fact that the story is complex and insanely hard to get, as the main character is sliding into madness - which is also hard to get to which degree until the very last moments. Thus, this game isn't suitable for everyone, as it requires to be able to use their brain while playing, so as to make choices as well as to try to understand the story so far: you simply can't play just to shoot. That game is a proof that videogame is art.P.S. : Somehow, the game made me remember of Prayer of the Refugee, by Rise Against. Just check the lyrics :p

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Spec Ops is an interesting game. It's a Third-Person Shooter with a story that is designed to make you think about your decisions. My problem with the game is that the major decisions are out of your control. You have no say what-so-ever in the outcomes of them. The few decisions that you are given are minor and ultimately have no effect on which of the 4 endings of the game you will receive. The endings are based on which of the 4 options you choose at the very end of the game. I have a hard time feeling bad for a decision that the game chose. The "obvious" answer to some who say you do have a choice is to just not play the game. That is a poor answer to me. You would not experience the rest of the story or the game unless you watched it on YouTube, or had someone tell you what happens. The actual combat in the game is typical TPS or FPS run-and-gun. I would recommend playing on Easy if you do decide to play the game. You do not lose or gain anything other than achievements by picking this option. I would play the game for the story and not the gameplay.All in all, it is an interesting game, but I would never say that I had fun playing it. Get it if you are just absolutely interesting in playing. I would recommend waiting for it to be on sale for $5 or around that area, for the 5-6.5 hours that it lasts.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												This was a surprisingly engaging game. It looks generic, but Nolan North's voice acting is a nice touch and the story is a change from other military shooters. It's not original by any means, but the characters are interesting enough to play this one until the end. It takes about 8 hours to complete, and the game is well optimized so high frame rates can be achieved if V-Sync is turned off. The graphics are amazing, as well as the audio. The gameplay is a standard third person cover game, but it works perfectly so that's not necessarily a bad thing. Ammo is scarce at times, so you'll find yourself picking up enemy weapons a lot in order to have a functional weapon. I'd recommend buying this game, it's not a Call of Duty ripoff - but instead more character focused... a story based around the effects of war and the hard choices that are made. What is right and what is wrong?

Posted: May 18, 2013
												If you play games just for fun then this game isn't for you. On the other hand if you enjoy a good story and game experience you will have a great time with Spec Ops: The Line but, BEWARE, THIS GAME IS ALOT GRIM! I beated this game in about 5 hours, more or less, and I have to say that I did get bored sometimes with the gameplay. It is in it's own a pretty basic run n' cover  third person shooter with squad commands, there's plenty of these out there. But where the game really shines is in the story. This game, despite it's short length, was easily one of the best 5 hours I spent playing a video game. I have to thank Yager Development for making one of the best, most engaging, stories in recent years along with probably amongst the best character development and character design I've ever seen in a video game.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
Product received for free
												It's a worthwhile product. Long story short, play it on easy difficulty and just for the story. The gameplay is used cleverly sometimes in unconventional ways.Not a masterpiece, some narrative twists are done for better drama effect even in Max Payne from 2001 by action game standards. Nothing more and nothing less than a good war drama set up in juxtaposition against "conventional" patriotic action ones. An allure towards the nihilistic unfortunately, as it only questions and doubts without introducing anything new.It's a recycling of previous notable works as "Apocalypse Now".The problem of the game is that the gameplay messes with the "no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t" approach to traumatized human feelings. The attempt to sarcasm Saving Private Ryan and other action war products of American culture is in conflict with the serious message on the topic of war. Breaking the 4'th wall is far too often used with questionable end result or in any cohesive message delivered.It's awesome to have Spec Ops attempt a new approach. I'm optimistically looking to the future of this message progress further. As a media, video games need more of this. However without trying to use inappropriate tools to convey those messages through achievements, hero puns. I wasn't searching for action in the first place. Did not think it was amusing or well placed.It would also be interesting to hear arguments pro war too. Or how consistent the message was in general, without deconstructions in post modernist style. Again, a lot of weak points in the general anti war message with wide generalisation.--------------------------------------------------------------------------Recommended for familiarisation.  A most thorough analysis was made almost instantly after release but the dedicated team at Extra Credits which can be found here: 


YouTube™ Video: Spec Ops: The Line - I: How to Restart a Franchise - Extra Credits 

			Views: 346,865		

			Spec Ops: The Line questions the very nature of modern military shooters. It completely exceeded our expectations, so let's take a spoiler free look at how - and why.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Spec Ops: the Line is far from great. The timing of its release was great, though, and did a lot to cement its relevance. I mean, when COD and its clones dominated the market, they were just itching to be brought down a few notches. And this game definitely chipped away at their image.Spec Ops is a re-imaginging of Heart of Darkness, a novella by Joseph Conrad. It's central premise is that man, for all of his ability to do great things, is capable of terrible evil, no matter how advanced or civilized he or his contemporaries may consider himself. Spec Ops captures this beautifully by having you commit atrocities as you traverse soaring skyscrapers.But the gameplay is bad, and the game itself is a slog. Heart of Darkness was a well written book, and the movie it inspired, Apocalypse Now, was well filmed. They were both technical and artistic achievements, the finest forms of their media. This game is just an emotional achievement that falls short of its predecessors. When people forget about jingoistic FPSes this game will lose relevance because it completely relies on it its story, little else, and that story has been told in better ways. And I guarentee a better game will come out, with just as good timing and similar themes. I still recommend it, but it's really not that well done; it's simply a well-timed reminder of the horror people are capable of.

Posted: November 6, 2014
												Part of me wants to make a humorous review like "10/10 Would be a hero again!" but in all honesty, I think this "average" shooter deserves better. And it is an average shooter, there is no denying that. I died quite a few times because of the occasionally wonky cover mechanics. The thing about this game that I think everyone should experience, is the story.What a story it is! I shall not spoil anything but it is pretty mundane for the first bit and even an early big shocker isn't super impactful (in my opinion). But the ending! Oh the ending! You can't just watch it on youtube, it's something that will only have any impact on someone who has actually played through the whole thing. There were a few intense choices at the end and I'm actually amazed at one of the choices the developers allowed the players to have.There will be no sequel to this game (it doesn't need one), but I hope the writers/developers go on to make more things that make me think while simultaneously ♥♥♥♥ing with my head.[Note: I don't think this is a $30 game but I'd say it's more than worth it when it goes on sale for ten or less.]

Spec Ops: The Line is an ugly, daring, and profound twisted war video game that doesn't hesitate to shock you.What appeared to be a simple story of three teammates sent on a mission to protect civilians against hostile foes immediately turned into a deadly nightmare of survival and siege. Throughout my experience, I couldn't relax myself because the game wouldn't allow me to unless I purposely quit on my own behalf as it ironically suggested so. Upon entering the cinematic sequences I felt immersed, shamelessly filthy, and broodingly satisfied. Aside from certain uncontrollable outcomes and deeply questionable aspects that felt utterly bizarre, I remained entertained and eager for more answers as the main protagonist.I entered this game with an open mind and exited with a broken psyche - and It was worth it.

content:
Posted: February 27
												Spec Ops: The Line is an intruiging story built on a foundation of the portrayal of the terrors of war. This is all wrapped around a robust third person shooter. The gameplay and mechanics are nothing to phone home about, but their framing of a provocative cruelty-of-war setting along with a roller-coaster of a personal story keeps the game interesting. The game is short, and outside of replaying the game to experience the story after gaining the perspective from completing the first time, or minor collectables, won't bring you back much replayability. This isn't helped by the lack of a multiplayer community.That being said, replayability is not this game's focus. Spec Ops: The Line will take you on a ride through the terrible and seemingly impossible choices in the moment of war and make you reflect on the choices for the future. Definitely a recommend if you're looking for a low-key enigmatic third person shooter.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												It's a relatively short game. You can finish it pretty quickly. It's a beautiful game. The graphics are excellent, especially the environmental effects. It's got some good squad-support mechanics, a bit of RTS mixed in when it comes to combat.Where it really stands out is the story. This is no CoD shoot-em-up against the russian/korean/middle eastern/chinese terrorists who pose a threat to MURRICA and the good guys have to go blast 'em with MUH FREEDOMS until they're all dead and a soaring bald eagle screams overhead just before the credits.No, this game takes a much more realistic approach with a small squad in unfamiliar territory as you watch the effects of combat and decision-making on their mental state and relationships.Of course, it's a game, so it is a dramatization. But it's an excellent game. Your choices have an effect. It wasn't made so you could choke on McDonald's while singing the Star-Spangled Banner. It was made to show that on the inside, there is no glory in war.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												Very few games have made me feel like Spec Ops: The Line has. To me, it seems like an abundant number of shooters are growing increasingly generic. Producing gore for gore’s sake, and scarcely ever using mature or violent content to actually make you feel for a character. Spec Ops: The Line is the embodiment of evidence that not all games adhere to this philosophy. Sadly, the game is also highly overlooked. Many people have, despite its obvious superiority to popular shooters, never been aware of its existence. The story is well written and quite riveting. Spec Ops: The Line places you in inconceivable situations, and imposes morbidity regardless of choices you make. For example, if you were given an option to save either a close friend or a hundred innocent people, you will feel equally awful no matter what you choose. While this might refrain from appearing unprecedented, Spec Ops: The Line does so in a believable setting with well-built characters, conveying emotional and vivid events. I thoroughly enjoyed the graphics. The yellow sands contrast well with the blue and purple hues used throughout. Many scenes are beautiful, the conjunction of ruined city and serene sand paints a stunning landscape. Spec Ops: The Line’s port (the game originally debuted on the Xbox 360) is adequate, most elements perform perfectly, however there are a few things that were not implemented well. Apart from minor issues, the game looks and plays fine on the PC.Unfortunately, Spec Ops: The Line does not innovate further. The gameplay mechanics are similar to an average third-person shooter. Acoustics are acceptable, but far from memorable. I felt that even slight enhancements on these elements would significantly improve upon the overall experience. Nevertheless, it is still enjoyable to play. Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who is seeking a shooter with a fantastic story. To me, a good story is always imperative - this one supersedes many others of the genre. Spec Ops: The Line is usually on sale during special events. That being said, I think it is completely worth it at full price, especially considering the quality that rivals many full-priced games.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line is a hidden gem in the shooter genre. In the wake of other AAA titles like the Call of Duty, Battlefield, Gears of War, Just Cause, Resident Evil and countless other shooter based franchises, Spec Ops: The Line truly captures the essence of great gaming that is usually missed by other tripple A titles. A heart felt story with likable characters who go from clean-cut delta operators to rugged murderers with heavy conciouses. The story is truly beautiful with severeal different endings all of which prove to give the feeling of sorrow as you see how far Capitan Walker has fallen into darkness. Stellar voice acting that progresses as you move through the campaign and reacts to situations. Spec Ops: The Line take away the romanticised views of war that most war games have and open the player's eyes that in war you're going to make choices between outcomes that are wrong and wronger, there is no right in war. With beautiful writing and an action pack campaign Spec Ops delivers 110%.Some people complain that many of the choices you make don't have too much effect on the story but personally i belive the devs made it this way to show that in times of crisis a lot of the decisions you make are insignificant because in the end everyone dies in a blaze of glory and only the lucky can make it out alive and even then, they leave part of themselves behind.The only things I can find wrong with the game are the♥♥♥♥♥♥multiplayer (so close to having the perfect game but sorry), and slightly wonky controls, however you get used to judging distance before hitting certian buttons (example: accidentally meleeing a car instead of going into cover because you were too far away when you hit the cover/melee key)Don't get me wrong, the game doesn't bring anything new to the shooter genre, some could even say it starts off as a generic shooter game but, it quickly shows that it did so deliberatly in order to show the true horrors of war. What it does is use everything the shooter genre does right and fix the one thing it does wrong: leave out the results of your actions and the true horrors of war.I would highly recommend this game to all fans of the shooter genre and those who are casual players of shooter games because this game is truly an experience that everyone need to experience once in their life.Singleplayer story: 11/10 absolutely perfectControls: 9.5/10 difficult at first with slightly unconventional key bindings but the game eases you in and you can quickly master the controlsMultiplayer: 6/10 rushed, nothing special, kinda♥♥♥♥♥♥ nobody plays the multiplayer anymore though so don't even worry about it. It has co-op though! But that is its only saving grace.Overall i'd give it a 10/10, its flaws are so insignificant that they are overshadowed by everything the game does right, get this game ASAP, you won't regret it.Do you feel like a hero yet Walker?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												There is a scene about an hour into Spec Ops: The Line, generally the one people who have already played the game will recognise as the "game changer" scene, that forces you to walk through a landscape of smouldering, writhing soldiers. Some beg for help, others just quietly choke on their own oozing fluids. And its around about this time that the average player will have an epiphany. "It takes a real cold hearted psycho of unimaginable cruelty to do something like this," they will think.Of course, the fact it was THE PLAYER that did it is exactly what makes this game unique. (THE PLAYER, an American soldier, NOT a Saturday morning cartoon villain who twirls his moustache, cackling gleefully as he kicks puppies and heils the swastika, or shouts "JIHAD!", or whatever is most fitting these days.) You see, Spec Ops: The Line is the anti-Call of Duty. And it doesn't so much deconstruct the Call of Duty games as it does strip them down to their bare reality, shove them right up the player's♥♥♥♥♥ and ask: "Just how cool do you think war is now?" The above mentioned scene in Spec Ops: The Line very obviously mimics a scene from CoD, involving bombing soldiers from an airborne drone. At least, it mimics the bombing people part. The moments after, where you witness the results of the bombing, are very specifically added. And this is the purpose of the game.Many will have noticed that in the Call of Duty series the focus of the games are entirely on the fast paced, pulse pounding, fifty-soldier-a-second-murder-rate action part of war, and never once do the games force you to witness the consequences of your actions. (Except for that "Crawling through the city nuke scene," but really, that was many years ago, and the tones of the games have changed drastically since then.) Spec Ops: The Line is happy to give you the pulse pounding action, and it even does so with similar over the top spectacle as can be found in the CoD series, but it never strays far from making you stare the horrific results of those actions square in the face. Likewise, the characters in Spec Ops: The Line grow ever more twisted, tortured and insane, clearly reflecting the reality of the horror around them. The player, be he or she a person of reasonable intelligence and not a sexually frustrated teenager, (you know who you are,) should hate themselves by the end of the game, not feel like a hero."This game doesn't sound like much fun," I hear you say, "What about the actual game part of the game?"Fair enough. Lets talk gameplay.  In terms of gameplay, I must be honest, Spec Ops: The Line isn't a perfect, and certainly isn't much to write home about. Its a reasonable third person shooter with functonal cover mechancis, reflecting Gears of War more than CoD, in point of fact. Even these basic mechanics, however, are a bit flimsy at times. On curved walls it seems a bit ambigous as to whether Walker, the protagonist character, will shift up the wall upon you moving the thumbstick to the right, or leap up out of cover like a man doing an interprative dance of a meerkat on the lookout for predators. These instances are rare, however, and the gameplay is for the most part fast paced, epic, and enjoyable. The gameplay really is, however, just a means to drive the wheels of the story forward.Lastly I would like to add that Spec Ops: The Line is also hands down the most breathtakingly beautiful game I have ever played. The sheer amount effort that must have gone into making the enviroments, that turn a war-torn Dubai into an artistic masterpiece, more then makes up for the average gamelplay, and then some. This game, a shooter that has you blowing off heads, simultaneously makes love to your eyes with an absolutely stunning gallery of gorgeous level designs. There is another scene I'd like to mention now, before ending this already overly long review, where you and your soldiers drop down into a cave, the floor of which is a carpet of hundreds of lit candles. And, as you and your soldiers walk over these candles, your clumping boots extinguishing the little pinpoints of light, leaving paths of darkness in your collective wakes. This visual metaphor of these soldiers and their purpose, (soldiers snuff out lives beneath their mighty tread and leave darkness behind them, for those sexually frustrated teenagers who didn't get it,) created in such am original and strikingly beautiful way, is why Spec Ops: The Line is one of my personal favourite games. This massively overlooked game, indeed not perfect by any means, was a risky project of passion by a group of developers I feel should have got more recognition for it. I commend those developers, and very much recommend the game to anyone who has the right mindset to appreciate it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28
												Amidst the awkward controls, the dated 2012 graphics (even for their time), and the mostly run of the mill 3rd person cover-to-cover shooter, lies a gem of a game, mostly due it's superb storyline and unique narrative. Spec Ops: The Line starts off a bit slow but once you picked up on the pace of the game, it quickly turns into a very entertaining and thought provoking experience.I'm gonna start reviewing the game from a gameplay and technical point of view. The 2012 release looks barely OK in 2017. It's not horrendous and I'll admit certain parts of the game look really good for their time, but even 5 years ago there were prettier things. The gameplay is your typical 3rd person action cover-to-cover shooter. Nothing you haven't played before, nothing revolutionary, just OK. You're in control of your character and two squad mates who you can order to help you to take down the enemy and provide covering fire. They can use flashbangs and revive each other but that's just about it. You can carry only 2 weapons, from a variety of assault rifles, submachineguns, snipers, shotguns, pistols and heavy weaponry. You can also have up to 3 different types of grenades. Ammo is not as generous as you might expect and truth be told that adds a little bit of difficulty and immersion to the game but overall there's not gonna be an issue. The controls are little bit awkward and for me it was a sore spot for the overall enjoyment of the game. Running from cover-to-cover is weird and you might die as a result of poor mechanics since sprinting and taking cover is the same button. Really poor design choice but again, nothing too serious.There's not really many types of enemies. Soldiers, snipers and heavies, very little mechanised combat with turrets/vehicles but I'd be a liar if I didn't say it wasn't fun. Not the best fun you've ever had but enough for you to push on through the campaign. I have to be honest here and say that there's really not much else to talk about the gameplay. It is as generic as it comes, I can understand people liking or not but for me it was as uninspired as it comes. The maps and level design were interesting at times and the environment of Dubai looked pretty nice for most of it's part. But the game is not about the way you shoot and kill and people, but rather the who, what, why.Spec Ops: The Line storyline remind me of the first Black Ops game. Kind of weird how both have the word Ops in their title right? I don't want to spoil too much of the story but I will try to provide context for the game. You're in control of Captain Martin Walker and his two squadmates, First Lieutenant Alphanso Adams and and Staff Sergeant John Lugo, part of the elite Delta Force, send to Dubai during one of the worst dust storm season the region has ever seen where The Damned 33rd Battalion of the U.S. Army is stranded after returning from Afghanistan. The 33rd is trying to help to evacuate the civilians out of the city but upon your arrival you notice that something else might be going on. The premise piqued my interest and the way the story unfolded over the course of the game had me at the edge of my seat. I wish I could divulge more information but sadly that would take away from the story. Naturally, the game's been out for over 5 years so really spoiler warnings might be unnecessary for some but if you're one of the lucky few who haven't experienced this yet, I feel it would be a shame if you didn't do so first hand.The game explores a variety of themes directly from the nature of warfare. If there's an anti-war game, I guess Spec Ops: The Line would be it. Nowadays you can rightly claim that some of the tropes and themes of the story have been explored before in other visual and interactive mediums, but the game has a great narrative supported by brilliant dialogue and an otherwise excellent soundtrack, with polarizing characters who you will meet. You have choices in the matter too; it's not RPG level type of divergence, but certain actions in the game will have lead to different outcomes.I have to add that I would love to see this game made into a movie or a miniseries even. If I could imagine Three Kings with a note of Apocalypse Now, this would be it. The game has attracted a variety of theories regarding the meaning of its story, the characters and I think that is a sign of pretty good storytelling.Spec Ops: The Line is not long, ~6 hours, but it's guaranteed to provoke some interesting feelings and thoughts upon completion. It's not the most difficult of games but there a few challenging situations especially on higher difficulties. I definitely recommend this game for everyone who enjoys action games and people who want a decent story and rich characters in their games as well. Do not be deterred by the mediocrity of its gameplay cause underneath all that game lies a great storyline and the feeling of completing the game will make you wonder about all that you experienced.

												This game came out of nowhere. Anounced at an E3 before Czar Russia, from the start it looked like a generic military shooter. And it maintains the illusion for about two hours of gameplay untill it punches you in the gut, grabs you by the hair and smacks your face into the mirror, say: look at yourself, are you happy now? is this what you wanted? Is this what you like? Decent graphics, great animation, average gameplay, incredible narrative. Deeply story-driven and demands attention. Also has one of the best examples of how to do moral choices right. 10/10

content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												Very few games have made me feel like Spec Ops: The Line has. To me, it seems like an abundant number of shooters are growing increasingly generic. Producing gore for gore’s sake, and scarcely ever using mature or violent content to actually make you feel for a character. Spec Ops: The Line is the embodiment of evidence that not all games adhere to this philosophy. Sadly, the game is also highly overlooked. Many people have, despite its obvious superiority to popular shooters, never been aware of its existence. The story is well written and quite riveting. Spec Ops: The Line places you in inconceivable situations, and imposes morbidity regardless of choices you make. For example, if you were given an option to save either a close friend or a hundred innocent people, you will feel equally awful no matter what you choose. While this might refrain from appearing unprecedented, Spec Ops: The Line does so in a believable setting with well-built characters, conveying emotional and vivid events. I thoroughly enjoyed the graphics. The yellow sands contrast well with the blue and purple hues used throughout. Many scenes are beautiful, the conjunction of ruined city and serene sand paints a stunning landscape. Spec Ops: The Line’s port (the game originally debuted on the Xbox 360) is adequate, most elements perform perfectly, however there are a few things that were not implemented well. Apart from minor issues, the game looks and plays fine on the PC.Unfortunately, Spec Ops: The Line does not innovate further. The gameplay mechanics are similar to an average third-person shooter. Acoustics are acceptable, but far from memorable. I felt that even slight enhancements on these elements would significantly improve upon the overall experience. Nevertheless, it is still enjoyable to play. Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who is seeking a shooter with a fantastic story. To me, a good story is always imperative - this one supersedes many others of the genre. Spec Ops: The Line is usually on sale during special events. That being said, I think it is completely worth it at full price, especially considering the quality that rivals many full-priced games.

content:
Posted: March 28
												Amidst the awkward controls, the dated 2012 graphics (even for their time), and the mostly run of the mill 3rd person cover-to-cover shooter, lies a gem of a game, mostly due it's superb storyline and unique narrative. Spec Ops: The Line starts off a bit slow but once you picked up on the pace of the game, it quickly turns into a very entertaining and thought provoking experience.I'm gonna start reviewing the game from a gameplay and technical point of view. The 2012 release looks barely OK in 2017. It's not horrendous and I'll admit certain parts of the game look really good for their time, but even 5 years ago there were prettier things. The gameplay is your typical 3rd person action cover-to-cover shooter. Nothing you haven't played before, nothing revolutionary, just OK. You're in control of your character and two squad mates who you can order to help you to take down the enemy and provide covering fire. They can use flashbangs and revive each other but that's just about it. You can carry only 2 weapons, from a variety of assault rifles, submachineguns, snipers, shotguns, pistols and heavy weaponry. You can also have up to 3 different types of grenades. Ammo is not as generous as you might expect and truth be told that adds a little bit of difficulty and immersion to the game but overall there's not gonna be an issue. The controls are little bit awkward and for me it was a sore spot for the overall enjoyment of the game. Running from cover-to-cover is weird and you might die as a result of poor mechanics since sprinting and taking cover is the same button. Really poor design choice but again, nothing too serious.There's not really many types of enemies. Soldiers, snipers and heavies, very little mechanised combat with turrets/vehicles but I'd be a liar if I didn't say it wasn't fun. Not the best fun you've ever had but enough for you to push on through the campaign. I have to be honest here and say that there's really not much else to talk about the gameplay. It is as generic as it comes, I can understand people liking or not but for me it was as uninspired as it comes. The maps and level design were interesting at times and the environment of Dubai looked pretty nice for most of it's part. But the game is not about the way you shoot and kill and people, but rather the who, what, why.Spec Ops: The Line storyline remind me of the first Black Ops game. Kind of weird how both have the word Ops in their title right? I don't want to spoil too much of the story but I will try to provide context for the game. You're in control of Captain Martin Walker and his two squadmates, First Lieutenant Alphanso Adams and and Staff Sergeant John Lugo, part of the elite Delta Force, send to Dubai during one of the worst dust storm season the region has ever seen where The Damned 33rd Battalion of the U.S. Army is stranded after returning from Afghanistan. The 33rd is trying to help to evacuate the civilians out of the city but upon your arrival you notice that something else might be going on. The premise piqued my interest and the way the story unfolded over the course of the game had me at the edge of my seat. I wish I could divulge more information but sadly that would take away from the story. Naturally, the game's been out for over 5 years so really spoiler warnings might be unnecessary for some but if you're one of the lucky few who haven't experienced this yet, I feel it would be a shame if you didn't do so first hand.The game explores a variety of themes directly from the nature of warfare. If there's an anti-war game, I guess Spec Ops: The Line would be it. Nowadays you can rightly claim that some of the tropes and themes of the story have been explored before in other visual and interactive mediums, but the game has a great narrative supported by brilliant dialogue and an otherwise excellent soundtrack, with polarizing characters who you will meet. You have choices in the matter too; it's not RPG level type of divergence, but certain actions in the game will have lead to different outcomes.I have to add that I would love to see this game made into a movie or a miniseries even. If I could imagine Three Kings with a note of Apocalypse Now, this would be it. The game has attracted a variety of theories regarding the meaning of its story, the characters and I think that is a sign of pretty good storytelling.Spec Ops: The Line is not long, ~6 hours, but it's guaranteed to provoke some interesting feelings and thoughts upon completion. It's not the most difficult of games but there a few challenging situations especially on higher difficulties. I definitely recommend this game for everyone who enjoys action games and people who want a decent story and rich characters in their games as well. Do not be deterred by the mediocrity of its gameplay cause underneath all that game lies a great storyline and the feeling of completing the game will make you wonder about all that you experienced.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												There is a scene about an hour into Spec Ops: The Line, generally the one people who have already played the game will recognise as the "game changer" scene, that forces you to walk through a landscape of smouldering, writhing soldiers. Some beg for help, others just quietly choke on their own oozing fluids. And its around about this time that the average player will have an epiphany. "It takes a real cold hearted psycho of unimaginable cruelty to do something like this," they will think.Of course, the fact it was THE PLAYER that did it is exactly what makes this game unique. (THE PLAYER, an American soldier, NOT a Saturday morning cartoon villain who twirls his moustache, cackling gleefully as he kicks puppies and heils the swastika, or shouts "JIHAD!", or whatever is most fitting these days.) You see, Spec Ops: The Line is the anti-Call of Duty. And it doesn't so much deconstruct the Call of Duty games as it does strip them down to their bare reality, shove them right up the player's♥♥♥♥♥ and ask: "Just how cool do you think war is now?" The above mentioned scene in Spec Ops: The Line very obviously mimics a scene from CoD, involving bombing soldiers from an airborne drone. At least, it mimics the bombing people part. The moments after, where you witness the results of the bombing, are very specifically added. And this is the purpose of the game.Many will have noticed that in the Call of Duty series the focus of the games are entirely on the fast paced, pulse pounding, fifty-soldier-a-second-murder-rate action part of war, and never once do the games force you to witness the consequences of your actions. (Except for that "Crawling through the city nuke scene," but really, that was many years ago, and the tones of the games have changed drastically since then.) Spec Ops: The Line is happy to give you the pulse pounding action, and it even does so with similar over the top spectacle as can be found in the CoD series, but it never strays far from making you stare the horrific results of those actions square in the face. Likewise, the characters in Spec Ops: The Line grow ever more twisted, tortured and insane, clearly reflecting the reality of the horror around them. The player, be he or she a person of reasonable intelligence and not a sexually frustrated teenager, (you know who you are,) should hate themselves by the end of the game, not feel like a hero."This game doesn't sound like much fun," I hear you say, "What about the actual game part of the game?"Fair enough. Lets talk gameplay.  In terms of gameplay, I must be honest, Spec Ops: The Line isn't a perfect, and certainly isn't much to write home about. Its a reasonable third person shooter with functonal cover mechancis, reflecting Gears of War more than CoD, in point of fact. Even these basic mechanics, however, are a bit flimsy at times. On curved walls it seems a bit ambigous as to whether Walker, the protagonist character, will shift up the wall upon you moving the thumbstick to the right, or leap up out of cover like a man doing an interprative dance of a meerkat on the lookout for predators. These instances are rare, however, and the gameplay is for the most part fast paced, epic, and enjoyable. The gameplay really is, however, just a means to drive the wheels of the story forward.Lastly I would like to add that Spec Ops: The Line is also hands down the most breathtakingly beautiful game I have ever played. The sheer amount effort that must have gone into making the enviroments, that turn a war-torn Dubai into an artistic masterpiece, more then makes up for the average gamelplay, and then some. This game, a shooter that has you blowing off heads, simultaneously makes love to your eyes with an absolutely stunning gallery of gorgeous level designs. There is another scene I'd like to mention now, before ending this already overly long review, where you and your soldiers drop down into a cave, the floor of which is a carpet of hundreds of lit candles. And, as you and your soldiers walk over these candles, your clumping boots extinguishing the little pinpoints of light, leaving paths of darkness in your collective wakes. This visual metaphor of these soldiers and their purpose, (soldiers snuff out lives beneath their mighty tread and leave darkness behind them, for those sexually frustrated teenagers who didn't get it,) created in such am original and strikingly beautiful way, is why Spec Ops: The Line is one of my personal favourite games. This massively overlooked game, indeed not perfect by any means, was a risky project of passion by a group of developers I feel should have got more recognition for it. I commend those developers, and very much recommend the game to anyone who has the right mindset to appreciate it.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
Spec Ops: The Line is an ugly, daring, and profound twisted war video game that doesn't hesitate to shock you.What appeared to be a simple story of three teammates sent on a mission to protect civilians against hostile foes immediately turned into a deadly nightmare of survival and siege. Throughout my experience, I couldn't relax myself because the game wouldn't allow me to unless I purposely quit on my own behalf as it ironically suggested so. Upon entering the cinematic sequences I felt immersed, shamelessly filthy, and broodingly satisfied. Aside from certain uncontrollable outcomes and deeply questionable aspects that felt utterly bizarre, I remained entertained and eager for more answers as the main protagonist.I entered this game with an open mind and exited with a broken psyche - and It was worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line is a hidden gem in the shooter genre. In the wake of other AAA titles like the Call of Duty, Battlefield, Gears of War, Just Cause, Resident Evil and countless other shooter based franchises, Spec Ops: The Line truly captures the essence of great gaming that is usually missed by other tripple A titles. A heart felt story with likable characters who go from clean-cut delta operators to rugged murderers with heavy conciouses. The story is truly beautiful with severeal different endings all of which prove to give the feeling of sorrow as you see how far Capitan Walker has fallen into darkness. Stellar voice acting that progresses as you move through the campaign and reacts to situations. Spec Ops: The Line take away the romanticised views of war that most war games have and open the player's eyes that in war you're going to make choices between outcomes that are wrong and wronger, there is no right in war. With beautiful writing and an action pack campaign Spec Ops delivers 110%.Some people complain that many of the choices you make don't have too much effect on the story but personally i belive the devs made it this way to show that in times of crisis a lot of the decisions you make are insignificant because in the end everyone dies in a blaze of glory and only the lucky can make it out alive and even then, they leave part of themselves behind.The only things I can find wrong with the game are the♥♥♥♥♥♥multiplayer (so close to having the perfect game but sorry), and slightly wonky controls, however you get used to judging distance before hitting certian buttons (example: accidentally meleeing a car instead of going into cover because you were too far away when you hit the cover/melee key)Don't get me wrong, the game doesn't bring anything new to the shooter genre, some could even say it starts off as a generic shooter game but, it quickly shows that it did so deliberatly in order to show the true horrors of war. What it does is use everything the shooter genre does right and fix the one thing it does wrong: leave out the results of your actions and the true horrors of war.I would highly recommend this game to all fans of the shooter genre and those who are casual players of shooter games because this game is truly an experience that everyone need to experience once in their life.Singleplayer story: 11/10 absolutely perfectControls: 9.5/10 difficult at first with slightly unconventional key bindings but the game eases you in and you can quickly master the controlsMultiplayer: 6/10 rushed, nothing special, kinda♥♥♥♥♥♥ nobody plays the multiplayer anymore though so don't even worry about it. It has co-op though! But that is its only saving grace.Overall i'd give it a 10/10, its flaws are so insignificant that they are overshadowed by everything the game does right, get this game ASAP, you won't regret it.Do you feel like a hero yet Walker?

Posted: December 26, 2014
												Man where do you start, and where do you stop.This game actually made me feel, and its been a long time since a game has done that period.If you are a parent looking for a friendly game for your children, <>!!!Turn Back Now!!!<>DO NOT BUY THIS<><This is not a game suitable for kids, some teens, and even a few adults.>The gameplay was ok, but whats real is the story, best shooter story I've experienced in a while, and I hated it.I was able to justify most of my actions at first, and as the game went on I was even able to accept my choices, and press on, but near the end..... I hated what I had become, hated the situation, and even said I should have never come here, just called for help. Or maybe even died. Should I stop playing? Probably, Maybe. No gotta see this to the finish.Was worth playing, might play it again after I have time to contemplate the ending more, ask myself if thats all even possible.Does stuff like that really happen in reality? At what point did the main characters mind break, and cross the line? It happened early....... but where?

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												This was a surprisingly engaging game. It looks generic, but Nolan North's voice acting is a nice touch and the story is a change from other military shooters. It's not original by any means, but the characters are interesting enough to play this one until the end. It takes about 8 hours to complete, and the game is well optimized so high frame rates can be achieved if V-Sync is turned off. The graphics are amazing, as well as the audio. The gameplay is a standard third person cover game, but it works perfectly so that's not necessarily a bad thing. Ammo is scarce at times, so you'll find yourself picking up enemy weapons a lot in order to have a functional weapon. I'd recommend buying this game, it's not a Call of Duty ripoff - but instead more character focused... a story based around the effects of war and the hard choices that are made. What is right and what is wrong?

The games takes about 6 hours to complete and you will want to play the game twice to see how the story elements unfold by your decisions. I enjoyed the game so much I beat it 3 times up to the highest difficulty (FUBAR) and got all 50 achievements!

content:
Posted: January 3, 2013
												When I first heard of this game I ignored it out of principle...why? Simple. Because war shooters tend to suck. Not saying they all do, but in my eyes its sub-genre that has more generic shooters than others sub-genres. Each year new Call of Duty with minimalistic changes, yet another failed attempt to reboot Medal of Honor series...its a mess.From my friends I heard great things about this game so I decided to pick it up and oh boy was I surprised. Fitting soundtrack, easy to use yet engaging squad command system and one thing I have been lacking lately...engaging game-play. If I were to go into graphics, which I really don't like to do because when looking at games graphics are on last place for me, BUT if I would, I would say they are beautiful.Now you might think "fine, good shooter so what?". I will tell you "so what". This game it does something games don't tend to do so much. It tries to attack your emotions. Mind you, I most often play all sorts of games as an maniac, trying to steal everything, shoot everything, then loot the thing I shot, and then shoot it again. But this game actually made me think. And not in a good way, in an depressing way. It made me actually care about events of the game. It made me fear the monstrosities that are happening.I am playing the game on second hardest difficulty out of four (fourth is available only after you finish the game on second hardest one), so logically I was sneaking around to not get shot in my beautiful coconut. And how I was sneaking I heard 2 soldiers talking (to not glorify the game too much, I didn't hear much dialogue between NPCs in this game). They were talking about how its actually beautiful in Dubai, when they have little peace from all the war that is going on, and how the melody of the wind remind one of the soldiers of his home. Of course then I threw an grenade and they were flying with their beautiful wind...but it got me thinking again. I had to kill them, I couldn't continue without it. And I guess that is main beauty of the game it makes you think.tl;dr : Buy it, play it, finish it, and if you want proceed to weep after that.

Posted: January 23, 2015
												Renewed my fading faith In gamingThis game, like many others has sat in my library for..... probably about a year or maybe more. I purchased via a humble bundle and never gave it much thought. It seemed like a simple older consol game that'd be a meh at best. *insert "never have I been so wrong" meme here* It was one of the more gratifying gaming experiences I have had before. It was one of those story lines that really pulled me along. I played for about 6.5 hours straight and that is fairly rare for me. It is powerful and well constructed. Everything feels deliberate and not without a review board. This game is what I had been looking for, as I have grown extremely bored with these lackluster attempts at game construction lately. Triple A be damned. I don't do these reviews often. But this game truly deserves your attention. A review, especially this one will not do it justice. Just give it an hour and you'll see.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												This was actually a very surpising game. I really did not think I would have liked it as much as I did since I am not a huge fan of modern military shooters. The main reason why I tried it was because I kept hearing great things about the way the narrative was handled and I was not let down. It does not glorify war or the military and it actually felt like the developers put a lot of time into developing the story. In this game, story came first, and the multiplayer aspect came second, and that is something that is a bit rare in shooters nowadays. So without further ado,  here's my review. Gameplay  The game is a third person shooter and has all the stuff that is considered standard in third person shooters nowadays: cover system, grenade projectory, blind shooting, etc. In terms of shooting, the game really brings nothing new to the table. It is all pretty standard shooting and the enemies provide a decent enough challenge. The player does have a squad that they can order around, but it pretty much boils down to the player telling them to just focus on a specific target or throw the occasional flashbang. A fun little mechanic, but nothing that is very innovative for the genre.At times the controls can be a bit clunky and I have died a few times because my character got stuck in cover, but it doesn't detract that much from the main game. Since the shooting is a bit standard and the controls are a bit clunky, the multiplayer really is not that great, so if that's what you're looking for, don't get this game. In terms of gameplay, it really isn't anything revolutionary. Story This is where the game really shines, and people who have played the game would probably tend to agree with me. It actually does a great job at providing a mystery for the player to figure out and the reveal is very well done.  The main idea of it is that sometimes it is not always clear what decision is the right one, especially in times of war. It shows a much different "war" than we are used to seeing in video games. One where not all the player's actions are not necessarilly the right or wrong choice. They are choices where, at the time, you thought for sure they were the right decision. (Or you thought for sure they were the wrong decision, if you're a bit sadistic.) The characters are actually pretty well developed too. I'll be honest, when I first started the game, I thought the characters were going to be the typical military charracter that we find in lots of media. You know the trope I am talking about, the "I aint got time to bleed" guys. I was pleasantly surprised to see that while the characters were tough, it wasn't their defining trait. The interactions they have after some of the situations they get into are quite believable and the player's squadmates have pretty distinct characteristics. When they disagree with the player, they let it be known. I like how the developers handled this in particular because in the beginning of the game when they disagree with the player, they just give you a certain look or something subtle. As the game progresses and the squad starts to see more and more horrible things, that subtle look of contempt turns into more obvious displays of their dissatisfaction. The strongest part of the story have to be both the main character (the player) and the villain. The trauma that a soldier experiences in times of war is depicted very well in the mental state of the main character. The way they depict how the main character starts to question the morality of his actions and why he is even fighting is just something that you don't typically see in games that are centered around the military. And that's really all I can safely say without completely spoiling anything.  TL;DR  Pros  - Great story- Great character development- Interesting environment- Some genuinely great music thanks to Radioman Cons - Standard gameplay for a shooter- Controls are a bit clunky- multiplayer is not the greatest.Overall, I believe this game is worth buying for the story alone.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												 Never in my life have I ever played a game that said "the only way to be the hero is to just not play". This game makes it very clear from the get-go. Are you a genocidal maniac? A sufferer of acute PTSD? Are you in purgatory reliving your sins until you find closer, in whatever form that may be? Or, are you the bad guy the whole time? This game never gives a clear cut answer, and although the story is linear, it is so full of story elements, I can't go into detail without spoiling the game. Buy it, but be ready to be mildly annoyed at the game ramming the whole "YOU DID THIS" sign in your face, which is the whole reason I bought the game.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2013
												This game surprised me in so many ways. My initial impression after completing the demo was a boring and generic third person cover based shooter with little that interested me. Now that I’ve sunk some hours into it, I can safely say my first impression was so wrong!Spec Ops: The Line is actually one of the most moving games I’ve ever played. The setting, the characters, the overall story and decisions, it all comes together to form such an unforgettable experience. Instead of mindless violence, the player sees the effect each enemy encounter has on the main characters. There’s a progression in the attitude of the characters towards both the enemies and each other. Few games manage to successfully pull this off without making it look outright cheesy.The sandy Dubai setting and unique back story make Spec Ops: The Line even more interesting. No more generic military desert country with “insurgents” and mud huts. Dubai really does feel like Dubai and the problems that exist there feel genuine and make you want to find out more. It’s safe to say that there are plenty of decent twists throughout the story line.The only problem I’ve noticed with Spec Ops is the gameplay which (although fun and addictive) could be improved upon. Enemies moving around and suddenly popping up from cover looks unnatural and the ballistic and particle effects look rubbish (when you shoot walls, fire your weapon). It’s still fun to use all the different weapons and basic squad tactics though. Seeing the look on the main character’s face as he gets shot at is priceless :DSpec Ops: The Line is one of the most surprising games I’ve ever played and I feel truly humbled to have found such a gem amongst a year of generic shooters that seriously lack story. The developers at Yager studios put their heart and soul into making The Line what it is and it shows (the same can’t be said for the absolutely terrible multiplayer, but that was made by another studio so who gives a ♥♥♥♥).
