content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												This game right here is freaking sick !!! amazing graphics, amazing story.The cover mechanic is ok, kinda like GEARS of WAR without the ridiculous health. i really wish their were more commands for your teammates apart from kill or heal, they get right in the line of fire and get down easy on higher difficulties. The enemy AI can be dumb sometimes, but make great use of cover use real military commands, swear alot and offer a good challenge on higher difficulties. the game's level are well designed i was expecting sand dunes all over the place, with a couple buildings or two, but instead got a semi-destructible environments such as shooting glass to drop sand on enemies, turrets mowing down certain covers.They did a fantastic job on the interiors; the glass, the carpet, plants, piano etc... everything had detail and time put into it. I like the background music alot, there is nothing like a shoot-out with classic rock in the background, it gets you pumped up(recommend putting the music on 10, sfx and voices on 7 amplifies does moments to a whole new level). The choices in this game are minor, but satisfying in a weird and evil way each worse than the other; like capping a guy with a magnum to prevent him the harsher death of being roasted alive might make you cringe, feel guilty and even put your controller away for a while ( or mouse, i like controllers better although admitting mouse & keyboard offers greater accuracy). I made every evil choice in this game and enjoyed it and in the end died like boss(felt like a true Sith lord), dying in the end  is optional this is not a Bioware game after all. Forget about that metascore of 76, this game is a 8.5/10 in my book and thats just because the storyline is kinda short and i never could find someone to play with on multiplayer, there are no multiplayer achievements so i did not worry about that. In the end none of these matters, it's just a vessel for a great story. No amount of buggy controls(extremely minor in this game), glitches (seems like i randomly could not take\switch cover )should keep you away from such a great storyline.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is one of the only games I would ever recommend putting on the lowest difficulty on the first playthrough.This is not a game you play for the amazing gameplay, although it's nothing worse than generic. I liked it. Different strokes for different folks.Were it to be judged purely on its design and mechanics, Spec Ops: The Line would be pretty forgettable, but it has an ace in the hole. And it's a bigg'un: a story so out of the blue in its direction and message that it's a miracle, a major publisher put this game out at all. What you think you're getting- particularly if you only play the demo- is another gung-ho gun-wielding slice of Americans saving the day by killing all the brown people. What you actually get is a slow, spiralling descent into madness of one man, that wears its Heart of Darkness/Apocalypse Now inspirations proudly and uses them to forge a modern-day commentary on the type of video game you thought you were going to play. Captain Walker is no tiantic Call of Duty avatar who can murder a thousand people and walk away- he falls apart mentally, visually and audibly as the game continues, his professionalism is stripped away and raw ego left exposed. "Tango down" becomes a more chilling, "Kill is ♥♥♥♥ing confirmed" as the game confronts you with issues of culpability and responsibility. It's incredibly unsettling and so out of the ordinary for the modern gamer that to most people, this might be thrown aside in disgust.This is no Gears Of War/Army Of Two clone. This is the story of one man who loses himself to the brutality of war.To the open minded and for someone who wants a great story mixed with an unsettling message, this is a MUST OWN.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2013
												Wow!  What an amazing, story-driven, combat game.  It was like watching a serious and brutally viscious war-gone-bad movie on acid.  The character voice-acting, imho, is the finest yet in all of gaming.  The music is top notch.  The weapons are real military weapons, and there's many.  The visuals are excellent.  The many diverse combat sequences are wild, intense, and sometimes challenging.  Some combat scenes and cutscenes are downright crazy, shocking, and memorable.  I think this is one of the best games ever made, and it's bound to be a classic.  I highly recommend it, but only if you can stomach brutal war images.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												At first sight when you never play this game to the very end; small levels with quite linear gameplay so a normal rail shooter by today’s standards, worth a look if you like the shooter genre (as you can tell I am not a fan of the genre)When you finish the game: The story just changed everything and makes you think the game is epic because of very unexpected changes.I really enjoyed this game because I hate your typical mainstream hero shooter game with 0 relation to the real horror of warfare. This game emerged me so much I played it from start to end in 1 day a rare thing for me. Your 2 AI companions are surprisingly smart, rarely had to save them from a stupid action + I can order them to focus on my target and I experienced 0 bugs. I only talk about single player but there seem to be a few co-op missions and multiplayer for which I (and most players) did not care.Graphically it was great, the choices and rare use of environment are appreciated but don't mean or change much. The story is the big plus for this game and was well executed. There are no good guys in this game only realistic humans. Wish there were more shooters like this but with more meaningful choices and bigger levels.At the discount I bought it, definitely recommend it. I never recommend shooters at full price they don’t last long enough and offer little replay ability in this case maybe once for a special difficulty, some collectables and the different endings.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Expecting a standard military TPS with some hamfisted morality message, I was instead treated to one of the greatest psychedelic war stories in recent memory.  The most I can say without spoiling anything is that Spec Ops: The Line calls to mind the 2nd half of Full Metal Jacket, Apocalypse Now, or the burning oil refinery scene in Jarhead.  It is a very well thought-out and self-aware commentary on the insanity of combat, culminating in an immensely satisfying and mindscrewing gauntlet.Mechanically the game is solid, although snapping in and out of cover is occasionally more awkward than it should be.  Ammunition is scarce even on the default difficulty, and nearly every encounter is designed in such a way that the tools for victory are always available if you have the right strategy.  I never felt like I was dying for any reason other than my own lack of skill.  Checkpoints are infrequent, so the sense of tension and reward when you clear a particularly difficult segment is tangible.  Compared to most other recent shooters this was a huge breath of fresh air.  Spec Ops respects your intelligence enough to assume you can figure out a way to shoot everybody in the room if you just put some thought into it.I bought and played this game on a whim (and because of a particular scene which you may have seen on Youtube involving incendiary weaponry).  If you've seen the same scene and felt the game was ruined/spoiled as a result, I assure you it's not.  That particular incident garnered a lot of publicity but only occurs about halfway into the game, with much more potent and interesting twists ahead of it.I still don't feel like a hero yet.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a 2012 third-person shooter video game developed by Yager Development and published by 2K Games. It was released on 26 June 2012 in North America and 29 June 2012 internationally for Microsoft Windows, and the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 consoles.n Spec Ops: The Line, the player controls Captain Martin Walker, who is sent into a post-catastrophe Dubai with an elite Delta Force team on a reconnaissance mission, where they find dead American soldiers. Upon the finding, Walker declares that the team's mission has changed, and that they will search Dubai for survivorsSpec Ops: does so many good things right, but falls short from a masterpiece. While the game is a brilliant set-piece of PTSD and the true horrors of war, it falls short as a game in whole. While the story, soundtrack, voice acting, visuals and overall quality is amazing, it's gameplay is just so generic and boring. Nothing new will be seen here, unfourtunately. The game is a third-person cover shooter game, with no originality. The cover system and gunplay are mediocre at best, and this is a real drawback from it being an amazing experience in all sectors. But, I really don't want to get too much into such details, it's just something you've played in a hundred other games, let's focus on what's so amazing about this underrated game.The story. It may sounds like something trivial, because people have high standards these days, amazing gameplay, amazing graphics, amazing this amazing that, you get my point. This game is narative driven game, and that's it. Multiplayer is shallow and unstatisfying, but this isn't the point of Spec Ops. It's a game that sets one goal, and one goal only. To trully showcase the Horror of war. War is a gruesome experience that really scars the human mind, and while me and you won't probably fight in one, this game has a trully shocking way of showing us just how brutal things can get between the gunfire. It will surely have a last impact on you, it did on me at least. The game starts pretty standard, a turret section that's pretty bland and boring, nothing too over the top here. But once the game kick off, things start to get heated. We start in the shoes of Cpt. Martin Walker, voiced by Nolan North. The game starts off with you and your squad mates being sent to the new destroyed Dubai, to investigate and search for survivor, call for reinforcements and get back home. Those are your only orders, nothing more. But things get out of hand once Walker gives to order to  open fire on the enemy. This thing will become more relevant down the line, since this game has set out to question one simple thing, Who is the enemy?. And it will teach you that thing, once you complete it.Being developed on the Unreal 3 Engine, the games shines mostly. Dubai is a super showcase of glowing sand, vibrant interiors and a feel of depth and complexity. But it's all just a shell to hide all of the horros that lay ahead of your journey to destruction. The game will soon present to you the brutal, and extremely graphic violence of when things get ouf of hand when people mentally breakdown and can't tell the difference between good or evil. It's amazing, especially since this game breaks once and for all the trope that all enemy's in video games must be shot down immediatly without question, and because they are different or russian/middle eastern. It's superb, to be honest. In the end, since I could talk about this game for hours and hours, even though it's a short, but it's an intense ride, and filled with guilt. Never, ever I have felt such guild after playing a videogame. Like, really. Videogames that make you feel guilty? How is that? One might ask. Well, it's quite easy. This game does not reward you for shooting everyone in a 100km radius at the speed of Clint Eastwood, it will break you down as fast as the protagonists. It's amazing how well the story is crafter, considering at the end of the day, it makes you feel human, it makes you question so many things. Superb. Honestly, superb. In case you don't want to hear all of my rumbling, I will list the things that I enjoyed and disliked about this game and give it a rating.The goodAmazing storySuperb storyBreathtaking visualsRetroactive enviromentUnique settingIncredible soundtrack/voice actingMoral and emotionally heavyThe badGeneric gameplayMediocre gunplayShort lenghtCookie cutter multiplayerNo replay valueThe cover mechanics are a bit awkwardI give this game a 8/10 rating, thanks to so many good elements in it, falling short, unfortunately to such a generic gameplay. Amazing overall nonetheless, I highly recommend this game to everyone.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												8,5/10Spec Ops The Line is an underrated game. If it was advertised like AAA titles it'd be one of best games of 2012.The story is good, giving choices and hcallanging (if played on highest difficulty). Some of moments that occur in the game are morally questionable. In real life they are considered war crime's. The game shows brutality of the war in small manner and complete lack of emotions from the oppressors.I recommend this game to everyone looking to have a great time in the game that is not casual! It can be completed within 7 hours.+ Interesting story with multiple choices at every occasion.+ Not boring with decent combat. Cover system reminds of Gears of War series.+Shows stuff that those pseudo-war games aka CoD and BF will never show.+ Not casual, it is easy to die.+ Low system requirements.+ Replayability value  (different choices throughout the game)+ Co-op+ Nice graphic quality...- ... textures could use higher resolution- too sensitive mouse controls, you need to set it to 1 ongame options at 2000DPi mouse to be playable- Linear story with choices. Yes, those choices are insignificant sometimes they are wrong.Neutral:Game lasts 6-7 hours.Out of all these advantages and disadvantages I recommend this game. Normally it costs 20€, it's good price but if you're saving money get it while on sale for 5€ ;) Regardless of which option you choose, it will be money well spent.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												A brutal storyline that shows how dark and sadistic human nature can be if that separates survival from death, or just greed and comfort from sharing. Paired up with a relatively short but compared to today's standards completely normal playtime and the well known generic TPS gameplay, it's a masterpiece where you won't even notice that the gameplay feels like the 1000th same TPS, because the atmosphere and the narrative is what gets you hooked on Spec Ops: The Line until you finish it. With all it's horrors and misleading delusions, it could be among the best fictional war movies with a perspective that slowly blurs reality with losing your mind to all the terror happening around you, with you, with your loved ones up to and beyond a point where you can't make a difference of what really happens and what is a delusion, and who is responsibile for all the death and suffering shown in shockingly real instead of overdramatizing and coloring it like the rest 99% of games do. It really is a masterpiece of psychological themed games. It makes YOU, the real person do horrific things and question your own morality, MAKES you want to find a twisted way to justify your decisions and depending on your choices, it possibly makes you feel like a monster.Other games tried it too but it was either too black and white or overly dramatized, almost cartoon-ish to keep the player reminded about this is fiction, and always gave a reason not to worry or feel like you are doing good in some way, even if that requires doing bad things.You'll question yourself here eventually, where were the line you shouldn't have crossed, and how long ago.And this is unprecedented in the gaming history.Throw in all this to the postapocaliptic feeling of Dubai being swallowed by the desert, with the people there being isolated from the world and are starving to survive any way neccessary.And the greatest thing is, that this isn't a selfish way of the developers to make their sick gore fantasy (partially) come to reality, everything you see is part of a greater puzzle, and once you see the whole picture it just blows your mind and leaves you in shock for minutes.TL,DR: It's pure genius worth mentioning (and being recommended) among the top games, even looking back more than two decades in the genre.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												ONLY SINGLEPLAYER REVIEW:I just finished the singleplayer. I already knew the story, the plot. But even with that knowledge, i wasn't prepared for this. This is masterpiece. The game market is flooded with modern military shooters, there are casuals like CoD, and Battlefield, or mechanicaly realistic like ARMA. But this. This shows what real war is. What PTSD feels like. The game is a third person cover based shooter, with all the right elements. there are around 10 weapons, some might say it's too few, but they are perfectly enough, since all of them feels differently and each has different firing mode. Using the covers feels smooth and natural. Shooting aswell. When you kill with a headshot, or get a multikill the game slows down a bit, you didn't just killed. You killed with brutality. Only thing i didn't like is the cluncy controls. Feels like i'm playing with controller settings on a keyboard. For example: Space - Use cover/Sprint/Drop down (from ledges).  R - Reload/Pick up weapon. This is PC. We have enough buttons, on our keyboards to use. It is annoying, that i want to run along a wall, and my character uses it as cover, or i want to pick up a gun, but i reload instead. Some positivity in the end: You have choices at certain points of the story, and i love that it wasn't: PRESS X TO DO THIS, PRESS Y TO DO THAT. The game not always tells you that you have a choice. But deep inside you know.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												So Spec Ops: The Line was currently on sale when I picked the game up and I thought, hey this doesn't seem to bad I've heard good things about this game so I'll give it a shot. The graphics on the game are nice and in my opinion fit the game well, there is times where you can see the odd things bugging out or not loading properly but that does happen in games so that doesn't really bother me. The story telling is amazing and multiple times I've found myself shouting holy♥♥♥♥♥♥or what the ♥♥♥♥ in to the events that just happened, There are points where you feel like you have no choice but to make a specific decision, then you realise it may not have been right, it opens a side to shooters where it isn't just oh you're doing whats right yay guns guns guns pew pew america, Honestly this game is worth the price if you can pick it up for not too much, I would heavily reccomend this game and advise playing it if you would like a different perspective to a shooter rather than you're doing what's forced on you while you slaughter A.I

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Short, but satisfying game. Even after 4 years, the graphics look nice and the engine works well (no bugs encountered). What made me love this game is the soundtrack, playstyle (getting headshots 24/7), and the story, although the last one is a love-hate relationship, as it shows the somewhat real army life - gorey and brutal, rather than running around killing people (though you have that too, from time to time). Also, the cinematics are pretty amazing, especially towards the end of the game - destroying buildings whilst flying a helicopter - what more could you want? You're allowed to make multiple choices throughout the game, which affect your sanity. The only drawbacks for me are the 30 fps/720p cutscenes, and the length of the game (6 to 12 hours), but that can be justified by the quality of the game, and the multiple choice scenarios. Overall, it's a great and original TPS, definitely deserving more recognition. If you haven't played it, make sure you get it on a sale, it can go for dirt cheap, and it's definitely worth playing.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												Spec Ops the line is a third-person modern military set in a ruined version of Dubai, now wait a moment before typing "Uuuuuggh, another modern shooter?" in the comments or what have you, because unlike other shooters this game focuses more on the story and still keeps some good gameplay elements.Pros:A fantastic story filled with moments that question your morality and the true consequences of war.Good sound design and graphics, making it look and feel like you're actually shooting a gun when pressing fire.Unique mechanics of using sand to your advantage and commanding two specially trained squad members.Difficulty scales with how far you get into the game, making you feel exhausted after long battles near the end, and so do the three protaganists in the game.Great characters with their own personalities and moral standpoints that make you question your own.Said characters (especially the Walker and his squad) get more and more mentally scarred as the game goes on, an example being Walker changing his "Tango down" to "GOT THAT MOTHER*beep*ER!"It makes you feel like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ person and hate yourself.Cons:It's short, only took me 6 hours to complete my first playthrough, though it does have some replay value with it's multiple choices throughout the story and an extra unlockable difficulty setting.Multiplayer seems pretty dead, but this game didn't really focus on it to begin with.It makes you feel like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ person and hate yourself.But besides those three(ish) cons, the game is well worth the 20 Euro (at time of writting) price tag, buy it for yourself (or for a friend if you already have it and need to spend some money quickly), play it to the end.Once you've done that, stop for a moment and ask yourself: Do you feel like a hero yet?

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												First of all, let me say that I would love to give spoilers during this review but I will not, I will leave a clean version and then black out the spoiled version (which will basically contain the whole story line)CLEAN VERSION: This game, fights like Gears of War if you've ever played that game, graphics, sounds, everything is a solid and I did not see any bugs during my play through. The storyline is what makes this game a true and EXCELLENT game despite its flawed and boring combat system, the story will keep you on your edge for about a good 3-6 hours, constantly while playing you keep delving yourself into the story until you know you have to beat this game; this game has a lot of twists in it that it will have you leaning to your monitor and when you finally see the end of the game you will gasp with awe and be in shock (which I rarely get shocked or am in awe as I am a very mellow person)SPOILED VERSION: You, Adams and Lugo are all 3 Delta Operatives that are sent into Dubai to find Komrad (a general) and over time you realize Dubai is a utter♥♥♥♥♥♥storm, you try to find everything out and keep pushing you and your men forward. You accidentally kill civilians with a mortar, but you keep going on and at the end of the game, you realize everything you did, all your actions to "help" the people of Dubai, you realize your guy that you're playing as is MENTALLY ILL which is a SICK TWIST but a great twist and you realize as your guy starts to flash back everything that he talked to corpses, made up scenarios as his troops stood by questioning him but followed his orders.You would buy this game for the story rather than the gameplay. Simply amazing.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												- duration of game (without deads about 5-6 hours)- Multiplayer (gameplays looks awesome, but I couldn´t find any server, nobody plays it...)- Keyboard setting (for example melee and jumping over cover is the same button)+/- your 2 partners (sometimes very good helpers /Lugo can easy take out snipers/ but sometimes wrong AI, they can dead outside, you can´t help them etc.)+/- Very easy achievements (Good for noobs, bad for hadcore players)+ Story (you can decide in few parts of game what to do)+ Weapons+ Graphic (Apocalyptic Dubai.. ..Man... AWESOME!)+ Dubbing and whole sound in game+ COOP with 1 friendThis awesome 3th person game is set in apocalyptic Dubai where you take a role like Captain of team 3 guys and you have to find out what happened. That´s all about story, cause I don´t want show anything, but I can say that it´s great with shocking moments and some decide parts. Gameplay is on good level with lots of weapons (assault rifles, sniper rifles, shotguns, machine guns...) and covering, running, camping system is like in Ghost Recon Phantoms. I didn´t find many negatives in this game, maybe the 1 big is sometimes your partners. They can be easy downed on open place without cover, so it´s difficult to help them, but this is a real problem only o hard difficulties. All in all: 90%

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												I just finished Spec Ops: The Line and I felt compelled to write a review.  I thought it was a descent shooter.  It was challenging  with an engaging environment.  It is set in a ravaged Dubai and you can see the opulence it once held combined with the savagery of the sand desert.   A good verity of weapons.  An interesting story if yet sometimes hard to follow.  There is nothing new here that you will not find in other games but it is all done well.  The graphics are descent.  The challenge is adjustable.  There is a coop mode and a multiplayer, but you better bring a friend because these areas are lacking in participants.  Overall a good game.  I give it 8 out of 10.

Posted: March 6, 2014
												Where should I start...This game is one beautiful surprise, you get in, thinking it's gonne one of these "shooters" where you do X thing to finish the game and then you get blown away. This game is a reflexion on war itself and on what war can do to the human race. What are we ready to do to survive....to accomplish our orders? The graphics in this game are astonishing and even though the weapons are quite limited, this will be the least of your worries when you will be stuck on your screen, trying to find out what's going on in this masterpiece. Finally, don't be afraid to shed a tear....it will only show yourself that you are still human and that this game accomplished it's objective perfectly.10/10 would erase my mind and play it again with the same feels.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												]You are here, because you want to feel something, you are not... A hero!Can a game put a blame on player for his actions? Can it mock the whole industry of so called "Military Realistic Shooters"? Can a game present main protagonist as not a player but his\her personality and deconstruct everything we knew about shooters so far?Spec Ops: The Line proves that it can be done! First of all, if you looking for fun in this game -- FORGET IT! There is no fun, this game has zero fun, and it feels right. that how this game should be; with both main hero and player, game gives both cognitive dissonanse and WTF feeling... Game puts blame on player, but also educates him. It hard to talk about this game without spilers, and I do not wish to spoil this expiriense for you.Know this, game communicates with player. And main hero represent not what you would expect. It build to deconstruct genre and gamers belives. Or maybe just the other way around, in embrasses player and his\her principles and gives a tool to stand a ground supporting second personality?Let's just say, that imagine if you would go into a strip club or bar, expecting to have fun! But the moment you enter, something starts to feel wrong, but at the saame time right -- like this is how it is supposed to be. You sit throug routine, when suddenly before closing, something rewealing strikes. And afterwards you expereinsing something that you never experienced before, of rarely. And you feel like♥♥♥♥♥♥ you want to kill yourself... For what? For doing everything without mistakes. You made zero mistakes, and you was wrong! But was you? Maybe you just missed your actual goal, and acidently droped into a club\bar, ye never meant to be? How to interpretate this experience you got? The only way is to come back and do this again. But it is hard... And not really that rewarding for the second time. And you can't just explain this feeling, you can only interpritate it with your own belives. And game gives you tools to do so! Think about it, like you want, choose the fate of main protaganist and yourself.But at the end, playing Spec Ops: The Line is like diving into a void, that sucks all good, leaving only darkness, pain and misery.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Certainly the best modern military shooter I have ever played ! Fluid gameplay, tactical and makes you stop and think for the best way to engage your problems or your enemies, instead of just running around and shooting, squad based strategy so you don't have to worry about godlike npc's who never die because you fail your mission if your squad breaks and the storyline makes the game a whole lot to play for. Makes you think why do wars exist, who kills and who gets blamed, what war does to a mind of a soldier who faces death everyday and lives to tell the story, what are the costs of following your orders and how far can you go to achieve your goal, or a madman's goal, how insane can you become and what's real and what's your imagination, how far can you go and who can you protect. Spec ops: The line, title says it all, sometimes there is a line that must be crossed for the greater good, question is, is it really the greater good? Or is it just a vision of a madman?

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line.To start of with I throught this game was just one of those games were everyone would ignore it, and it would just quietly past by in the corner. But no this game is a hidden gem, here is why.Spec Ops The Line is a 3rd person shooter, with a cover system. But Unlike the rest, this one is more story driven, this makes a massive difference to the way this game plays.Graphics, this game looked stunning when it first came out, and it still does now. The Devs really put alot of attension to detial and passion into this game..The charators look good and they animate very well, voice sync is pretty much perfect to lip movement etc. The guns you can tell what they are, but remember this is a 3rd person shooter.Finally the envirment, just wow, however word of warning which comes with a spoiler alert...This game turns...Dark and sinister quite quickly, now I did warn you that this one is different.Sounds, the weapons sound belivable, but when playing I m spending most of my time not getting shot than I am admiring the sound of the weapons. Explosions have a bassy smooth boom to them, the envirment itself when not in a fire fight is quite quiet all you can hear is the wind howling around the buildings and things moving about in the wind.Music is quite unnoticable during quiet stages of the game, just your standard low intensity tranquil music, till later in the game were the music turns, darker... the firefights the music does pick up but its over showed by the firefight itself.Last, voice acting. These are fantasic I mean they would be, this is a story driven 3 rd person shooter. You can even hear the mood in the voices they are that well done.Story, without giving away too much, this game is based in a storm ridden dubia, you are leader of 3 Spec ops trying to find survers and the "dammed 31St"..But what you acturly find is..a place full of chaos, and civial war. This is all I m wanting to give away.Gameplay, as I said this game is a 3rd person shooter. To that point it plays like any other, it does have a cover system and the controls are tight mostly( althrough they are simifyed for consles) so one button does 3 different things basicly..This can cause issues but I get that.As for its gun play it is very tight, and when one knows how the game works and how to move and get the cover system to work with you, than you are in for a great time. I almost forgot to mention about the basic squad commands, but your AI ( and the enamy ai) is pretty good they can take care of themselves and take down thier foes.Now as I mentioned this game takes a turn, and turns very dark..What I mean is this you get some very odd choices, even through the gameplay is liner its not do this this this..It lets you chose. But in general the devs want you to see the choas and the darkness here, and its that which gives this game a personalilty.ConclustionSpec Ops the line is a great 3 rd person, and it has a great story to back it up, and the way it delivers that story, with great voice acting..Its a great expierance and a joy to see it.This 3rd person is going to be very hard to beat and has alot going for it I feel.8 out of 10

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												A nearly flawless third person shooter.Let's get the story out of the way. You play as Captain Walker who, along with the other two guys, is sent to the destroyed city of Dubai in order to investigate a distress signal by the missing Colonel Konrad. Pretty soon you discover that the city is not empty and is filled with some civilians as well as the AWOL U.S. 33rd Army battalion which was supposed to evacuate the city after being deployed in Kabul. You then quickly proceed to battling and killing your country-men. Neat. I'm surprised this German developer didn't get any heat from critics yet for giving you the ability to kill U.S. army men. Along the way, you unravel the mystery as to what exactly is happening.The scenery is quite breathtaking. The Unreal 3.0 engine makes character models and distant vistas look crisp. The desert is so well made that it reminded me of the Uncharted 3 desert. You also get to leave foot prints in the sand. There are no texture pop ins and every texture is pre-rendered. However, the amount of video options is limited. The engine provides no DX10,11 or anti-aliasing for that matter.The game itself plays like a solid A/B action flick. There are some grand action set pieces, there is plenty of dialogue, there are opportunities to sneak up on enemy and there are some grave choices to be made and alter game in the process.One of the most essential components of the game is the A.I. and boy is it good, both friendly and A.I. The enemy soldiers will communicate with each other, they will give out orders, they will attempt to flank you and sometimes attack you from both sides at the same time, they WILL run away and jump away from your grenades, they will retreat, raise alarms, call for back ups, they will also throw grenades pretty accurately and they will do suppressing fire as well. However, some handpicked A.I. will just stand there without taking cover, just waiting to be shot. The reason is that if they are standing on the glass or next to a mountain of sand behind glass, they can be killed with the force of the surrounding environment.This game forces you to think when dealing with the enemy. They aren't supermen and they aren't pushovers either.As for the friendly A.I., well just about the only way that you can order your teammates around is by telling them to attack this guy or that guy or flash bang them. However, once you do give the order, your team mates will do their best to take out the indicated guy either with regular rifles, sniper fire or grenades. At times, I saw my team mates stand their own ground pretty effectively. This feature is unparalleled with many shooters, wherein even IF you are a part of the team, you are the one getting shot at most and you are the one having to kill every foe. (COD ahem)You also get to collect intel and figure out what happened to the populace and Dubai in general after the biggest sand storms decimated the city.Something about the gameplay feels right, I can't quite put my finger on it. You can only carry two weapons and a handful of grenades. The ammo is always scarce so the game forces you to not waste ammo. I also like how any assault rifle magazine will be out of ammo after just a few bursts - it's all pretty realistic. There is no evasion button and there is no prone button. The constant sand storm atmosphere creates a hostile and extreme environment and the sound of sand storms is quite deafening. Also, what's awesome is that once your frag grenade explodes, it also creates a collateral sand fog which stuns the surviving enemies which can be plucked one by one.As far as the weapons are concerned, well, every other weapon has a secondary feature. The M-16 or whatever has a silencer, so does the pistol, the AK-47 has a three bullet burst feature, the sniper rifle has a 8x, 16x zoom feature, etc.The thing that quite often DOES mess up the gameplay is the sprinting, that's right. When you go forward press "space" for sprinting (default) and then let go of "space", Walker will just keep sprinting for an indefinite amount of time. And if you want to stop immediately, you have to press "S", to back up. So I decided to switch to the good old "shift" for sprinting instead. It sorta helped but the running still feels consolish, especially when you try to make sharp turns and attempt to take cover while being shot at. What sucks again though is that the crappy consolized controls made "shift" stand for both sprinting AND melee. It's like, seriously devs? You could not allocate a separate action key for melee for us, PC gamers? we do have a keyboard, you know.Oh about that, when you are running toward cover and getting shot at, your character will automatically slide towards cover for about 2-3 meters, which is pretty neat because the game does not force you to press the cover button again. That's what they should have done in Operation Raccoon City instead of just adding automatic cover that doesn't work half the time.I've also noticed that the devs put a lot of effort into level design which look as if they were taken from real locations. The flamboyant hotel rooms, the flashy lobbies, the elegant living quarters, the vanity statutes, the artifacts displaying wealth of the city now gone - all bring an engaging dystopian feeling. At times, there are also numerous ways of advancing and flanking your enemies.The wobbly cross-hair is quite neat. The only time your aim is remotely steady is when you come out of cover, however if you sprint and then attempt to shoot, your aim will be all over the place. Thus, every other kill feels like a small accomplishment. If there only was no regenerative health. The good thing is that your team mates cannot revive you when you get shot up. However, you can pick them up and they can pick each other up.I should also add that voice acting in the game is quite exceptional.As for the multiplayer, well, it delivers on many levels. The crappy sprinting is still there, so it's best to not run at all. You get to customize your character as you progress. You get to choose 15 perks as you progress. These range between being invisible on the minimap while sprinting, increasing your protection against explosives, reducing the cross-hair wobble, increasing your weapon damage, increasing your mini-map (radar) range, etc. As for the weapons, there are 5 SMGs, 9 Assault rifles, 4 shotguns, 4 sniper rifles, 6 handguns, 2 machine guns and RPG. The levels are pretty balanced too. Some levels feature active destruction and temporary sand storms that reduce your speed, visibility and accuracy. Sometimes these storms cause collapse of nearby structures so you better stay clear.However, if you are playing a 30 minute match and then all of a sudden "lose connection to server" all your progress is going to reset. Now this sucks big time because after playing for some time, I "lost connection to server" and reverted back to level 1. Now this is a certainly good feature to discourage rage quitters and quitters in generals but it sucks big time when you lose your experience points and perks.All in all, this is a pretty solid M-rated (there is torture, mutilated bodes, up-close violence and executions) third person shooter with some new gameplay elements and addictive multiplayer that will keep your interested. Here are the minuses:1. Limited video options.2. No Co-Op campaign. (This could have easily been a 2-3 player co-op game).3. Medium-length campaign. 15 medium-length chapters.4. The pistol cross-hair sucks. And you can't turn it off.5. No way to turn off indicators when in cover. (Indicators that tell you if you can swap cover; it's cluttering the screen)6. Crappy consolish sprinting.7. Limited destruction.8. Bad grenade explosion animation.9. Having to press "space" for springing, taking cover and reviving team mates.

Posted: March 5
												Spec Ops : The Line is TPS set in the ruins of Dubai. It attempts to bring a fresh blood to the TPS games using the sand theme and with choices that reflect the harsh reality of war. Pros-Graphics and optimization -Good scenery and atmosphere-Interesting story-Voice acting-It has some replay value to it-ChoicesCons-Biggest problem for me was the gameplay. Controls get in your way a lot of times and aiming feels weird for some reason.-AI is dumb as ♥♥♥♥. For both sides that is. -Some parts of story are really cliche. Well, it's a war TPS so this shouldn't be news for you. -At times I felt like the game tried reaaaally hard to make me feel like a terrible person.Finally, this is a solid overall shooter but don't expect anything perfect, it has it's flaws. If you like TPS games you should give it a shot as it offers some quality time with it's story.74/100

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Finally I get to play this controversial game (because I want to read the book "killing is harmless" solely written on this game).It is a short game, I finished it (at least the majority of the narrative) in 5 hours. But the gameplay, to be honest, is mediocre if not horrible. Plus Multiplayer is dead. Graphics, let's say, mediocre again because it is really not impressive. The whole weight of the game goes to the narrative. It is really a anti-FPS shooter game. I even doubt if they actually made the other aspects of the game deliberately awful so as the player can focus on the "shock" of the narrative. Thus it is most fun to play this game with the expectation that this is just another shooter like GoW etc. The choices (and how impotent they are) the player are asked to make reminded me of Mass Effect series particularly 3 and its ending. The psychological manipulation and guilt-driven portrayal of war all aims at making the player uncomfortable (possibly contemplating). The hero is the villain. It is not the usual "there is no clear cut between hero and villain" rehtorics, but the entire dichotomy is destroyed. There is no justice in a war and it does not matter which side you choose. When the soldier is bodily on the battlefield, the gore and brutality does permanent damage to him. It affects the protagonist to its core while the he strives to maintain his legitimacy through construction of himself as the hero regardless of what he had done to many lives. Now I am going to read that whole book, if I ever got the time.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This could be just another war shooter, among so many others, but don't be fooled by its look. While in other war franchises where you take place as a cold-blooded soldier, used to face death in all its ways, this game makes you actually feel what is like to be fighting a war, not only physically, but also mentally.The main character, as the game progresses, becomes more and more injured, and his mind, at a moment, starts to twist and be filled with guilt, which causes him to have hallucinations that will affect the behavior of you and your team, from professional soldiers, to out-of-control psychotics, thus affecting gameplay.As of the mechanics, it follows the classic formula for third person shooters: precision aiming, cover system, etc. Being squad based, it gives lots of emphasis on colaboration within your team, and to survive you must work together with your  teammates. Ammo is very scarce, as you are often required to scavenge weapons from fallen enemies. Enemies comes in varied forms, from light soldiers to heavy-armored juggernauts.With a good plot, and a good concept for a war game, give it a try, as you won't find such a realistic approach in another game.It's worth every penny.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												One of those rare third person shooter game with great visuals, great narration, great voice actors and incredibly well written story.Spec Ops The Line never attempts to be great at gameplay. In fact, it tries to be as simple, as streamlined and straightforward as possible. What you need aside of shooting enemies (well , this is third person shooter game after all), is to make a good cover of yourself using environment as a shield. The game literally forces you to hide all the time, and only come out to make a progress. When in battle, AIs force you to hide like 95% of the time and they do a great job at it. There's no upgrades, skill trees, side quests, open world or anything your regular gamers want from today's games. Learning curve is minimal at worst, at best it is no curve at all.This simplicity, however, what makes the game good. It really fits with the game's linearity and storyline that challenges your moral/ethic code.You control Walker, one protagonist, and go on a simple rescue and evacuate mission. During the process, there's many background stories that develop into more complicated moral-driven situations. Throughout the game, I was forced to make some decisions I would not have made in real life - where I have the options, where I have the luxury to do many things I want.. during peace. In a war, all is different. The atmosphere made in game is just perfect depicting that condition - you feel yourself in Walker's shoes - see and think in his perspective. Very rarely does a game try to do that.That said, the game also has stunning visuals where I have no complaints at all. You see a detailed landscape of post-apocalyptic Dubai, along with the occasional sandstorms. Graphic optimization is also great, I've got no problem running this maxed on my laptop rig that's mediocre at best. Audio wise, it's more than enough to accompany the visuals. When fighting, it feels realistic. The sound of guns, explosions, environment sounds are well made make you feel the tense and heat of the battle. Furthermore, with decent voice actors, it makes game's narration just perfect - each characters' dialogues are performed with heart.Game's pretty short, 7 hours should net you almost everything. Nevertheless, as a whole, Spec Ops The Line is a great experience that all gamers should feel themselves. A game that starts great with great end.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Spec Ops: The LineBought game because of positive reviews on Steam. Was not impressed, and I am a military buff for games and documentaries and thought provoking material. Truly am surprised how so many people are 'mind blown' by the storyline that does not give you any power to truly choose. Most likely people who've thought little of war and its horrors, and the philosophy of human nature, might find this 'mind blowing.'Short review first. Scroll down for random rants.Story: Concept was somewhat daring, dark and unique. More importantly, a topic not explored which is why I give it a lot respect for. But ultimately the medium used brings it down, as well as poor pacing of monumental decisions that are made in the game as well as the execution of the story as a whole. Tip: There's a reason this game was not very popular.Gameplay: Good assortment of weapons. Cover system was sometimes clunky. Basic aim for the head gameplay. Enemies types were literally a handful. Boring and reptitive overall.Graphics/Enviornment: Some of the cutscenes were downright terrible looking for some strange reason. Some cutscenes looked good. The textures were bland as expected of a B-Budget game.Verdict: Ultimately, the game did provoke thoughts of actions and consequences. But the game itself did not do the story justice. And the story felt very unreal because of it. The pacing of the story and its content was slow, and slammed all the end. The end was decent. But all throughout the game they make it seem like 'you had a choice' but I really did not feel like I did. The repetitveness made me just want to finish it. Overall I was disappointed after reading the reviews, and if I had another chance I would skip this game. I only paid 5 bucks, but also had to invest 6 hours that did not have a worthwhile end at all.Random Rants: A strange game.Tries to portray a morally wrought story. That is supposed to evoke realism and grey warfare.The moral choice outcomes were somewhat thought provoking thankfully since thats what all the other reviews on here praised and reccomended the game. Though on one big choice you did not know the outcome after you had done it, so it was not really 'fair.' You thought you had picked something, but a different outcome than anticipated came out. Which is good and bad since it makes things not linear, but also means your decision was based on bad information. So I did question what choices would I take had I been a delta operator in this strange unrealistc storyline.Some of the Bad Rants:Then it puts you in an unrealistc settings(the sky scrapers are all abnormally huge and the city is half buried in sand. The local populace is apparently huge in numbers, all males, and armed to the teeth out of nowhere.) unrealistc combat (takes 3-5 body bullets to kill, or 2 bullets to the head) and apparently the main characters have indestructible bodies. (Sliding down sky scrapers, smashing their spines on rocks and metal beams, mid flight catching themselves with bungee cords, walking away without a scratch,  ziplining from sky scrapers.) Makes you feel like youre watching a hollywood action movie. Not a video game trying to evoke the horrors of war and the reality of war.Some of the Good Rants:The dialogue between characters after making moral decisions was realistic and thought provoking.Without spoilers, the enemies you fight leave a bitter taste in your mouth as you find out who they are. Not used to something like that in US games.The combat feels fluid and clunky at the same time. The slo mo effects when getting headshots feel nice. You spend most time just headshotting everyone.The US would never sent 3 delta operators to 'rescue' a battalion. They dont operate in 3 man units. Second they never had radio contact with base. Which would never happen.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Violence, bloodshed, and cruelty are unfortunate, likely indelible parts of our reality. As widespread as they are, it’s only natural they’re reflected in expressive media. Guns, for example, are always a hot topic, and a good fit for video games: point, shoot, be visually and technically rewarded. First and third-person shooting can provide such a compelling feedback loop for players that hundreds of these games are developed, and millions of copies are sold. Series like Call of Duty and Gears of War set the pace for the modern shooter. In a medium, in a society, so acclimated to this kind of violence, it is, in turn, only natural that opposing commentary arises. See Heart of Darkness, Apocalypse Now, and Spec Ops: The Line.A third-person shooter set in the near future or an alternate present, Spec Ops: The Line puts players in the shoes of Captain Martin Walker, an American soldier sent to Dubai with two companions to evacuate survivors from the city, long in ruins from hellish sandstorms. Upon arrival, the group picks up a distress signal from Walker’s old commander, Colonel John Konrad, apparently holed up in the city with his battalion, the 33rd. Walker decides to search him out, only to be met with extreme opposition from crazed members of the 33rd itself. Over the course of the game, Walker and his fellow soldiers cross paths with the CIA, cross swords with the 33rd, and make decisions that will change the lives of thousands.From minute one, the influence of Conrad and Coppola is clearer than a summer sky. Konrad (like, come on) may as well be named Kurtz; Walker, Marlow or Willard. The trek through Dubai is as hellish as the Conrad’s Congo or Coppola’s Vietnam. It is certainly a fitting setting for a modern retelling. Dubai is a rich man’s paradise built on the backs of thousands in a position no better than slavery. It’s in close proximity to areas heavily occupied by US armed forces for the last two or three decades; it’d believably be a point of interest and interference for our troops if such disastrous storms ever did strike. While The Line does hit these points, the classic story beats, and more, it’s held back by a lack of subtlety and a few key, sloppy moments. Narrative choices are peppered throughout, typically deciding between the life or death of nameless characters - only the final choice matters counts towards your ending, as far as I can tell. Those choices are further undercut by narrative choices you have no say in. This is summed up in an early chapter: you have a choice to save an informant or some civilians. One of your squadmates pushes for the informant and the mission, while the other wants to protect innocent lives - I went with the civilians. Hardly ten minutes later, your path is blocked with considerable forces, but there just happens to be white phosphorus mortars nearby. Now, strangely, your squadmates’ roles swap - the one who argued for the civilians now argues for completing the mission by any means necessary, while the other now vouches for finding another way. “There’s always a choice,” he says. Apparently not, because you’re promptly forced to melt a couple hundred people to continue towards your goal. This is made all the more baffling when, in later chapters, load screens directly chastise the player for killing without caring. I do appreciate that The Line asks these questions and poses them to players, many of which may be expecting just another action-packed military shooter. I’m just sure there’s a way to do so with more finesse and, ultimately, impact.Gameplay is serviceable, though drab. The closest comparison is probably Gears of War, owing to the focus on cover, roadie run, visible grenade arcs, and other nuances. Level and encounter design is, again, just serviceable. There are in-game challenges that offer a bit of engagement - get a hundred headshots, kill twenty rappelling enemies. I suspect this feature is a self-aware genre jab, juxtaposing arcade-like objectives with horrific and widespread death, but it ended up as the only thing maintaining my interest in each firefight. That’s the thing about this game: much like Apocalypse Now, it can feel like just another example of what it’s trying to criticize. It can come off as a cheap Gears clone made to sell units, and there isn’t always enough evidence present to say otherwise.I’ve been hard on it, but I do have a lot of respect for Spec Ops: The Line. Amidst the ocean of Duty, Battle, and Honor, this game stands out as a genuine effort to make these audiences, and this industry, to consider genre standards we may be too comfortable with. It’s worth attention, despite its missteps. Apparently, development was repeatedly delayed, some of it owing to story changes; with more time and a unified vision, Yager Development could’ve made something truly great. For now, we have a solid attempt at a Heart of Darkness for the modern age that deserves recognition for confronting complacency to violence.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line, is most certainly, without a doubt, THE hidden gem of 2012. Here's why:Gameplay: 6.5/10 - This is probably the weakest part of this game. However, it was still enjoyable enough to keep me occupied during the whole single-player campaign. This game is a cover-based third-person shooter. While there are some neat little gimmicks here and there, Spec Ops doesn't really do much to innovate, and stands as basically being an average shooter when it comes to the core mechanics. You will move from cover to cover, shooting blankly, or pushing yourself out and aiming, using your fairly average assortment of modern-military shooter weapons. You also have two squad members that you can direct to either attack enemies or to paralyze them. This is rather useful, and the A.I. is fairly decent and can actually help you out quite a bit when you're in a pickle. Another thing to mention would have to be using the environment to kill your enemies. However, this is nothing too special and just looks pretty for show. Now, if you're expecting a non-linear experience from Spec Ops: The Line, then you should look elsewhere. Spec Ops: The Line is an extremely linear game, in which you will go through corridor after corridor of enemy encounters as the story and character progression grows. There are collectibles to find in the game, but are fairly easy to find for the most part, and won't lead you off the beaten trail.Spec Ops: The Line also has the cinematic setpieces you would expect from modern-military shooters, but they actually compliment the story for the most part. When it comes to multiplayer, it really should just be avoided. It's nothing special and may even ruin the atmosphere of the game itself for you. Presentation: 9.0/10 - Spec Ops: The Line isn't exactly set in the most original place when it comes to modern-military shooters (Dubai), but the art-style is fantastic and compliments the game's overall atmosphere greatly. Everything is very bright and colorful, as the lighting and particle effects are excellent. The whole city of Dubai feels very surreal and liely, though the whole game is extremely dark in tone. This actually creates a rather disturbing and disjointed feeling throughout the entire game, which is great. When it comes to textures, there's nothing really special here. The game looks average, with character models especially having seemingly low resolution textures. Cutscenes are decent, except for the pre-rendered ones, which are locked at thirty frames per second, and don't even look much better than the ones that aren't. However, many cutscenes are very emotional and well voice-acted, just as the rest of the game. What I do have to mention is that anti-aliasing does not work for the most part, which is a shame.When it comes to music, Spec Ops did something different than hiring an orchestra. Instead, the developers rigged all of Dubai with massive speakers that play classic rock songs during gunfights that creates an oddly disturbing feeling throughout the whole thing. Other than that, it's mostly low base chords, but it still sounds great.Plot: 9.5/10 - Spec Ops: The Line is a game about how gruelling war truly is and what it does to you. The game has great character development and pacing, along with some truly emotionally crushing moments. The endings are all fantastic, as they all lead up to a more subtly devesating conclusion. While all this is great, what may turn people off is the length of the single-player campaign. I beat it in about four and a half hours on normal difficulty. It would seem the average range for game completion for people is 4-7 hours. While these are not good statistics, I fell like the game ended itself when it needed to, and didn't just keep adding filler content.Overall: 8.5/10 - Great.Spec Ops: The Line doesn't innovate on gameplay, but it makes up for it with an outstanding story and beautiful world.

content:
Posted: March 3
												Very few games have acheived the level of mind ♥♥♥♥ery that Spec Ops: The Line has. From a gameplay perspective, it's a very basic cover based 3rd-person shooter. The gameplay is purposely boring, almost even a chore at times, but it's all to convey the fantastic story and themes. Spec Ops wants you to think about why you enjoy killing virtual people, it wants you to consider if your actions are forced by the gameplay or out of your own choice. It does these things better than any other game I've seen. Length wise: it is pretty short. Playing on the normal difficulty I was able to beat it in 4 hours. Though it has some good replay value, with 4 different endings and plenty of choice driven sections. Additionally there are a small amount of collectibles that are worth searching for that add to the extremely interesting world Spec Ops has built. I would highly recommend picking this game up if you're even the slightest bit interested. A must buy if it's on sale. You are doing yourself a disserive by not playing this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												This game is tedious, annoying, frustrating and simply not much fun.And that's what makes it so great."What?" You might be asking yourself. What makes a tedious, unfun game so great? Is it some kind of "So bad it's good" kind of thing? Absolutely not, it was made this way intentionally, and for very good reasons. Spec Ops: The Line is very much like Schindler's List. You're not supposed to feel good about it once you've gone throught he story.The real problem with reviewing a game like this is that, without giving out spoilers, it's impossible to find a way to say, "Ya, play it guys, seriously!" Without some kind of attempt to list out what makes this game special, all I can say is, "The gameplay is lackluster, there are obvious monster closets, the AI is horrid and the multiplayer should have just been ignored entirely. I totally recommend this, 8/10." And that comes off as just strange.So, to try and do this without spoiling too much (and if I do, I apologize for the unintentional spoil), Spec Ops is less a game and more a thematic deconstruction and criticism of modern military shooters. And by deconstruction, I mean a total, across the board deconstruction. The game goes all-in on many gaming tropes and points out various areas that could easily use improvement or development into a generally quality mechanic and also makes it a point to deconstruct the players who play military shooters themselves.The following topics are given a deep insight:- The player's relationship with the main character- Who really controls who? Does the player control the character or is the game controlling the player?- The effects of dehumanizing the enemy on a person and, by extension, the player- Tedious gameplay that highlights the effects and shock of what people experience in combat- Moral ambiguity and a lack of any real clear "good" or "evil" in the game- Demonstratably real effects of cognitive dissonance experienced by returning soldiers suffering PTSD- The illusion of choice in video games- How easy it is to convince people to blame others for "forcing" them into choices they don't have to makeA particular poignant point takes part in the final acts of the game where the game questions if you, the player, are beyond help and are incapable of seeing what's beyond Call of Duty and its clones and pre-emptively telling anyone that scores the game low due to monster closets and tedious third person cover shooting mechanics that they completely missed the point and are beyond help.Everything about the game is designed as intentional and develops a deep experience that's difficult to find in gaming. While games like The Stanley Parable do a good job parodying the insanity of player choice, it fails to truly get the player to stop and think about it, let alone cast a wide net over the entire first person shooter genre and intelligently question nearly every gameplay mechanic, enemy AI complexity, faceless enemy syndrome, plot decisions and concept of legitimate choice.If it wasn't for the deliberate end-game reveal, various load screen quotes and even the changing menu screen graphic, I would have simply thrown this game to the side as some kind of boring, derivitive shooter trying to be macho. But everything about this game is lovingly intentional, from the three man squad with token black man explosive expert and wisecracking white guy to wave after endless wave of idiot enemy. The whole game exists as a critique of the FPS genre, the games industry and the players themselves. And it's not a caustic, nasty critique, but one that asks us to think why we suffer through these mechanics and why we don't demand improvement or something better. Even using the fact that this game can be called "Spec Ops 11" is deep in and of itself since using a brand new IP would have missed out on critically adressing the excessive sequelitis that the gaming industry is stuck in.Spec Ops: The Line is a bad and tedious game, but it's meant to be, and with the plot and decisions made within the game itself turns it into a brilliant commentary on what has happened to the games industry and the modern games consumer. I highly recommend you experience it in full to understand for yourself what's happening. It's a game that needs to be played since those Let's Play videos will do it a disservice as your active participation is necessary to get the complete experience as to what Yaeger is attempting to tell us all.And I thank Yaeger for making me think.The gameplay is lackluster, there are obvious monster closets, the AI is horrid and the multiplayer should have just been ignored entirely. I totally recommend this, 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2013
												When I picked up this game, I thought I was buying another faceless brown-and-bloom military shooter on the cheap... you know, Call of Duty/Modern Warfare knock-off with a ruined Dubai gimmick.What I got was so much more. I wish I had purchased it at full price, because the developers deserve much more money than I gave them. This game was fantastic for the story alone. I can't give more detail without spoiling it, but with only a few games have I ever felt this affected or deeply moved by the gameplay. There's a lot of shooting and some of it is repetitive, but it's vastly over-shadowed by the narrative and it's damned beautiful the whole way through. If you haven't played it, I really recommend picking this game up immediately... it's SO much better than it lets on and one of the only games I've ever played that manages to prove its point through every facet of the gameplay.In fact, one of my favorite moments I've ever had in a game happened during one of The Line's loading screens... that's a tall feat, considering. It's that good.

												This is an amazing game. What really captivated me is the dark and very emotional, in my opinion, storyline. It may seem like a "U.S.A. saves the day yet again!" kind of game but it's actually not. It's kind of a thought-provoking game instead. The decisions and actions you take will have repercussions on you and your squadmates psychology throughout the game. A lot of "dem feels" moments as the story progresses. Visuals are also very nice in this game despite being a 2012 shooter, Dubai looks great despite being not very immaculate due to the sandstorm. The gameplay is fine though, just a third person shooter with very simple mechanics to comprehend.I really recommend this game for its storyline though. It just blew my mind, really. It makes you want to seek for answers and even more answers... What the hell is going on in Dubai? 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												A clever experience, one wrapped in a familiar story and predictable rhythm:  A special operations team is dispatched to Dubai following a massive sandstorm and a communications blackout to determine what happened in the silent city.The third-person gameplay feels immediately familiar with cover, headshots and team orders.  The colorful environments and dilapidated city create a wonderful background to close-quarters firefights and hallway progression.Then...Then something starts happening.  Your squad starts making decisions.  They aren't the cleanest kind.  The more you look at what you're doing (if you look at all between the gunfights) the more you question what's really happening.By the time your tour in Dubai is over, you will have been witness to stunning human tragedy, a heavy-pitted feeling of betrayal and an aching need to determine just what the hell happened to make things go so bad.And if for some reason you remain unfettered by moral quandary, at least it's a solid cover-based shooter.Spec Ops: The Line is not really meant to be enjoyed light-heartedly, but is a delight to be experienced with an open mind.

Is it some kind of "So bad it's good" kind of thing? Absolutely not, it was made this way intentionally, and for very good reasons. Spec Ops: The Line is very much like Schindler's List. You're not supposed to feel good about it once you've gone throught he story.The real problem with reviewing a game like this is that, without giving out spoilers, it's impossible to find a way to say, "Ya, play it guys, seriously!" Without some kind of attempt to list out what makes this game special, all I can say is, "The gameplay is lackluster, there are obvious monster closets, the AI is horrid and the multiplayer should have just been ignored entirely. I totally recommend this, 8/10." And that comes off as just strange.So, to try and do this without spoiling too much (and if I do, I apologize for the unintentional spoil), Spec Ops is less a game and more a thematic deconstruction and criticism of modern military shooters. And by deconstruction, I mean a total, across the board deconstruction. The game goes all-in on many gaming tropes and points out various areas that could easily use improvement or development into a generally quality mechanic and also makes it a point to deconstruct the players who play military shooters themselves.The following topics are given a deep insight:- The player's relationship with the main character- Who really controls who? Does the player control the character or is the game controlling the player?- The effects of dehumanizing the enemy on a person and, by extension, the player- Tedious gameplay that highlights the effects and shock of what people experience in combat- Moral ambiguity and a lack of any real clear "good" or "evil" in the game- Demonstratably real effects of cognitive dissonance experienced by returning soldiers suffering PTSD- The illusion of choice in video games- How easy it is to convince people to blame others for "forcing" them into choices they don't have to makeA particular poignant point takes part in the final acts of the game where the game questions if you, the player, are beyond help and are incapable of seeing what's beyond Call of Duty and its clones and pre-emptively telling anyone that scores the game low due to monster closets and tedious third person cover shooting mechanics that they completely missed the point and are beyond help.Everything about the game is designed as intentional and develops a deep experience that's difficult to find in gaming. While games like The Stanley Parable do a good job parodying the insanity of player choice, it fails to truly get the player to stop and think about it, let alone cast a wide net over the entire first person shooter genre and intelligently question nearly every gameplay mechanic, enemy AI complexity, faceless enemy syndrome, plot decisions and concept of legitimate choice.If it wasn't for the deliberate end-game reveal, various load screen quotes and even the changing menu screen graphic, I would have simply thrown this game to the side as some kind of boring, derivitive shooter trying to be macho. But everything about this game is lovingly intentional, from the three man squad with token black man explosive expert and wisecracking white guy to wave after endless wave of idiot enemy. The whole game exists as a critique of the FPS genre, the games industry and the players themselves. And it's not a caustic, nasty critique, but one that asks us to think why we suffer through these mechanics and why we don't demand improvement or something better. Even using the fact that this game can be called "Spec Ops 11" is deep in and of itself since using a brand new IP would have missed out on critically adressing the excessive sequelitis that the gaming industry is stuck in.Spec Ops: The Line is a bad and tedious game, but it's meant to be, and with the plot and decisions made within the game itself turns it into a brilliant commentary on what has happened to the games industry and the modern games consumer. I highly recommend you experience it in full to understand for yourself what's happening. It's a game that needs to be played since those Let's Play videos will do it a disservice as your active participation is necessary to get the complete experience as to what Yaeger is attempting to tell us all.And I thank Yaeger for making me think.The gameplay is lackluster, there are obvious monster closets, the AI is horrid and the multiplayer should have just been ignored entirely. I totally recommend this, 8/10.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												If you want a great single player experience, this really is a great game for that.Spec Ops The Line may look like your standard 3rd person shooter. In many ways, it is. However, this is somewhat deliberate due to the context of the game being a gritty, dark game in a unique setting that makes you question everything about shooters such as these.This is a game that reminds you the reality of war compared to war in video games. In many games, you gun through loads of enemies because thee game told you to without thinking why. This game makes you think why.  In many games, you're a hero that saves the  day. This game makes you think what makes you that hero. The game beats you up for doing tthings that it common practice in shooters, and really makes you think differently about modern day shooters we see all so much of. This is helped by some great voice acting and script work along with both subtle and shocking story devices that make this game feel unique. The story has some shocking moments that you'll want to experience for yourself. Those looking for a rich gameplay experience or a multiplayer masterpiece or even a game that makes you feel good for being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that kills more people than he saves may want to go elsewhere. Those looking for a unique story and setting with developed characters and good enough gameplay that questions everything in the shooter genre to date, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												This is a good game. Gameplaywise, it's a fairly standard cover-based shooter with a button dedicated to commanding (read: killing) your squadmates, so I guess it could be construed as a tactical shooter (it really doesn't have to be if you don't want it to be, though). Storywise, it's a bit hit or miss, as I felt that the twist at the end threw away some great potential for a truly satisfying ending; imagine M. Night Shyamalan directing Apocalypse Now, and you're almost there. So basically, the gameplay isn't bad per se, but the story isn't as intelligent as it thinks it is (although the loading screen "hints" desperately want you to think otherwise). Still, the script is solid for what it is, the stark yet vibrant art direction is superb, and it is frequently fun. Pick it up when it goes on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
"Gentlemen, welcome to Dubai"I don't think a video game has ever truly affected me like this one has, it's a game that just absolutely makes me hate myself. The game is basically Apocalypse Now, disguised as Call of Duty. From just looking at it, it looks like every other modern military shooter out there, you would go into it expecting to find another game of gung ho pro-America machismo bull♥♥♥♥♥♥ but you come out of it looking inwardly, thinking about the concequenses of your own actions.The character you play as starts out as just a white bred all-American stereotype, but by the end of the game you don't even know who you are anymore, the character keeps making decisions and you have to follow along, the game willingly tells you to do things, and then when you see what it is you've actually done it just drives the point home and makes you know what you've done. You feel a disconnect between yourself and the character because the character thinks all he's doing is right, and all he's doing is just. When in reality it doesn't seem that way, you don't want to do these things but the game tells you to.The gameplay is nothing really to write home about but it uses genre cliches to get it's message across, it doesn't try to really make the shooting fun for you, it wants you to look at what you're doing, it wants you to see the horrors you are perpetuating. It just wants to make you feel like hell.And it's the little things that really make it hit home, the characters slowly falling apart as the game goes on, both mentally and physically, the loading screens just hitting home and blatantly telling you what is happening and what it is your doing just to show you that you are being a horrible human being.If you aren't squeamish and want a game that doesn't conform to storytelling standards you see in most video games, buy this game as soon as you can, it's amazing how much it really affects you.
