content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Do you like movies like Platoon or Apocalypse now and all other movies about what war will do with soldiers mind, just going a bit deep than "killing is a simple, just pull the trigger"? And do you like shooters? Consider playing this game.Game has very very strong corridor feeling, story is just same as in others game like that ... for a while.Graphics:Overall nice, for me a bit too eyecandy and colors rich graphics. But well tuned and everything fits its place. Fighting in sandstorm was both freaky and beautiful. Nice character animations.Sound:There is nothing exceptional, everything is perfectly done. Nice ambients. But i was a bit stunned when i encountered some battle in some large hall and there was some local radio station playing some hits of 70's ... it was like watching movies mentioned at the very beginning of this review or maybe like being inside them or a bit of living them during the game. It just pumped atmosphere twice :).Level design:As said before, this game has very strong corridor feeling with no alternative ways, but is nice. Loved lonely Dubai which nature decided to take back in her arms. Everything was perfect natural with strong feel of realism.Gameplay:Simple and good. You command two your buddies, you can give three simple commands "attack", "cover/protect me" and "heal", very simple mechanics but works nice. Also game has multiple endings and during gameplay there are few significant deciding moments what path you will take. Very nice story twists. Story is strong enough to get one to same mindsetting like main characters in game (if your heart is not just rock you will feel it). And until you finish the game (and maybe after finishing it too ;)) it is not clear who is actually bad and who is actually good ... and maybe aho is actually who.For me very uncommon FPS. Maybe exceptional FPS.

												As PC Gamer states "Set my Brain on FIRE!" I have to agree; the most unique Single-Player game in ages; especially as a military shooter - I am surprised a company had the balls to pull off a story as dark and ♥♥♥♥ED UP as this games story; with moral choices you are forced to make that change the reactions and outcome; and three differing final endings (with an optional ending prior to those as well) - it's the only military shooter that focuses on being a dark amazing SP work of art rather than a cash cow yearly franchise of patrotism and heroism about saving the world from terrorists.Perhaps in Spec Ops: The Line no choice is good or bad at the moment. It's all just horrifying; overly disturbingly realistic in the best way possible and leaves you thinking for days after - a contender for best story in a game at the end of the year for SURE.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												This game.. is something else. What on the surface appears to be a Army style third person shooters goes much much deeper into human sanity and morality. The Gameplay itself is lets be honest, pretty average however its the story that sets it appart from every other game like it. It isnt a long game with me finishing it at around 7 hours however i do not regret a single second spent in game. I would gladly recommend this to any "Choice" based video game enthusiast with a heavy influence of story narrative. The moral and ethical choices you have to take in this game are painstakingly difficult. Over all its a good buy if you have a spare 10 quid and a few hours to enjoy a good, well written story.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line are not a shooter game, it's a story game that use shooter as it's gameplay and to define itself in the ever-growing list of game-genre.It's the masterpiece of Yager Development, that Spec Ops: The Line can come with such a story that no other shooter game can rival.Spec Ops: The Line gameplay is standard or mediocre for a third-person shooter game, you'll find shooter game with better gameplay out there, but that's not what Spec Ops: The Line is trying to sell.It's the story.Most shooter game have a linear story, or non-linear story but centered on a larger view of the conflict.Spec Ops: The Line have a large story centered on how our character will define himself during all his 'brutal' mission in Dubai.Surprisingly the larger story of how the conflict in Spec Ops: The Line happen are told only by collected Intel that are miss-able.Upon playing to a certain degree, you'll be faced with a choice, that will make effect on your squad impression on you as their leader and your sanity that tread the thin line of soldier that obey order or a human being trying to survive on Dubai's Apocalyptic vision of hell.A minus factor is that all the choices you made will not result in a different ending. Ending will be determined only by 2 choices, and all the choices you made previously will be presented in a flasback momentarily at the ending choice.All in all, why should you get Spec Ops: The Line?Because of the deep story, and how the main character develop it's character. In the end of the story 1 likely thought that the main character will have, is the recurring loading screen message: "Do you feel like a hero yet?" after all you have done in Spec Ops: The Line.Getting this for the gameplay, and you will have a bad time.8/10, if only it has a unique or a little deep gameplay style. But 1 can't ask too many.Forget the multiplayer aspect of this game. Spec Ops: The Line is intended for a single-player game. (Even Yager says the MP mode initially aren't in the game scope, and it's been worked by another Studio)Though you can try the co-op mode if you have friend who also buy this game and playing it.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												Ohoho...this game is a doozy. If you think this game is Call of Duty, then you're sadly mistaken. It's more like Mass Effect (gameplay, deep story) meets Call of Duty: and heavy on the Effect, and heavy on the Duty. This game makes you think...constantly, trying to figure out just what the hell is going on, and makes you think about moral decisions you must make to walk the path of Darkness, or of Light. Like The Walking Dead game, you will be given choices to make and you will grit your teeth and think "Goddammit, I don't want to decide...all choices are ♥♥♥♥ed!". But you have to make a decision, and live with it, and listen to your teammates give you♥♥♥♥♥♥about it.It makes Call of Duty look like kindergarten. The setting is amazing. The wonder city of Dubai is cast into chaos when a freak, apocalyptic sandstorm buries the city under red death. The citizens just want to survive. But something's not quite right... If you've ever seen Apocalypse Now, or read the book/watched the movie Heart of Darkness...you'll instantly start seeing similarities. And hopefully, you'll get the shivers. Because this game holds no punches, and you'll be wondering if your sanity will remain intact by the end of the game. Okay, maybe your character in the game will be wondering, but you'll be okay though.It's not a very long game. I think I finished it in about 12 hours, exploring everything I could. But it's the story that makes you feel like you've been through epic hell and lived to tell the tale.  Or do you....? ;-) It's not one that I'll put 80 hours in, probably, but the time you do spend there will be worth every minute. And you'll be thinking about the game for a long time afterward.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												A solid third-person shooter that delivers intense action and a compelling setting, but relies too much on established mechanics, rather than delivering something new. The story however really stands out - a grim and challenging reflection on violence is something you won't find in any typical shooter. Perhaps containing one of the best storyline in gaming, Spec Ops the line is an experience that comes along extremely rarely and is a must have. While the gameplay admittedly falls flat and fails to be anything revolutionary, the Heart of Darkness inspired story really shines though with its themes and inglorious war and really gives you an emotional experience as you witness the slow spiral down Walker experiences though the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is far from the best game I have ever played. However, it may very well be one of the most important games I have ever played. Third person, cover based shooters are one of my least kinds of games, but the story, atmosphere, and acting of SO:TL made me play it all the way through nearly as soon as I bought it. It is a shorter game, but some pacing issues aside the game never feels like it needs to be longer or shorter than it is. It has multiplayer and co-op, but they really are not what makes this game valuable. If you generally like atmospheric, story driven games, this is a must play. If you are looking for a good third person shooter, you will be better served elsewere. The story alone make this game worth playing, and the attention to detail in the atmoshere, story telling, and characters are icing on the cake.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
Spec Ops: The LineSpec Ops is one of those under the radar hits, it probably has something to do with promotion, but this game didn't reach the public as it should've, and this is completely undeserved. First looks might pit it with any other generic modern warfare game like we've been bombarded with, but it is totally undeserved. Were other games in this genre don't even try to innovate other than some new weapens or multiplayer perks or features, *cough* yeah we all know which ones I mean. This game focusses on putting up a decent single player and just adds the multiplayer component under pressure of the publisher, this results in an impressive game and unimpressive multiplayer. And frankly I wouldn't have it any other way, I prefer a good story experience late night in the couch, multiplayer is not my first interest and depends largely on the community.In-depth review follows:Story and SettingThe game starts of with a squad inserted in a deserted city of Dubai wich has been struck by an abnormal natural disaster caused by global warming. The city is being hit by huge sandstorms anf US forces have tried to evacuate local populous, but failed miserably. They have been stranded and forced to survive since air traffic is blocked to travel beyond the city because of the storms. The squad led by Cpt. Walker the crew travels through the city to gradually unveil what has happend to the company that was sent in to evacuate the population. It soon becomes clear that being stuck in a city in the desert with no means of escape has taken a large toll and it becomes a psycological trainwreck facing difficult choices and paints a grimm picture of wat true conflict is.GameplayThe background isn't your typical modern warfare setting, but still faces you with the depraved reality of an actual conflict-zone. This is however amplified with the fact that everyone is stuck in one place with limited resources and a harsh surrounding setting. At first it is unclear what has happend in the city, wilst you're already forced to make decisions, these decisions aren't like your regular precedented choices. Like e.g. 'Press A' for choice 1 and 'Press B' for option B, I can understand why this might create some confusion for general players. Instead you can shoot a specific important character or try to bypass the situation. These stealth pathways aren't always obvious and the squad does urge you to make your decision fast which will result in most players just shooting their way out of the problem and in retrospect ask themselves were the choices in the game are made. In my opinion this is exactly what the game is trying to portray, are you a 'no-brain gunner' or do you use your hits to figure the problem out another way. I have to say, these situation aren't that abundant as far as my first playthrough, but I might find other instances my second time. Even though the developers do try hard to create variety in the gameplay, by inserting sections with street chases, helicopter chases and by splitting you up from your squad forcing you to play for yourself or to cover your squad from a separate path. However I wouldn't have minded a few more of these stealth sections, because I do have to confess that sometimes the firefights get repetitive. The AI including your squad is very good though, so you will be presented with a challenge. You can issue some attack commands to your squad, but it is limited. They do a pretty good job on their own and I have only been faced with them dying in the field by doing something stupid a very limited time in my whole playthrough.VisualsThe game looks very good, it is build in an Unreal 3 engine, and thus doesn't offer anything supprisingly new. But it does a very good job in painting a colorful and varied surrounding considering it is a desert setting. And believe it or not it isn't all brown and yellow sand locales you will see. You're guided through the Dubai desert, streets and even the Bubai aquarium. Theres even a very blue broadcast tower you'll be going into which reminesces of Mirror's Edge colour palette. Even the sections with white phosphorous and burned down massive graveyard dumps have their distictive feel.Most levels have been destroyed by the sandstorms an gives you some destructable aspects with very nice gameplay and visual effects. Speaking of effects, the lighting effects in the game are amazing. Obviously the sun plays a very important infuance in the levels and I believe the designers have added new lighting features not seen in the engine before. Don't quote me on the technical aspect, but it does look amazing.In the end I must admit I have stopped numorous times to enjoy the panorama and vistas or visceral setttings.SoundLike I have told before the game has stealth aspects and I might have liked some more of them, but on the other hand when the action starts you are engaged with some very good music. The nice post-apocalyptic wind effects only reminiscing to Fallout are muffled away for eighties and nineties rock music. I didn't check the artist list, but it sounds good and amplifies the military setting very well, and is just upsweeping enough to keep gunning.You can frequently overhear 'The Radioman' on broadcast and he will eventually adress your squad personally, all of which gives you a very good impression of how everyone in the city have been indoctrinated. This is obviously an important part of the story.But he just plays good music as well, so it's all good.VerdictLike I said before this game is worth a try if you enjoy a good story-driven game with a very twisted and realistic setting. The game including gameplay, engine, graphics and sound are build very well which cannot be said of the other generic triple A titles out there. Some of the firefights might get a little repetitive sometimes, but it is swiftly diversified by the story or environment and gameplay twists.I didn't really play multiplayer, but it follows your basic recipe: Cover-based gunning + Lot's of weapons + Game modes + Progressive unlocks = Boring(You make up your mind on that)Post Scriptum:- I did purchase the game on sale for 5€, which does make it even more worth it!- I play on an Apple LED Cinema Display, which makes games look very colorful! I might have been biased by that, :-D.

												If you like FPS, you should play this.If like to tear shooter stories apart you should not play this.While the game tries to be the equivalent to an Anti-war film, it fails due to the interactive nature of video games. While in a film you are disgusted by the characters, SPEC OPS: THE LINE wants to make you feel uncomfortable.You have a few choices, but no big ones. NO SPOILERS AHEAD: So sadly the key scene in the middle of the game contains a moment were you can't actually choose. That moment bothered me to rest of the game, even though the moments of choices appear more often. While I was forced to make a decision I still felt sick seeing the aftermath.The game is also rather challenging.So once more: if you like FPS or just don't hate them you might give this game a try.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												This is a good game. Gameplaywise, it's a fairly standard cover-based shooter with a button dedicated to commanding (read: killing) your squadmates, so I guess it could be construed as a tactical shooter (it really doesn't have to be if you don't want it to be, though). Storywise, it's a bit hit or miss, as I felt that the twist at the end threw away some great potential for a truly satisfying ending; imagine M. Night Shyamalan directing Apocalypse Now, and you're almost there. So basically, the gameplay isn't bad per se, but the story isn't as intelligent as it thinks it is (although the loading screen "hints" desperately want you to think otherwise). Still, the script is solid for what it is, the stark yet vibrant art direction is superb, and it is frequently fun. Pick it up when it goes on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												If you're reading this, chances are you're looking at this game because either, you're looking for a good shooter, or you've heard the story is amazing and you're interested in that.The simple answer is, yes. With no qualifiers or reservations, I say, you should buy this game. If you need no further explanation, then enjoy. For everyone else, I continue.On the surface, Spec Ops: The Line doesn't look like anything special. It's a cover-based third-person shooter, where you move from shooting location to shooting location, looking for the right moments to take down your targets. In this way, it is the same as countless other games. As is the norm these days, when you're hurt, just hide long enough and you'll be back to full soon. Your squad can be commanded with simple commands, and shockingly, they're generally very competent. The gameplay is fun, smooth, and I can find no fault with it--this is not written as a ringing endorsement, simply a fact: the game plays well.The story, likewise, appears unassuming. American military, Middle-Eastern conflict. If you threw in a nuke and maybe a cameo from the Covenant it'd be as formulaic as they come. It doesn't take long, however, before matters start falling apart, and the story leaves you guessing what's really going on. The way the storyline develops is a very strong point to the game, staying interesting, dare I say gripping, from beginning to end. On the merits of the strong story alone, I would recommend it.But many video games tell a good story. Whether they emulate a book or a movie, showing you the storyline from checkpoint to checkpoint as it unfolds. Video games have been criticized and defended over whether or not they are an art form. I have always believed that they had the potential to be, but very, very few games lived up to that potential; it isn't enough to simply tell a good story, a game must utilize interactivity to tell its story. Whether that means choice, or even the illusion of choice, the difference is it is you, the player, that drive things forward, as part of the story, not a player-character that completes objectives in the right order. Very, very few games accomplish this.Spec Ops: The Line is one of those few. This game is not about what happens, it is about what you make happen, and even as a linear game with only a few possible conclusions, it is a game where I felt that I created the outcome more than the most expansive sandbox RPG I've ever played. In the words of a certain famous madman, killing is making a choice, and this game puts the gun in your hand and makes you make that choice.This is a game that demands to be played, do yourself a favor and play it.

Posted: May 15, 2015
												Lets' get the average point out of the way first - gameplay is that of a generic 3rd person cover shooter, so don't expect anything else. The rest is all so bloody brilliant though. We have been conditioned going into shooters expecting that we are the heroes taking down the "bad guys" and as long as we all survive for a brotastic moment when the U.S. defeats (insert communist nation here) it's all good. The Line will rip your heart out and stomp on it violently, and will make you question your actions in all shooters to come. It puts a face to the hundreds of "enemies" you massacre and takes away that whole generic bad guy thing.The sound is amazing too. Both the soundtrack and voice acting are spectacular, especially Nolan North's performance.Don't blame me if you feel like a bad person after finishing it.8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												This review is only for the single player campaign on normal difficulty.  Pretty well everything about this game was exactly what I would want out of a FPS campaign.  There was a decent variety of guns, some of them had secondary fire options, a few gernade choices and a melee option.  The best thing about the guns was that there wasn't one or two that were obviously the ones you had to take with you, you had the choice to pick whatever two you liked and make your way through the game.  Of course there were times that one gun was much more useful than another but for the rest of the time you could run with what you want, till you ran out of ammo anyways.  Enemies were not to difficult for the most part outside of a few areas that were tricky.  Later game enemies did start presenting a bit more of a challenge.  They used cover surprisingly well and did attempt flanks and the like.The setting, enviroment, graphics, etc... were all top notch, there is pretty well nothing that I could complain about in that department.  From the beauty of the open spaces in destroyed dubia to the smaller areas were unspeakable horrors abounded, everything was just so well presented.And the story.  Without getting into spoilers because this is a game that should be experienced spoiler free.  I loved the story, I'm still not sure I entirely got everything that there was to get from the story, but thats the great part.  The game did leave some choices to make, as to what exactly those choices decided at the end of the day, well thats why I want to play the game more than once, and I can't really think of any FPS single player campaings that made me want to come back for more.  The only big gripe that I had with this game was with your AI teammates and their use of cover, or well lack of cover I guess.  The two AI teamates that you travel the game with are better than a lot of other AI teamates other games have stuck you with, these guys actually can kill an enemy or two but they tend to walk stupidly out of cover every now and then.  They would end up dying foolishly and you'd have to break cover to revive them or mission failure.But to sum it all up.  This is exactly what I've wanted out of a FPS single player campaign.  Everything was presented beautifully.  There was a decent selection of weapons to keep the shooting interesting and a story that above all else makes the game stand out far above a lot of other FPS campaigns and is something that I would whole heartedly recommend to almost any FPS fan.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												No spoilers, I promise. Where to start....jeez. This game is hits you and hits you HARD. I'm not talking about the gameplay. The gameplay is pretty standard. It plays like Gears of War; over the shoulder 3rd person, lumbering running, different weapon modes. It's not that hard to grasp the cover system, although I always found myself trying to get from cover to cover and forgetting to sprint so Walker just kinda saunters to the other chest-high wall. The story. It's unlike any modern shooter story. It doesn't make you feel like a war hero. You don't leave the game feeling good about yourself. You didn't save democracy. I challenge anyone to make it through this game lightheartedly. I certainly can't. No scores. No 10/10. Just play it. Give Yager their due. They made art out of a modern shooter. This is art in my eyes.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												This is an amazing game. What really captivated me is the dark and very emotional, in my opinion, storyline. It may seem like a "U.S.A. saves the day yet again!" kind of game but it's actually not. It's kind of a thought-provoking game instead. The decisions and actions you take will have repercussions on you and your squadmates psychology throughout the game. A lot of "dem feels" moments as the story progresses. Visuals are also very nice in this game despite being a 2012 shooter, Dubai looks great despite being not very immaculate due to the sandstorm. The gameplay is fine though, just a third person shooter with very simple mechanics to comprehend.I really recommend this game for its storyline though. It just blew my mind, really. It makes you want to seek for answers and even more answers... What the hell is going on in Dubai? 9/10

It is fun to click and pop heads in this Third-person shooter and it contains a really sad truth about war.Not gonna spoil much but this game will definitely make you feel like a horrible person. The challenge in changing the difficulty (especially FUBAR) really put me on edge on how carefully I should time,move from cover to cover and shoot even thought it is kinda anooying to die over 50 times. Little details I noticed as well were put into this game, for example, the image of the main menu screen changing as you progress the following chapters and how your characters' gear, mental stability and how badly wounded they are increases as you near the end of the game piqued my interest. In conclusion, this game is definitely a (+) to me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Unique TPS with good gameplay mechanics, an apocalypse-now type story and an excellent setting.Good♥♥♥♥♥♥+The setting is one of my favourites so far in gaming. Think a creative, beautiful and post apocalyptic Dubai.+Story is interesting and different than the norm with subtle clues and interesting decisions.+Gameplay mechanics worked well for me, but not for some. It's mainly a cover based shooter.+Style, sounds, weapons and music. The main title has (I think) Star Spangled Banner by Jimi Hendrix playing.+Melee finishers on downed enemies work nicely. No instant takedowns.+Multiplayer is actually pretty good. There's free co-op to but I havn't tried it yet.+(MINOR SPOILER) As the story progresses your character's finishing moves and "taunts" get more brutal. Nice touch.Don't feel right: -The shooting can get somewhat repetetive as there is not a lot of variation in what you can do.-Little replay value unless you want the story again from a more understanding perspective.Conclusion:The game is solid and of appropriate length for a shooter. I'm glad they didn't drag it out unecessarily and that the gameplay mechanics are of good quality. Nothing ruins immersion and good story like bad gameplay. Sadly the story didn't get a hold of me emotionally as it did for some, I really wish I could get into it but I just couldn't get real emotion from it as a whole. Certain parts got to me a little but not overwhelmingly. Still, it was a very satisfying take on one of my favourite tales: man goes into darkness and creates his own vision of society. Certain parts of the story/ending confused me a little but the whole thing is up to interpretation and certainly worth venturing into. Games like Far Cry 3, The Last of Us (especially), Mass Effect series and MGS series are examples of what engaged me emotionally. It's unfortunate that this did not but I still loved the experience and was always eager to play on and uncover the story unfolding. Maybe I've played too many shooters and become a little detached, who knows? Throughout the story you will get to make a few moral decisions but I won't say any more on that.Anyway, I'd give it a 9/10 easily, a full 10 if it had increased combat options/variation. I'm not gonna mark it down for failing to grab me as it did for others, however, as it deserves praise nonetheless.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line is a game where everything but the gameplay is top notch. What it does well is the setting which is the beautiful Dubai and the time they put into the detail made me really believe I was there. I especially liked the fish tanks. The amazing soundtrack which features Deep Purple and Jimi Hendrix and the absolutely excellent voice acting surpised me and there was a great plot with a tweeeest.It's just a shame that despite all this, the gameplay is just bog standard third person shooting you've seen in a million and one games already. It's all go into next room, suspiciously also full of chest high objects to take cover behind (!) and kill them nasty americans before moving on which has been done to death. There are some neat little things they've added though such as shooting windows with sand behind will crush the enemies dumb enough to stand next to them.Moving on, there are some powerful scenes in this game. My personal favourite is the white phosporus scene, it just hits you hard once you've realised what you've done. It's clear the game wants to think about what you're being ordered to do and in the finale basically tells you that you're far from the hero you think you are. It's a rather hamfisted way to get you to think about what you're doing in other games but I admire the devs for doing this.The voice acting changes throughout the game, as the missions and the plot progresses you and your men go from calmly talking and ordering around to full on shouting. I really like this as it does help the plot convey how far gone the main character is. Another part of the audio is the soundtrack, it matches the tone of every situation you're in and the radio man really knows how to set the mood when he deploys songs like Nowhere to Run. In conclusion, Spec Ops: The Line is a great game to pick up. It's an enjoyable experience which could've been amazing if not for the typical whack-a-mole third person gameplay. Pick it up for £10 or less if you can.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
PresentationTen years after the release of Spec Ops: Airborne Commando for the PlayStation 2, the franchise reboots with Spec Ops: Line for the current generation of consoles, bringing the classical shooting experience of the 90's to the current generation, changing lots of things to the Spec Ops formula in order to keep up with the current technology and the needs of the market. The story of Spec Ops: The Line follows the Delta Force team formed by Captain Martin Walker, Lieutenant Alphonse Adams and Staff Sergeant John Lugo in their reconnaissance mission in Dubai, after the city was constantly hit by major dust storms in the past six months, killing thousands and leaving those who are still alive in a constant battle for survival. As the city was believed to be abandoned when your team arrived in Dubai, your mission was mainly to confirm the fact that everyone inside the city is dead. As you'll find out from the very first moments of the game, that isn't the case as the 33rd Battalion commanded by Lieutenant Colonel John Konrad made a stop in Dubai on their way back home from Afghanistan. The story is profound and different from what you're used to in modern military shooters, and features multiple moments of tragedy, regret and life changing decisions, keeping you constantly on the edge of what's happening in Dubai and reminding you that lives are at stake. Sometimes the game gives you the opportunity to change how the events will unroll in a situation, making the difference between life and death and also the way your crew will appeal to you. The game does feature four different endings, and even though the decisions you take along the story will impact the way you look upon what happened and what role you played in the entire scheme, they won't affect the ending itself, as you can see all endings by reloading the final chapter. In addition to the amazing story, the game features a multiplayer mode similar to what other games like Uncharted or Call of Duty have already done in the past, but apart from that there isn't much more to it. There are different game modes and maps you can try out, the most unique and entertaining experience probably being provided by the Buried mode, which tasks two teams of four to sabotage the enemy headquarters while defending their own, a great experience enjoyed with a couple of friends or online with all slots filled.Rating: 8.5GameplayThe gameplay is exactly what you would expect from a third person shooter, yet there are a few features that make this experience different from the others. The inventory of weapons is large, including everything from pistols, to SMGs and heavy artillery, and even more the game awards you with achievements for using all of them and killing enemies in unique ways. In addition to those, you have grenades, sticky grenades and flashbangs, which serve as an important tactical maneuver, as you'll often run out of ammo, being forced to use a flashbang to stun your enemies while you make a run to grab another gun or find some extra ammo. One thing that is different in Spec Ops: The Line however, is the fact that you can use the environment to your advantage, from shooting the roof on which an enemy is standing, to exploding barrels and breaking the barrier keeping the sand away from an encampment, there are plenty of ways to use the environment to your advantage and save some ammo. The game features three difficulty levels, plus the FUBAR difficulty level that is unlocked after you've completed the game on the Suicide Mission level of difficulty. Each level of difficulty is nicely optimized depending on your needs for challenge, and combined with the different story outcome, there are lots of reasons the play the game all over again on a higher difficulty level. You are also allowed to give orders to your crew, a feature that will prove quite handy when you're low on ammo or surrounded by groups of enemies that you can't handle by yourself. The enemies are quite diversified, from snipers to shotgunners and heavy armored shooters the game offers enough variety in the terms of combat, while still maintaining the level of realism and logical equipment for those troops in the middle of a desert. On the multiplayer side, the game features many modes, although most of them have the same twists that have been done many times before; in the addition to the classic death match, the game has additional modes such as Rally Point which requires your team to hold the target point for as long as possible, Buried, which serves as a VIP escort mode with a few objectives before getting to that, or Uplink which requires each team to make a rush for the center objective, but only after they've secured their own mini team uplink.Rating: 9GraphicsThe landscapes of Dubai are simply astonishing, with tall buildings destroyed by the sand, all of it designed by adding the even the smallest detail. The world around you is full of items and equipment, exactly how you would imagine an abandoned luxury city to look like. From the expensive hotels turned upside down by the civilians running for their lives when the storm hit, to the swimming pools filled with sand from the previous storms, everything looks amazing. The visual effects are nice, especially the ones involving sand, dust storms and everything related to that; the lightning effects are awesome and different from a place to another, providing a quality rarely seen in such an area. The characters look okay and detailed enough to actually see the marks left by the combat on the faces of your team from a chapter to another, yet the facial animations could use some improvements.Rating: 8.5AudioThe sound effects are nice and synchronized with the action on the screen and the quality is standard high definition audio. The soundtrack is okay, yet limited and sometimes unneeded, but it does help you get in the mood for what's coming next, so I'd say it does the job just fine. The voice acting features the legendary Nolan North, known for his great acting in the gaming industry in franchises like Assassin's Creed, Call of Duty and Uncharted, things that made him an obvious choice for the role of Martin Walker. Other roles are played by not so known actors like Christopher Reid in the role of Lieutenant Alphonse Adams or Bruce Boxleitner as Lieutenant Colonel John Konrad, yet they managed to delivered their lines in an outstanding manner, making the entire voice cast for The Line one that gives personality to those characters creating this amazing story around your actions.Rating: 9ExtrasThere are plenty of reasons to replay the campaign all over again, or at least parts of it as you can choose to play individual chapters after you've completed the game once, plus the achievements are fun to do and trying new things as you progress through the campaign is always a boredom killer. In addition to that you have the multiplayer mode that offers more hours of gameplay depending on how much you're digging it, but don't expect to be a game changer as most of it has been done before in the exact same manner.Rating: 8VerdictThis game isn't your typical modern combat shooter, as it doesn't follow the events of any war or your quest to killing an evil treat, instead it focuses on your actions and the way things can change drastically in just a few hours. The game successfully created a great atmosphere and an even better story, making you the center of attention by the moment you arrive in Dubai, as you'll change the entire city with your decisions and dedication to your service.Rating Overall: 8.6Check out the full review and a lot more about Spec Ops: The Line at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=277

												Ah.. what do I say... or infact.. what do I start with...            The way the game takes in inspiration from Heart of Darkness, a book frirst published in 1899 and written by Joseph Conrad, which centers around Marlow, an introspective sailor, and his journey up the Congo River to meet Kurtz, reputed to be an idealistic man of great abilities.. or the fact that it makes references to the great 1979 movie Apocalypse Now, directed by Francis Ford Coppola, taking place during the Vietnam War.... many things reference both.. such as the Phosphorus scences.... depicting the shear awsomeness of the weapon itself... yet also having such emphisas on its horrid use and concequences...            This game is too great to be left alone... its a must play... you will have some great times... and some wishing you'd haven't chose that path...    And to finish this review off... the wellsaid line of what I think... one of the greatest movies to ever come out of the U.S. of A...Kilgore: Smell that? You smell that?Lance: What?Kilgore: Napalm, son. Nothing else in the world smells like that.Kilgore: I love the smell of napalm in the morning. You know, one time we had a hill bombed, for 12 hours. When it was all over, I walked up. We didn't find one of 'em, not one stinkin' dink body. The smell, you know that gasoline smell, the whole hill. Smelled likeKilgore: victory. Someday this war's gonna end...

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												My overall experience of the game was great. 9/10Moral Choices: There were some choices in the game, but a bit difficult to actually notice them or understand how to make the choice for a couple of them.Story: Was alright, not entirely easy to follow and the end is a bit of a mind♥♥♥♥.Graphics: Some cheap explosive effects from cannisters, and the sandstorms could have used a little polishing.  Other than that the graphics were fantastic, they paid a decent amount to minor details such as injuries and bandaging them up as the game goes along.Guns: There was a decent variety, but I mostly stuck to the starting weapons, the pistol had amazing accuracy and stopping power, and the rifle had little kickback.Controls: Pretty good with some dashing/sprinting exceptions. IE: Trying to manuever around and taking cover on a column was tough.  Also the toggle mode for sprint was annoying as hell, holding it down and letting go would have been much better.AI: The AI was decent, but at some points there were glaring issues and oddities in their behaviour.  Not enough to detract too much from the gameplay.Some of what these guys were wearing made absolutely no sense for a desert. IE: A super heavy suit of armorDifficulty: Played it on the 2nd hardest mode, felt it was mostly well balanced.Theres a difficuly spike towards the end, which I found very frustrating.I don't think the game was done justice, for my first over the shoulder "FPS" I was quite pleased with it.

Excellent story-focused 3rd person shooter+ authentic depiction of war and madness it creates+ thrilling story with several important choices+ fast-paced action, plentiful enemies, all the good old shooting, realistic violence+ military manner of speech with excessive profanities (the action seems more realistic when my character shouts "F**k you" at the enemy and the soldiers use the F-word in every sentence:)), top-notch voice acting+ graphics, especially the setting of ruined Dubai and some nice details like the protagonists getting gradually covered with mud and blood+ balanced difficulty (I died quite a lot, but never got frustrated of feel the AI plays unfair)+ great rock'n'roll soundtrack (very rare and original in this genre)+ I could play it twice in a row without ever getting bored- the game is really short (not a con for me though; the choices support replayability)- no sandbox here, the field of battle is in most cases tunnel-like

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2013
												Can a video game use clunky controls and cheap deaths to get its message across? Can a video game make you feel guilty about things it told you to do?War is hell, and you experience it as Captain Martin Walker of Delta Force who is sent to a apocalyptic Dubai along with his friends to look for survivors. What starts of as an average 3rd Person military shooter, turns into something that most video games shy away from. You witness public executions, walk through a mass grave, and see soldiers burst into flames, each one effecting Walker and his friends mental state until they are a shell of their former self. You are not meant to enjoy Spec Ops The Line, as the game will always put the odds against you and any "heroic action" will get you killed. The choices you make will affect everyone around you, and doing what needs to be done isn't always right thing to do, and sometimes, you don't have a choice. Spec Ops: The Line is a dark and grim game that I highly recommend.

												Spec Ops: The line starts off seeming like a pretty ordinary, run-of-the-mill shooter (set in a semi-surreal Dubai) and then develops into one of the best story-driven shooters ever made (contradicted by the undeserved meta-score). Don't enter The Line with high expectations in the way of gunplay and all, but be prepared for a harrowing story-driven experience. I don't recommend reading too too much about the game before playing because the story is easily-spoiled once you're made aware of its inspirations (a certain piece of literature, and a certain film).

content:

												Usually I can't stand any of the modern, strictly scripted and linear shooters, for plenty of reasons. Most of them do not offer anything interesting in gameplay, and their scripts are generally so bad that they seem to be written by a trained monkey. Well, Spec Ops: The Line is quite an average shooter, when considering the gameplay, but the script and the story are something truly extraordinary and unforgettable. If you're a fan of the Heart of Darkness novella or any of its adaptations, for example Apocalypse Now, you should give this game a try.All in all, I have not encountered before any strictly linear modern warfare shooters with an interesting single player campaign and a truly thought-provoking story. Well, I really hope that this wasn't the first and the last time.

												Finished the game twice,I have a clearer glance now.....Just buy it.Being at normal price or on sale,buy it,you won't regret it.The best thing about this game is the story and then comes the gameplay.Story[no spoilers]You are a 3guys squad[Captain Walker,Lugo and Adams] sent to Dubai to rescue the population,that has been hit by some ''furious'' sandstorms[both Dubai and the locals].There the so called 33rd US army is on a ceasefire,the ''Exiles'' and the ''Damned'',so you have to  pass throught the 2 fighting teams to accomplish your mission,to evacuate Dubai.Things are getting twisted[Very good things happen]That's the basic plot.-The best thing in this game is the combination of modern warfare and philosophy.the impact of war to human's brain and psych.The story is a bit mysterious,I mean you may have to search about it on the Internet to find out some things In the game.-Its graphics are satisying[2012]-The features are 85/100[Mechanics etc]Negatives....Multiplayer is ''dead''But you can try out to play co-op,solo or with friendsAll in all I rate Spec ops the line....8.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												At face value, this game is quite misleading. It merely seems like yet another third person cover based military shooter, and while it is that, there is SO much more that this game offers in its single player that *very* damn few games offer in terms of sheer quality. The story in this game is beyond stellar, so much so, that I would place it in a top 10 list of any entertainment media, ever. Of all time. It is simply that good. Movies, TV shows, games, mini-series, all of that. The sheer attention to detail in character progression, mentality, the horrors of what war does to a mind, and even just how you progressively become more physically worn along with your mental psyche as this horror story unfolds on not just you, but your three-man squad. THAT is where the beauty of this game lies. If you are looking for the next big shooter, thats not quite this, but if you want a story that will stick with you and seriously make you ponder throughout the game,, through the end, and hours after you turn it off, this is THE game for you. The story is so damn good, you will want to play the game again and again to pick up things you might have missed, see things you will understand a second time around because the endgame was explained, and there are multiple endings, but there is no good ending here. Not with what Captain Walker goes through. Also, he is voiced by Nolan North.The setting is essentially a post-apocalyptic Dubai. Not the world being so, just that one city that we all know and adore for its beauty. The city was absolutely and horrifically demolished by a monstrous sandstorm that would have Mars getting jealous, and they still pop up in the game from time to time and make for some hellacious tense gameplay. The US Army sent in a ranger battallion to the city in hopes of relief effort, but they had fallen and become rogue as a civil war broke out inside that battallion. The CIA gets involved, the locals take up arms in rioting, and resistence, and your squad gets caught all in the middle of it, and are forced to fire back on US Soldiers and locals alike. There are no allies except your other two men, and even that gets put through many tests, and test you this game will. There are decisions to be made in this game, but unlike other games, there is no right or wrong, no branching path, no ultimate change in story, and it tests your morality and makes you think on just what you might do in the absolute hell that is now Dubai. On the surface in this review, that may seem like a bit of an overstatement, but play the game and see just how much it gets to you in the heat of the moment. There are *very* few games that will have the impact that this one carries, and this game is very gruesome and dark in that aspect. To wrap it up, this is WITHOUT A MODICUM OF DOUBT, a game that you absolutely need to play and experience. Pay attention to the story and all the details of the world, how much it changes and how much you change (both in game and real life) throughout it. I easily can rate this game a perfect 10/10 on its story mode alone. DO NOT ignore this game as we as the gaming community need so much more like this and should be, for lack of a better word, blessed that something with this quality still exists.One last thing to remember, all throughout the campaign....do you feel like a hero yet?

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												A slow descent into madness and despair that is worth every minute of it. The locations are very well designed, creating very interesting firefights. The hand to hand combat and killing animations were also a personal favorite. Another good point is that the various choices you have to make are integrated in the continous flow of the gameplay instead of pausing the story at a junction waiting for you to decide. Something else I really liked was the change of the behavior and mental state of the characters as the story progresses which helps even more with the immersion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												I highly enjoyed this game. It has the best story I have encountered in its medium and it addresses the player and not just the in game character. It is dark, wastes little time (~6 hours on suicide difficulty), and delivers harsh consequences for choices that the character makes in the story. A large amount of enemies are killed but it is not a bro-tastic shooting game. These characters have hardships which are legitimate instead of being cheesy and tacked on.Its gameplay is standard over-the-shoulder cover-based affair, but I enjoyed the challenging combat (I only have played on the hardest difficulties available and cannot speak for the easier settings). While the ally AI is sluggish and lacks judgement, the enemy AI flanks and suppresses and is effective at sending you to the death screen.This is a painfully obvious console port, though.The controls are not terribly intuitive. Sprinting, melee bashing, diving into cover, and vaulting over cover actions are tied to two different buttons. Sometimes one action is performed when the other was desired due to how they are tied together. It will take time to get used to their cover system, especially on keyboard. It does its job but is a bit clunky.There are limited graphical settings in the menu, most noticably the complete lack of AA. If you want to remove those jaggies, do so through other means. The game otherwise looks pretty good considering that not much graphically seems to have changed from its transition from console to PC. The settings are especially nice to look at.I enjoy this game even while reminds me that I am a virtual murderer. A third runthrough is in my future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												This is basically PTSD: The Game.As a game, it's pretty standard.  You get into cover.  You shoot guys with guns.  Run to the waypoint to continue getting into cover and shooting guys with guns.  It feels fairly clunky to actually get into cover.  I felt like I had to hit the space bar a specific way to actually get into cover.  There are a handful of weapons in different categories like rifles, shotguns, small arms, snipers and heavy weapons.  Everything feels fairly generic with a few exceptions like shooting a part of the environment to dump sand on your foes and that's about it.  You can give orders to your team, but some orders only pop up at specific times and I could never seem to be able to use the attack order.  I was able to beat the campaign on the hardest availible starting difficulty in under 7 hours.  Again, as a game, it's pretty generic.As an experience, it's a completely different beast.  Never in my life have I played a military shooter that was this shocking.  If you thought the nuke scene and "no russian" from Call of Duty were hardcore, then you haven't seen anything yet.  It's really something you have to see for yourself and I wouldn't dare spoil it.  If I had to compare the story to anything, it feels a lot like the movie "Apocalypse Now" and if you've seen that movie then you should be aware of the levels of shock you are getting into...but even the story here goes above and beyond that.   Again, as an experience, it's quite unique.If you can get it cheap, do not pass it up even if you don't like cover shooters.  This is one game you need to see to the end...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												Ohoho...this game is a doozy. If you think this game is Call of Duty, then you're sadly mistaken. It's more like Mass Effect (gameplay, deep story) meets Call of Duty: and heavy on the Effect, and heavy on the Duty. This game makes you think...constantly, trying to figure out just what the hell is going on, and makes you think about moral decisions you must make to walk the path of Darkness, or of Light. Like The Walking Dead game, you will be given choices to make and you will grit your teeth and think "Goddammit, I don't want to decide...all choices are ♥♥♥♥ed!". But you have to make a decision, and live with it, and listen to your teammates give you♥♥♥♥♥♥about it.It makes Call of Duty look like kindergarten. The setting is amazing. The wonder city of Dubai is cast into chaos when a freak, apocalyptic sandstorm buries the city under red death. The citizens just want to survive. But something's not quite right... If you've ever seen Apocalypse Now, or read the book/watched the movie Heart of Darkness...you'll instantly start seeing similarities. And hopefully, you'll get the shivers. Because this game holds no punches, and you'll be wondering if your sanity will remain intact by the end of the game. Okay, maybe your character in the game will be wondering, but you'll be okay though.It's not a very long game. I think I finished it in about 12 hours, exploring everything I could. But it's the story that makes you feel like you've been through epic hell and lived to tell the tale.  Or do you....? ;-) It's not one that I'll put 80 hours in, probably, but the time you do spend there will be worth every minute. And you'll be thinking about the game for a long time afterward.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												A solid third-person shooter that delivers intense action and a compelling setting, but relies too much on established mechanics, rather than delivering something new. The story however really stands out - a grim and challenging reflection on violence is something you won't find in any typical shooter. Perhaps containing one of the best storyline in gaming, Spec Ops the line is an experience that comes along extremely rarely and is a must have. While the gameplay admittedly falls flat and fails to be anything revolutionary, the Heart of Darkness inspired story really shines though with its themes and inglorious war and really gives you an emotional experience as you witness the slow spiral down Walker experiences though the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is far from the best game I have ever played. However, it may very well be one of the most important games I have ever played. Third person, cover based shooters are one of my least kinds of games, but the story, atmosphere, and acting of SO:TL made me play it all the way through nearly as soon as I bought it. It is a shorter game, but some pacing issues aside the game never feels like it needs to be longer or shorter than it is. It has multiplayer and co-op, but they really are not what makes this game valuable. If you generally like atmospheric, story driven games, this is a must play. If you are looking for a good third person shooter, you will be better served elsewere. The story alone make this game worth playing, and the attention to detail in the atmoshere, story telling, and characters are icing on the cake.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												This game is more than just another ordinary shooter, this game is more than a video game. I got this game through the Humble Bundle deal a while back and I kind of just shrugged it off, didn't think much of it. I can now say that I was foolish for neglecting this game. I had played through the first 30 minutes and then left it for months on end until about a week ago, when I decided to play it again. Let me tell you something, this game hits you in the blind spot. You expect another shooter but instead, you get this rich story, well developed characters that actually feel important, and gritty action that I have not seen in a shooter in a while. The decisions and consequences of your actions can very well depict the harsh reality of warfare, and the life in general. This game flows really well, and does not miss a beat. The beginning may come off slow, but stick with it and you will be rewarded. The combat may take a bit to get used to, but the mechanics are fairly decent for a third person shooter. I sometimes found myself getting "lost" during combat, especially when a grenade is thrown, I found myself sprinting towards the grenade because of mechanical issues. Aside from that, I have almost no negative comments about this game. But to be fair, the game is still far from a 10, so I would give this game a solid 8.5/10. But don't let that score fool you, I still very much enjoyed this game and I'm sure you will too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Playing this game is rather like watching the proverbial train wreck: you'll be horrified, but you can't look away. This is in no way a bad thing. Spec Ops wants to tell a story about soldiers in war. But unlike games such as Call of Duty, it doesn't want you to feel like an awesome, unstoppable killing machine that's fighting terrorism FOR 'MERICA!!! or whatever; it wants you to see that war is not glamorous, awesome, fun, or desirable. It wants you to see the terrible toll that combat can exact on those who experience it. And above all, it wants you to see that in real conflict, there are no "good guys" and "bad guys," and the world is full of gray areas. War is hell, and anyone who goes in will either join the fortunate dead...or have to live with what they've done to survive.Spec Ops is a third-person cover-based shooter that alternates between desert environments and crumbling urban ruin. You have two squadmates who can be directed to attack specific targets or heal a fallen comrade; they're pretty good at following orders in a timely fashion and, unlike some other AI partners, they're not highly prone to getting themselves shot constantly or hung up on the level geometry. Enemies are decently clever, more than willing to flank you, toss grenades to get you out of cover, or trick you into walking right into a Heavy Trooper's line of fire.The game also offers the clever idea of having drifts of sand piled up on fragile surfaces like windows, which you can shoot out to bury your enemies. It doesn't show up that often, but it's kind of neat when it's there.There's the usual shooter stable of weapons: pistols, heavy pistols, shotguns, sniper rifles, etc. They sound good and feel decently punchy, and aiming is never a problem. Most weapons also have an alternate fire mode, which does add a little depth to the combat.I didn't play the multiplayer, so I can't honestly review it. I will say the developers originally didn't even want multiplayer, and the campaign is designed well enough to stand on its own, so make of that what you will.I highly recommend this game. It is a breath of fresh air in an over-crowded genre that's becoming increasingly generic. This game is also visually stunning, with exceptional voice acting, and sound. It is definitely worth the money and the effort to play the game from the beginning to the end.Final Decision: 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2013
												I'll be honest, I came into Spec Ops: The Line thinking it would be another ''MURICA!'' shooter, and I left absolutely blown away. The combat feels very Gears of War-esque, but I found it to be quite nice for this game (No, there's no wallbouncing or anything like that). The great thing about SO:TP isn't the combat, but the story. Rarely, do I feel empathic for the charcters in a game, but Spec Ops is a fantastic exception. The game follows Martin Walker and his squad, in an attempt to evacuate the refugees in the now destroyed Dubai because of heavy sandstorms.  As the game progresses, you find out you HAVE to make tough descisions to move on. You realize that true war isn't about right or wrong, but whether the choices you make are intended for the greater good. I won't spoil the endings for you, but the game tells you that YOU did this. YOU could've stopped the senseless acts of violence at any point, but YOU kept going on. Sadly, the multiplayer is dead, therefore I can't comment on that. However, Spec Ops The Line is a great buy if you're looking for a compelling story and a different experience from the ''B-b-bloody screen! SO REAAAAL!'' mainstream war games.Do you feel like a hero yet?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Well, I finished this game almost at once, so we can kinda say it sucked me in. Let's start with a little summary of the game.Spec Ops: The Line is a rather linear TPS with a couple of places you can make your own decision between♥♥♥♥♥♥ and even bigger♥♥♥♥♥♥ And you'll feel♥♥♥♥♥♥in the end. The story:Delta Force sent to Dubai for a recon mission that quickly turns into a rescue mission, then into a "shoot everything that moves" mission. It gets confusing at times, but the end (which I won't spoil you) helps. It's...not what you'd expect. You start out as your standard US Soldier shooter with the grizzled veterans shouting commands, shooting baddies, being badass, but that quickly turns around. You are just a piece of the chess game of the forces behind the scenes. To give credit to the game, the story of Dubai getting hit by sandstorms, and getting Fallout'd is rather cool. And the visuals match, but bit later about that.Through the game I felt I was playing a TV series. Heck, it'd make a bloody good mini-series - about 6 episodes or so. The characters are good, and while not overdetailed, they do their job. And when I finished it, I felt like after a good TV show or movie. It left satisfied, but somehow empty. The conversions are awesome. I had a few laughs, but the interactions between the characters never went over the top, and kept me interested throughout the story. Nobody felt flat or uninteresting, so that's a pretty good thing too.Overall, 8/10. I had little to no expectations, but left with something I won't forget soon.Gameplay:It's a rather standard TPS with a decent selection of firearms. You get Assault Rifles, Shotguns, Pistols, SMGs, LMGs, and so forth. Most of them has a secondary mode, which is to say switch the sniper rifle's zoom (from 8x to 16x), or put a sound suppressor to the M4A1. It's fun, and while the diversity forces you to either be a really accurate shooter, or switch your weapons frequently. Ammo boxes scattered around the maps help you. The cover system while sometimes tad awkward, is good. Made me think of Mass Effect. In every section you can find pieces of intels - a great way for knowing the backstory a bit better, and adds to the overall feel to the game. You'll be more disturbed after you find them fo' sure. Sometimes they are at obvious places, but you gotta look for the to find all.The game is rather linear, but with a game like this, it's not much of a problem. I wouldn't list this as a pro, but neither as a con. It's just linear and that's it. 7/10 - you'll remember the game for the story, as the gameplay is, while rather flowing, brings nothing new.The visuals:Like in my Sleeping Dogs review (which you probably haven't read, but I like to mention my other written stuffs), I have to state I don't have the full specifics to play the game on High graphics. I went with medium, and it ran with about 30 fps. For me, it's solid, and the game, while not gorgeous, it looked good. The Sandstorm'd Dubai (which is almost Darude, but let's stay away from memes for a second) looks good. It's pretty detailed, and I never got bored of the environment. It wasn't exactly the same as far as I recall, and fighting on the top of a skyscraper is a nice change after eating sand on ground level. It matched the game, so I'm fine with it as is.Overall a 8/10.Sounds:Okay, this is awesome. The mad DJ with the hits of the 80s that he plays seemingly random, the ambient music, and the OST for the game is AWESOME. Fitting, believable, and you'll feel that it gives a lot to the game. You'll eventually search for the OST on Youtube, and save it to listen later. It's really good. Kudos to the composer.10/10Overall I'd give this game a 8.5 out of 10, totally worth playing, and totally worth your money. Be aware of the graphic images of gore, death, and the feeling of emptiness and guilt after you've finished the game, regardless of your choices.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Nolan North voicing the main character is a strong selling point in this game. As tired as I am of 1st Person militaristic shooters like Call of Duty and Battlefield, with all their awestruck destruction and "omg" comradery moments, it's a tired genre. Well this is a 3rd person action adventure game with incredibly well done sand effects that apply to combat. Like shooting a glass ceiling and watching the sand envelop your enemies. Fighting in sandstorms provides intense drama during the impaired visibility. This game takes you on a journey, both storywise and comraderywise with your two cohorts. There's moments that blur the lines between right and wrong and survival and completing the mission. The lines really blur when you fight American troops because they shoot at you first. Trying to figure out what happened before the sandstorm took down Dubai and where all the survivors and the troops are, is so intense.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a third-person shooter telling the story of US captain Walker, who is sent to Dubai to investigate the failed evacuation of the city after it has been hit by several huge sandstorms.Gameplay-wise, Spec Ops is your average tps: you need to master taking cover in order to survive and use the game's environment to your advantage (explosives, sand drops, ...). Althought the enemies are kind of repetitive and the various encounters basically the same, the title is entertaining and playable enough. It also spots an average lenght (five or six hours, on an average).The strongest suits of Spec Ops: The Line are its visuals and atmosphere. The plot and the situations you will find yourself in are basically severe deconstruction on the most abused cliches of modern military shooters. The sanity slippage suffered by the protagonist and the general lack of choices in some instances just add to general surreal theme of the title.All in all, Spec Ops: The Line is a very atmospheric game and a good gaming experiment in its own right

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												The "Apocalypse Now" of videogames.This game isnt perfect. The campaign has a dissapointing length of 6-7 hours, which isn't bad, but at the same time does not allow spec ops to explore war as much as I might have liked. The gameplay is clunky, with mechanics which sometimes stop working (I oft died when if the game was working I'd have been fine). Lastly, there were some technical issues (the sound didnt work in one cutscene).Besides that however, Spec Ops stands with BioShock and Heavy Rain as one of the best stoies in videogame history. It explores the horrors of war in a brutal, dark way, where the characters become less and less likable, and the insanity builds and builds until the terror soaked climax. Did I mention this and "Apocalypse Now" were based on "Heart of Darkness"? It will leave you wondering weather or not there are heroes in war, and the brutal violence throughout helps to create a dark vision of war. Such a shame that a brilliant story is ruined by iffy gameplay and a short runtime.7/10

Posted: January 22, 2013
												It's hard to give a fair accounting of Spec Ops: The Line because listing what makes it worthwhile is pretty much damning with faint praise. Is doing a war game with better accounting of moral consequences than other military shooters an accomplishment?If games are to be judged by the extent to which they achieve their filmic ambitions, SOTL is a Michael Moore flick: Well presented and touching on important points but nothing new to anyone who pays attention and by its very reputation unlikely to reach the people who might be exposed to a new idea. The overwrought praise for SOTL more or less damns it to never be played by fans of the dudebro shooters whose conventions SOTL seeks to upend.SOTL isn't going to blow your mind and its cover shooter mechanics are pretty humdrum and workmanlike -- think the Mass Effect series stripped of its RPG elements.That said, it still has Hollywood ambitions in its presentation and visuals. Its storyline, while not deserving of the hype it receives, is still enjoyable and a nice break from the spiritual and moral poison of your typical rah-rah army shooters.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2012
												Holy Hells. Playing this game is like being punched repeatedly in the gut and then forced to watch someone strangle a puppy. In the best way possible.The game is simultaneously a self-aware critique of modern shooters, an "Apocalypse Now" for the new generation, and as I've described it to several friends: the feel-bad game of the decade. Do not play this game for the gameplay. The gameplay was very good in my opinion, but I do not play many 3rd-person cover-based shooters, and people who do that I have talked with tell me that it is not particularly good on that front. No, instead play this game for the emotional, mentally crushing kick to the groin that it delivers very slowly over the course of a six hour single player campaign. I don't think any other game has made me physically sick with this unique cocktail of revulsion, guilt, and cognitive dissonance. I believe it was somewhere around the point when the loading screen asked me "Do you feel like a hero yet?" and I replied simperingly out loud "No, no I just want to go home, please," that I realized what a real work of art this game was. So, if you're just looking for another mindless CoD or Battlefield clone, please, avoid this game, it probably isn't for you. But if you are instead looking for a game that will make you rethink the nature of morality, war, and sanity, give this game a go. You won't be dissappointed.

content: Posted: December 29, 2013 Spec Ops: The Line is a fairly straight forward, third-person cover based shooter (like Gears of War). Set in the sand storm beset city of Dubai, you play as Captain Martin Walker of Delta Force, leading Lieutenant Adams and Sergeant Lugo in what begins as a simple recon mission but quickly becomes much more. Having been inspired by the book Heart of Darkness (which in turn inspired the film Apocalypse Now), probably the game's strongest suit is its story. We'll get to that in a bit. This review was written after one play through on the default campaign difficulty.GAMEPLAYThe mechanics of the game are nothing revolutionary, but they work functionally. Controls are fairly responsive, and unlike Gears of War, I didn't run into the problem of sprinting into cover I didn't want or exiting it when I didn't want to. However, the sprint button and the enter cover button are on the same key, so if you are sprinting to cover you need to press the button once to enter a sprint (the button doesn't need to be held) and then press again to enter cover. Vaulting over cover is assigned to a separate button, which helps ease the pain of accidentally exiting cover when you don't want to. You carry two weapons at a time, and switching between them is bound to a key (by default, the mouse wheel toggles between your three different grenade types) while activating alternate fire/alternate functions is bound to a separate key. Aiming grenade throws is pretty easy as well, as all that is required is you hold the button to bring up a targeting arc that will show you where the grenade will land upon releasing the button. Lastly, you have a melee key, which will also trigger a brutalized execution animation for foes who have been temporarily incapacitated and are on the floor but not dead.The variety of guns is about what you would expect from a game of this sort. The major division of guns are rifles, sniper rifles, shotguns, small arms, and heavy weapons. Most weapons have an alternative fire mode (such as burst mode for the FAMAS and the AK-47, which supposedly increases ranged accuracy) or an alternative function (such as the scope for the 417 or the suppressor for the M4A1). The game warns that ammo for weapons is scarce in Dubai, but there were only a few heavy firefights that left me strapped for ammo and most of the time enemies drop plenty (or there are ammo boxes scattered about the battlefield that refill a significant amount of rounds). The gameplay varies with the weapon you choose – shotguns and sub machine guns require you to get in closer and be more aggressive, whereas rifles and sniper rifles allow you stay at a longer range and take well placed shots to take out enemies. Generally, I found rifles to be the superior weapon type, as enemy AI played into rifle gunplay quite well.One thing this game is sorely lacking in is enemy variety and enemy AI. For the first half of the game, you'll be fighting the same type of enemy (sort of – without spoiling anything, enemies change models but are for all intents the same type) until you're introduced to a slightly more armored variant of the standard foe, who can take a couple headshots instead of just one before being downed. The last and most annoying enemy to face are called “heavies,” and they are heavily armored and armed foes that take several explosives or a lot of ammo to bring down (even if you're scoring direct hits to their unexposed face). As far as AI goes, most soldiers hide behind cover and pop out to take shots, advancing or retreating to gain a slightly better position, with shotgunners, SMG wielders or bayonet soldiers rushing you at melee range. From time to time, you can use the environment against enemies by shooting out ceilings and causing sand to fall on them, but opportunities for this are rare.The game also features a rudimentary squad based command system. Certain contextual situations will allow you to press a key (middle mouse button by default) to have your squad mates throw a stun grenade, or heal a downed squad mate. Holding the key and targeting an enemy then releasing the key orders your squad to attack that enemy, which usually results in Sergeant Lugo sniping them. In the rare cases where you're undiscovered by the enemy, ordering an attack will cause your squad to use silenced weapons so long as you remain unspotted from the enemy.I was unable to play any of the multiplayer modes the game has to offer.STORYThe game's story is its strongest suit. The basic set up is as follows: Delta Force Captain Martin Walker is sent into Dubai along with Lieutenant Adams and Sergeant Lugo to assess the ongoing evacuation and report back to command. In the first level, insurgents have apparently attacked the 33rd Battalion, headed by Colonel Konrad, and so the mission changes to a rescue operation. Things become increasingly complicated as the game goes on, and it forces you into uncomfortable moral quandaries as only war can. But it appears that at the center of all the madness of war and the state of affairs of Dubai is Colonel Konrad, who Captain Walker pursues with a single minded earnestness. There are several factions at work in Dubai, including insurgent rebels, the local civilians, Colonel Konrad's 33rd Battalion, and even the CIA. The game features a twist ending as well that leaves final interpretation up to the player. GRAPHICS/SOUNDPlaying on max detail, I thought the game looked very good. It also performed well on my system, never losing frames even when there were dozens of enemies and explosions going off all over the place. However, the graphics options didn't seem very customizable compared to most PC games, giving you a scant handful of settings to tweak with. I could see how someone with a lower end system might have a problem configuring the game to look good and run well at the same time since the options are sparse.Sound was also fine. The music was entirely forgetable, but the voice acting was well done and sound effects were right for a game of this type.PLAY TIME/REPLAYABILITYAccording to Steam, I beat the game in six hours. Replayability is also low, unless you want to go achievement hunting or for whatever reason play on a harder difficulty. I played on the normal difficulty; if you pick the hardest one available from the start and beat the game on that, it unlocks an even harder difficulty, so if you're into that sort of thing there's some replayability there. FINAL RECOMMENDATIONSpec Ops might not be worth the default asking price of $30 for such a limited experience, both in the time it takes to beat the campaign and the banal lack of variety that firefights provide. The experience amounts to an extended interactive movie, of a sort, and the story it has to tell is interesting and I believe well done. I personally purchased the game on sale for $15 and feel it was a worthy experience, and one I may return to at some point in the future.
