content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												Where do I start with this game?...Well, the sound track was absolutely beautiful. It's all your fault. The game was also very very beautiful, both graphics and scenery-wise. It does a great job of allowing you to use the environment againt your enemies. No more water. It also does a really good job at preventing you from having 9999+ bullets like most FPSs, but also doesn't make it feel like you're forever trapped in a limbo with having bullets and then having none for a long time. And prehaps the best bit of the game is its immersion, I truly felt like I was in every moment of it. That it was I who made the choices, I killed them. But they were suffering, weren't they? From start to finish in this 11 hour give or take game, it was truly amazing. I highly suggest you buy Spec Ops: The Line. Truly it is a gem in the gaming industry...but...I just have to ask you one thing reader......Do you feel like a hero now?

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												It starts as a Bad Company style buddy war shooter game, and from there it just descends. The brutality escalates, becoming more and more savage as you march onward, your friends slowly torn apart and your very sanity coming into question. I was awestruck, cut down by the brutality and the true, unbridled monstrosity. You don't play this game, it plays you. It tore at me and ate away as I followed the descent into the darkest, blood-stained pits of human brutality. This is a horror game, if by horror you mean it's horrific. I sat there as the credits rolled, disgusted at myself, repulsed by the things I had done regardless of whether or not they were necessary. I felt like the scum of the earth, a murderous sadist and brutal killer. There was no reprive. No sugar coating. No justification. No mercy. Sheer, unbridled atrocity, and you are responsible.10/10, I recommend it

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												This game is more than just another ordinary shooter, this game is more than a video game. I got this game through the Humble Bundle deal a while back and I kind of just shrugged it off, didn't think much of it. I can now say that I was foolish for neglecting this game. I had played through the first 30 minutes and then left it for months on end until about a week ago, when I decided to play it again. Let me tell you something, this game hits you in the blind spot. You expect another shooter but instead, you get this rich story, well developed characters that actually feel important, and gritty action that I have not seen in a shooter in a while. The decisions and consequences of your actions can very well depict the harsh reality of warfare, and the life in general. This game flows really well, and does not miss a beat. The beginning may come off slow, but stick with it and you will be rewarded. The combat may take a bit to get used to, but the mechanics are fairly decent for a third person shooter. I sometimes found myself getting "lost" during combat, especially when a grenade is thrown, I found myself sprinting towards the grenade because of mechanical issues. Aside from that, I have almost no negative comments about this game. But to be fair, the game is still far from a 10, so I would give this game a solid 8.5/10. But don't let that score fool you, I still very much enjoyed this game and I'm sure you will too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												So far in my life I have only played two games with such moral complexity that I would say as a gamer, you HAVE to play them. One of those games is Shadow of the Colossus and the other one is.... Spec-Ops: The Line. I'm not going to spoil the big plot twists because this is a game that spoilers will ruin. I can't stress how much you need to play Spec-Ops: The Line. Anyway, over all Spec-Ops: The Line is a sophisticated deconstruction of the modern warfare genre and one of the most down right brilliant games I have ever played. So when you start Spec-Ops, the first hour is nothing special. You play as Captain Walker, a special forces operative on a mission to rescue civilians in Dubai because massive sandstorms have totaled the city. The game starts as your typical, generic, linear, modern-warfare shooter as you meaninglessly gun down "enemies". It's not until after the first hour when the game starts getting interesting. You quickly find that things are not as what they seem then plot twists unfold and by the end you are left thinking about who is really the bad guy. Usually I say that a good game connects gameplay, narrative, and design which Spec-Ops: The Line does this flawlessly. The design starts off very modern as the story and gameplay are utterly generic. But as the narrative starts to dive into the psyche of Captain Walker as he goes totally insane, the design of the dull environments seamlessly transitions into looking and feeling more vivid, colorful, and surreal. Gameplay isn't anything special, you just shoot tons of people like any other modern warfare game but it's amazing how the narrative contextualizes and comments on the gameplay by asking questions like who were those people, why are you shooting them, why does that make you the hero, and what is any of the killing even worth? The gameplay also feels clunky and stressful which these mechanics intentionally feel this way to serve as metaphors that help express some of the major themes of the narritive during gameplay. The narrative paints most of your actions in the game with a coat of moral ambiguity which makes Spec-Ops: The Line profound, brilliant, and complex. As for the plot, it is driven by Captain Walker's coherent character arc as he and his squad are isolated and thrown into a hostile environment and any humanity is stripped away along with compassion, reason, and rationality until only a monster remains. But it's brilliant how Spec-Ops questions the morality of the player by involving them in the gameplay because we essentially control Captain Walker. This raises some interesting questions about the relationship between player and player-character. Are Walker's actions merely our own? Or do we just represent the last thoughts of reason in his damaged mind as he railroads us into committing more war crimes. Even the gameplay starts reflecting the narrative as Walker goes more and more insane, his hallucinations slowly start becoming intertwined with gameplay until you aren't even sure what is real or not. This game is a masterpiece in storytelling and you just have to experience it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												This game is tedious, annoying, frustrating and simply not much fun.And that's what makes it so great."What?" You might be asking yourself. What makes a tedious, unfun game so great? Is it some kind of "So bad it's good" kind of thing? Absolutely not, it was made this way intentionally, and for very good reasons. Spec Ops: The Line is very much like Schindler's List. You're not supposed to feel good about it once you've gone throught he story.The real problem with reviewing a game like this is that, without giving out spoilers, it's impossible to find a way to say, "Ya, play it guys, seriously!" Without some kind of attempt to list out what makes this game special, all I can say is, "The gameplay is lackluster, there are obvious monster closets, the AI is horrid and the multiplayer should have just been ignored entirely. I totally recommend this, 8/10." And that comes off as just strange.So, to try and do this without spoiling too much (and if I do, I apologize for the unintentional spoil), Spec Ops is less a game and more a thematic deconstruction and criticism of modern military shooters. And by deconstruction, I mean a total, across the board deconstruction. The game goes all-in on many gaming tropes and points out various areas that could easily use improvement or development into a generally quality mechanic and also makes it a point to deconstruct the players who play military shooters themselves.The following topics are given a deep insight:- The player's relationship with the main character- Who really controls who? Does the player control the character or is the game controlling the player?- The effects of dehumanizing the enemy on a person and, by extension, the player- Tedious gameplay that highlights the effects and shock of what people experience in combat- Moral ambiguity and a lack of any real clear "good" or "evil" in the game- Demonstratably real effects of cognitive dissonance experienced by returning soldiers suffering PTSD- The illusion of choice in video games- How easy it is to convince people to blame others for "forcing" them into choices they don't have to makeA particular poignant point takes part in the final acts of the game where the game questions if you, the player, are beyond help and are incapable of seeing what's beyond Call of Duty and its clones and pre-emptively telling anyone that scores the game low due to monster closets and tedious third person cover shooting mechanics that they completely missed the point and are beyond help.Everything about the game is designed as intentional and develops a deep experience that's difficult to find in gaming. While games like The Stanley Parable do a good job parodying the insanity of player choice, it fails to truly get the player to stop and think about it, let alone cast a wide net over the entire first person shooter genre and intelligently question nearly every gameplay mechanic, enemy AI complexity, faceless enemy syndrome, plot decisions and concept of legitimate choice.If it wasn't for the deliberate end-game reveal, various load screen quotes and even the changing menu screen graphic, I would have simply thrown this game to the side as some kind of boring, derivitive shooter trying to be macho. But everything about this game is lovingly intentional, from the three man squad with token black man explosive expert and wisecracking white guy to wave after endless wave of idiot enemy. The whole game exists as a critique of the FPS genre, the games industry and the players themselves. And it's not a caustic, nasty critique, but one that asks us to think why we suffer through these mechanics and why we don't demand improvement or something better. Even using the fact that this game can be called "Spec Ops 11" is deep in and of itself since using a brand new IP would have missed out on critically adressing the excessive sequelitis that the gaming industry is stuck in.Spec Ops: The Line is a bad and tedious game, but it's meant to be, and with the plot and decisions made within the game itself turns it into a brilliant commentary on what has happened to the games industry and the modern games consumer. I highly recommend you experience it in full to understand for yourself what's happening. It's a game that needs to be played since those Let's Play videos will do it a disservice as your active participation is necessary to get the complete experience as to what Yaeger is attempting to tell us all.And I thank Yaeger for making me think.The gameplay is lackluster, there are obvious monster closets, the AI is horrid and the multiplayer should have just been ignored entirely. I totally recommend this, 8/10.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												On the surface, this game looks like anyother war shooter. You're an American soldier tearing through enemy forces and trying to be the God dang hero! To be honest, Spec ops' gameplay doesnt add much when compared to other third person shooters. But this isnt a game about being a hero, this is a game about war , and in some sense, a game about games. A game that holds you accountable for every life you take, every action you chose, and makes you really think everytime you pull the trigger.  Spec ops adds a new deminsion to the War genre, and blurs the lines between good and evil, right and wrong, etc. As you play, you will begin to notice a twist in the games identity from generic war shooter, to horrific game depicting the harsh reprocusions of war. The character development in this game is unreal and is what really drives this game home. You will see the degredation of your squads morals, mental health, and humanity as they have to deal with the reprocusions of your actions. While the gameplay is somewhat lackluster, the story is truly the best part about this game, and i would easily recommend it to someone who is looking for one heck of a story, and a life ruining experience!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												Suicide Mission was chosen for my first run, and Fubar second time.No spoilers in this review, after all, there is no fun if you know any story of it before enjoying it.Compared with other shooting games, Spec Ops: The Line is not unique at all or even much more tedious about its gameplay. What players have to do is shoot targets, take cover from gunfire and  move on to a next point, continuously.Control is a bit clumsy, sometimes it may get you killed and repeating under some critical situations couple times. For instance, Sprinting to sandbags for cover, taking cover and vaulting through it, all of the movements do not seem to flow smoothly. Mere conditions that some spots look available to interact with, like beside a low closet of a bar table,  actually not for cover,  are annoying.Graphics is not that appealing even in 2012 , but it is still fine and acceptable. Personally, I like how the developer created the feel while a desert storm is striking. When headshots happen, there is a moment of slow motion effect. With some high-caliber rounded weapons, there is also a gore effect.Music is great, and some classic old rock songs are introduced as well.The essence of this game is about its storyline. I guess that is something worth playing, especially for players who have played lots of shooting games, shooting games especially like CODs. Spec Ops: The Line will definitely blow your mind and thought on shooting games.If you are an enthusiastic shoot'em up gamer and want something different, this game is absolutely for you.Strongly advised, do not read any articles related to its story before finishing the whole game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												A clever experience, one wrapped in a familiar story and predictable rhythm:  A special operations team is dispatched to Dubai following a massive sandstorm and a communications blackout to determine what happened in the silent city.The third-person gameplay feels immediately familiar with cover, headshots and team orders.  The colorful environments and dilapidated city create a wonderful background to close-quarters firefights and hallway progression.Then...Then something starts happening.  Your squad starts making decisions.  They aren't the cleanest kind.  The more you look at what you're doing (if you look at all between the gunfights) the more you question what's really happening.By the time your tour in Dubai is over, you will have been witness to stunning human tragedy, a heavy-pitted feeling of betrayal and an aching need to determine just what the hell happened to make things go so bad.And if for some reason you remain unfettered by moral quandary, at least it's a solid cover-based shooter.Spec Ops: The Line is not really meant to be enjoyed light-heartedly, but is a delight to be experienced with an open mind.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												There are stories out there (be it movies, books, or in this case, video games) where it is highly encouraged to experience with 0 prior knowledge.  I would suggest doing so with this game, but let's be honest, you most likely know that this game leaves you with some heavy emotional baggage.  With that said, I will do my best to avoid any plot-specific details, and instead, mention their presence.This falls into shooter subgenre, the 'Modern Military Shooter'.  The subgenre is classified by solely focusing on Multiplayer, with short, linear campaigns, because making a game that's multiplayer only isn't worth 60$ (though the Single Player isn't valuable). The gameplay itself relies on hitscan weapons (weapons where bullet travel is instant, and explosives travel about as fast), very low damage threshold, and regenerating health.  I bring this up because Spec Ops dumps their eggs into single player, and only added multiplayer because 2K requested it.  Without getting into finer details, the gameplay doesn't derive itself very far.The story is more than serviceable; it's good.  The story is based around the special operatives Walker, Lugo, and Adams going into a post-apocalyptic Dubai to find signs of life, and if so, leave and signal for a rescue team.  It takes you less than a tutorial level to find out a bunch of anti-American zealots  have taken a marine trooper hostage and plan to execute him.  So, instead of finding out about survivors and leaving, you go after the hostage.  Along the way of killing survivors in self defense, you run into a splinter group of marines who you trade bullets with.  So now, you are killing marines who survived the apocalyptic sandstorms, and the citizens of Dubai.  This is counter-intuitive to saving the city and its people.  The events that transpire end up getting to our three generic grumps, who end up going crazy and stricken with PTSD the more the game goes on.  The descent into trauma is the best part of this game.  At the start of the game, you're talking with your squad using terms like "tango down" or "target down", and as the game goes along, slowly degrades into Nolan North shouting incoherently.  The problem is that the whole game, you're told that you're responsible for all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ problems that you experience, while the player is disempowered from being responsible for the situation.  The developers say that your power as the player is to whether or not you quit the game or keep playing, and even incited this mid-way through the game.  I don't think I need to point out how juvenile of an excuse that is.  The only option is option A, I took option A, and now the game is telling me I'm a monster for taking option A.  I don't mind that the characters start to slowly lose their sanity, because they are empowered as human beings, and do debatably evil things.  I, as a player, am coerced into doing debatably evil things.  There's a plot twist at the end which I'm not going to spoil, because, you know, you're reading this to debate whether or not to buy this game, but do know that it almost ruined the entire experience, because it was so bad.The gameplay is vanilla with a cherry on top; a bland, but competent formula with a topping that is in and of itself bland.  You have a cover shooting system, weapons that do a lot of damage, recoil, but are samey.  You have a heavy assault partner, and a sniper.  You can make them focus on killing certain people, and, if you're pinned, they can throw a flashbang grenade to save your♥♥♥♥♥  Between Elizabeth in Bioshock Infite and Ashley in Resident Evil 4, their AI is closer to Elizabeth, while not being absolute game breakers.  I played on Hard, and it definitely kicked my♥♥♥♥♥  I'd recommend playing on Hard because you're supposed to be playing a game that makes you feel like♥♥♥♥♥♥ and making it difficult on top of that helps.  The game does get more difficult as it goes on, because your cover options become less and less suitable, though they do throw a meat shield or two your way, and your only option is to kill them before they kill you.For a game with the words "Spec Ops", I don't really feel like a special forces agent.  If I were a heavily trained soldier, with a focus on saving lives, I would imagine being more like Naked Snake or Adam Jensen where, while I can fight in open combat, prefer to not be caught.  You're given silencers on your base guns, but those silencers don't matter when the level designs don't permit this gameplay.  Instead, the levels cater to set piece battles (a real problem with cover shooters, sadly).  I do think that the game's story would have been damaged though, if you managed to get through almost all of the game without getting caught, and are then told by the game that you're a horrible dude because you killed all those guys.  I do have legitimate problems with this game.  It does have a good story that does throw some legitimate sucker punches at the players, with what is most likely the best story of any modern military shooter in a superb environment.  However, the gameplay detracts from the whole experience, because you have no choice (or illusion of choice at points), and are treated like you did.  I leave it with a recommendation, because I can tell people to play this game comfortably, but you might find the game's hollow gameplay and disgusting plot twist detract too far from the game.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												This game looks and feels like a generic third person shooter with Gear of War type mechanics like the cover system (Which I will mention later about) and the running. However, the game was tempting you to follow its story of your standard shooter of just killing the badies and terrorists in a war. It seemed normal, but later on you will feel as though that something is not right. But as soon as you know it, it is too late and shows you the TRUE horror of war. Never I felt a game hurt you so much of showing you the true monster and bad guy... YOU. This makes any other shooter to go down in shame with this game showing the PTSD inducing and fears of what war actually does to us. It doesn't make us heroic. It makes us turn into a monster that we weren't supposed to be. The gameplay isn't bad since it is just like any third person shooter, but the cover system (like mentioned before) is terrible since it is too sticky that you can run into enemy fire and get cheap deaths. The game has many choices, but unlike other games with morals of good and bad. This game has not a single good moral one, it will hurt you no matter the choice you picked.The multiplayer is not bad, but is forced to put in. It is basically your standard shooter modes and has classes. It is not the game's best, but is okay enough for a few matches.Overall, if you want a take from a shooter fan (like me), but want to see something new in a darker tone. I highly recommend this game. This game is like Call of Duty's and Battlefield's (and any other shooter's) dark brother that loves to torment people into crying.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Unique TPS with good gameplay mechanics, an apocalypse-now type story and an excellent setting.Good♥♥♥♥♥♥+The setting is one of my favourites so far in gaming. Think a creative, beautiful and post apocalyptic Dubai.+Story is interesting and different than the norm with subtle clues and interesting decisions.+Gameplay mechanics worked well for me, but not for some. It's mainly a cover based shooter.+Style, sounds, weapons and music. The main title has (I think) Star Spangled Banner by Jimi Hendrix playing.+Melee finishers on downed enemies work nicely. No instant takedowns.+Multiplayer is actually pretty good. There's free co-op to but I havn't tried it yet.+(MINOR SPOILER) As the story progresses your character's finishing moves and "taunts" get more brutal. Nice touch.Don't feel right: -The shooting can get somewhat repetetive as there is not a lot of variation in what you can do.-Little replay value unless you want the story again from a more understanding perspective.Conclusion:The game is solid and of appropriate length for a shooter. I'm glad they didn't drag it out unecessarily and that the gameplay mechanics are of good quality. Nothing ruins immersion and good story like bad gameplay. Sadly the story didn't get a hold of me emotionally as it did for some, I really wish I could get into it but I just couldn't get real emotion from it as a whole. Certain parts got to me a little but not overwhelmingly. Still, it was a very satisfying take on one of my favourite tales: man goes into darkness and creates his own vision of society. Certain parts of the story/ending confused me a little but the whole thing is up to interpretation and certainly worth venturing into. Games like Far Cry 3, The Last of Us (especially), Mass Effect series and MGS series are examples of what engaged me emotionally. It's unfortunate that this did not but I still loved the experience and was always eager to play on and uncover the story unfolding. Maybe I've played too many shooters and become a little detached, who knows? Throughout the story you will get to make a few moral decisions but I won't say any more on that.Anyway, I'd give it a 9/10 easily, a full 10 if it had increased combat options/variation. I'm not gonna mark it down for failing to grab me as it did for others, however, as it deserves praise nonetheless.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line is a game where everything but the gameplay is top notch. What it does well is the setting which is the beautiful Dubai and the time they put into the detail made me really believe I was there. I especially liked the fish tanks. The amazing soundtrack which features Deep Purple and Jimi Hendrix and the absolutely excellent voice acting surpised me and there was a great plot with a tweeeest.It's just a shame that despite all this, the gameplay is just bog standard third person shooting you've seen in a million and one games already. It's all go into next room, suspiciously also full of chest high objects to take cover behind (!) and kill them nasty americans before moving on which has been done to death. There are some neat little things they've added though such as shooting windows with sand behind will crush the enemies dumb enough to stand next to them.Moving on, there are some powerful scenes in this game. My personal favourite is the white phosporus scene, it just hits you hard once you've realised what you've done. It's clear the game wants to think about what you're being ordered to do and in the finale basically tells you that you're far from the hero you think you are. It's a rather hamfisted way to get you to think about what you're doing in other games but I admire the devs for doing this.The voice acting changes throughout the game, as the missions and the plot progresses you and your men go from calmly talking and ordering around to full on shouting. I really like this as it does help the plot convey how far gone the main character is. Another part of the audio is the soundtrack, it matches the tone of every situation you're in and the radio man really knows how to set the mood when he deploys songs like Nowhere to Run. In conclusion, Spec Ops: The Line is a great game to pick up. It's an enjoyable experience which could've been amazing if not for the typical whack-a-mole third person gameplay. Pick it up for £10 or less if you can.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												Simply amazing.A MUST PLAY for anyone who loves storytelling in games. This one is on par with the greats like Bioshock and Portal.WARNING:THIS IS NOT A CALL OF DUTY CLONE LIKE THE TRAILERS AND BOX ART WOULD HAVE YOU BELIEVE, IT IS BASICALLY THE MOST ANTI-CALL OF DUTY TRIPLE A SHOOTER GAME EVER MADE.THIS GAME ISN'T "FUN" IT'S ENGAGING AND THOUGHT PROVOKING AND YOU WILL NOT HAVE A TRADITIONAL GOOD TIME PLAYING IT!The best way to explain what this game is to start at it's creation.Spec Ops was a shooter series that nobody cared about in the late 90s/early 2000s.2K (the publisher) wanted Yager (the developers) to make a new Spec Ops game. It could be about ANYTHING so long as it was about the US military.What they made was a decent into madness that will make you rethink everything you knew about the Modern Military genre.Many games are "adult" because they have violence and sexual themes, though children still play and enjoy them. This game is adult because it's got mature themes and will make you think.I can't spoil ANYTHING because it's best to go in completely fresh but it's amazingly dark and you will feel awful after beating it, but in a good way.Gameplay's standard MMS fare but played from a third person perspective, similarly to Gears of War. The shooting feels good and they keep adding new, varied weapons to keep things at least somewhat varied. The cover mechanics are pretty clunky and awkward and It all gets kinda boring.But it's not about that, it's about the story.Play this if you want something that questions the MMS genre.Play this if you want to play something that makes you feel awful and think.DON'T play this if you want a pro-USA shooter where you kill the terrorists and stop World War 3.I wholeheartedly reccomend this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												This game is amazing because, like most people have pointed out, it breaks alot of "norms" in the shooter genre. The story is amazing, and by the end of it all you genuinely feel bad for walker and for yourself for the things you have done. Alot of reviewers have said that while the story is good the gameplay leaves alot to be desired. Im not really going to argue that but i will say that the shooting mechanics get the job done. This is a 3rd person cover based shooter. There is not really much room to "revolutionize" the industry in terms of shooting mechanics here. It gets the job done and thats it. I found the gameplay fun, and the AI, while not exactly Skynet level intelligent, DOES attempt to give you a hard time if you dont take them out quickly. They will flank you, and use grenades quite frequently (i was playing on the hardest initial difficulty, before unlocking the FUBAR difficulty). A wider choice in weaponry would have been welcome, and perhaps some sort of weapon customization options, but considering the type of game this is, weapon customization would have probably not been incredibly useful overall anyways.What i appreciate the most though, above everything else, are the subtle changes to Walkers character and personality as the game progresses. I dont want to spoil anything, but i will say this: from the start of the game pay attention to how walker acts. From reloading, to taking out enemies, to using the teammate commands. EVERYTHING. Then notice towards the end of the game how he handles taking out enemies, how he gets impatient and screams while reloading, how progressively more brutal and unneccesarily cruel executions become.This is definitely a game that deserves your time. It has an amazing story, amazing characters, and the gameplay is solid. I highly recommend playing this game on the hardest initial difficulty though, because on normal it can feel a tad on the easy side.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												This game is amazing because, like most people have pointed out, it breaks alot of "norms" in the shooter genre. The story is amazing, and by the end of it all you genuinely feel bad for walker and for yourself for the things you have done. Alot of reviewers have said that while the story is good the gameplay leaves alot to be desired. Im not really going to argue that but i will say that the shooting mechanics get the job done. This is a 3rd person cover based shooter. There is not really much room to "revolutionize" the industry in terms of shooting mechanics here. It gets the job done and thats it. I found the gameplay fun, and the AI, while not exactly Skynet level intelligent, DOES attempt to give you a hard time if you dont take them out quickly. They will flank you, and use grenades quite frequently (i was playing on the hardest initial difficulty, before unlocking the FUBAR difficulty). A wider choice in weaponry would have been welcome, and perhaps some sort of weapon customization options, but considering the type of game this is, weapon customization would have probably not been incredibly useful overall anyways.What i appreciate the most though, above everything else, are the subtle changes to Walkers character and personality as the game progresses. I dont want to spoil anything, but i will say this: from the start of the game pay attention to how walker acts. From reloading, to taking out enemies, to using the teammate commands. EVERYTHING. Then notice towards the end of the game how he handles taking out enemies, how he gets impatient and screams while reloading, how progressively more brutal and unneccesarily cruel executions become.This is definitely a game that deserves your time. It has an amazing story, amazing characters, and the gameplay is solid. I highly recommend playing this game on the hardest initial difficulty though, because on normal it can feel a tad on the easy side.

												Um dos jogos que mais gerou debates nos últimos anos, Spec Ops mostrou o que pode ser feito para se passar uma mensagem forte a quem joga.Utilizando da mesma jogabilidade de todo shooter já feito como elemento de crítica e quebrando a quarta parede de forma genial (“matar civis é um crime de guerra, mas isso é só um jogo, então você não se importa com isso, certo?”), Spec Ops te eleva a herói nos primeiros momentos, só para te dar rasteira e fazer você se sentir mal ao puxar o gatilho e matar mais um “inimigo”.É um jogo que me deixou num estado de choque durante todo o tempo que joguei, e me fez ter arrepios sempre que escuto as palavras “fósforo branco”.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												I went into this game expecting an entertaining third person cover based shooter. What I received instead was a story centered game focusing on the difficult and ethical dilemmas faced in extreme wartime as well as the effects they have on relationships and one's sanity. The story alone makes the game worth playing but add in the gameplay which is excellently done third person shooter style, the game morphs into a surprising addition to my favorite games. Story: 8/10 - Interesting and surprisingly emotional storyline following three special ops soldiers attempted rescue of hostages in Dubai.Gameplay: 6/10 - The gameplay is excellently done in the way that it is a deeply addictive third person sprint to cover shooter. My one problem is that it does get fairly repetitive and while playing on the more difficult modes does add to the challenge and enjoyability it does not lessen the repetitive feel of the gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Outstanding Story with a breathtaking plot with alternative endings.Spec Ops is about you, the effects of your actions, and events that are out of your control.This game defies the standard army shooter in a way that you have never seen before, it actually makes you question your actions, where you find yourself asking if killing is right or wrong.Multiplayer's a wash, but the campaign is worth replaying - seeing the same events while knowing what's really going on is uncomfortable in new ways, but the intelligent encounters and level design make each fight exciting, and the voice acting creates genuine and believable characters.Absolutely, and without a doubt, one of the best stories you'll find in any game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												         Spec Ops: The Line is not your typical run and gun it Call of Duty FPS, Spec Ops is a Third-Person Cover Fire Shooter. What makes Spec Ops BETTER than CoD and Battlefield, etc. is it's campaign story that tackles on the subjects of genocide, murder, and the morals of War. While in the begining it might seem like just another Shooter it turns out to be one of the BEST GAMES EVER MADE due to the character development and story.         [SPOILERS AHEAD] from here I'm going to talk about my fav. parts in the game in no order: "The Mortar Canon Scene" In this level you use a mortar canon to bomb the crazy amounts of enemies near you and after that when you push on it turns out they were protecting a CIVILIAN camp; inside the camp there is light shining on a mother that is completely burnt and dead holding her child (whom is also dead and burnt) to try and protect him/her from the canon fire. It was tear-jerking. "Lugo hanged by Civilians Scene" In this level you rush to save Lugo but you're too late, the civilians hanged him because YOU and Adams and Lugo took away the water supply so that Konrad and his troops would die; not knoing that the civilians would also die. Then out of anger and frustration Walker (the player) and Adams gun down the civilians. After you kill them you can't help but feel like you did the wrong thing.TL;DR Great Game, worth playing. And if you or a friend loves CoD and loves guning down random people, give them this game, it will change them...10/10 MUST PLAY

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line is a third person action shooter with some really grizzly depictions of the actions of war and the consequences of them.At first it might just seem like any other third person linear shooting game, but after a while you realize that there is something more behind the game. We follow Captain Walker and his 3-man squad of Delta Force Operators in their attempt to aid the people of Dubai and find a man called Colonel Konrad who is in charge of the American 33rd Battalion in charge of evacuating the civilians of Dubai. In their search they find themselves in difficult and harsh situations that changes their view of their mission, as well as their mind.Follow Delta Force on their journey to madness through a wartorn and sandfilled Dubai.9/10
